questions.Question: The artificial kidney is a
questions.solution: Solution:		The artificial kidney is a machine.

questions.Question: With reference to the work of human kidney consider the following statements1. After the waste is removed in the kidney the clean blood is sent back through renal artery.2. From Bowman's capsule, the filtered liquid passes through tiny tubes where much of the glucose is reabsorbed and sent back to the blood in the renal vein.Which of these statements is/are correct?
questions.solution: Solution:		From Bowman's capsule, the filtered liquid passes through tiny tubes where much of the glucose is reabsorbed and sent back to the blood in the renal vein is the correct statement.

questions.Question: Which of the following function is performed by the kidneys in the human body?
questions.solution: Solution:		Most people know that a major function of the kidneys is to remove waste products and excess fluid from the body. These waste products and excess fluid are removed through the urine. The production of urine involves highly complex steps of excretion and re-absorption.

questions.Question: Which one is located at the rear of the abdominal cavity?
questions.solution: Solution:		The abdominal cavity is lined with a protective membrane termed the peritoneum. The inside wall is covered by the parietal peritoneum. The kidneys are located behind the peritoneum, in the retroperitoneum, outside the abdominal cavity.

questions.Question: Urea is transported through
questions.solution: Solution:		Urea is the product of excess amino acids. It is transported into blood plasma by the liver and removed by the kidney. This process is called excretion.

questions.Question: Mycology is the branch of botany in which we study about
questions.solution: Solution:		Mycology is the branch of biology concerned with the study of fungi, including their genetic and biochemical properties, their taxonomy and their use to humans as a source for tinder, traditional medicine, food, and entheogens, as well as their dangers, such as toxicity or infection.

questions.Question: Mycology is the branch of botany in which we study about
questions.solution: No explanation is given for this questionLet's Discuss on Board

questions.Question: Phycology is the branch of botany in which we study about
questions.solution: Solution:		Phycology is the branch of botany in which we study about algae.

questions.Question: The DNA bacterium consists of ring-like pieces known as the
questions.solution: Solution:		The DNA bacterium consists of ring-like pieces known as the plasmids.

questions.Question: It is commonly found in the bottom tidal pools?
questions.solution: Solution:		Ulva is commonly found in the bottom tidal pools.

questions.Question: Volvox colonies are found in
questions.solution: Solution:		Volvox can be found in ponds, puddles, and bodies of still fresh water throughout the world. As autotrophs, they contribute to the production of oxygen and serve as food for a number of aquatic organisms, especially the microscopic invertebrates called rotifers.

questions.Question: Which one of the following is not reserve food of fungi?
questions.solution: Solution:		Reserve food material in all the fungi is glycogen and oil but not starch.

questions.Question: The nitrogen fixing bacteria present in the root nodules of leguminous plant is
questions.solution: Solution:		Rhizobium is a genus of bacteria associated with the formation of root nodules on plants. These bacteria live in symbiosis with legumes. They take in nitrogen from the atmosphere and pass it on to the plant, allowing it to grow in soil low in nitrogen.

questions.Question: All of the following are true of neurons except that
questions.optionB: They are a very specialized form of connective tissue
questions.optionC: Thay are separated from one another by synapses
questions.optionD: When mature, they lose ability to divide
questions.solution: Solution:		All of the following are true of neurons except that they are a very specialized form of connective tissue.

questions.Question: Synapse gap is present between which of the following?
questions.solution: Solution:		An electrical synapse is a mechanical and electrically conductive link between two neighboring neurons that is formed at a narrow gap between the pre- and postsynaptic neurons known as a gap junction.

questions.Question: Purification of blood takes place in
questions.solution: Solution:		Purification of blood takes place in kidney.

questions.Question: Fully mature human RBCs has
questions.optionC: Nucleus may or may not be present
questions.solution: Solution:		Fully mature human RBCs has no nucleus.

questions.Question: Which of the following blood group is universal donor?
questions.solution: Solution:		For emergency transfusions, blood group type O negative blood is the variety of blood that has the lowest risk of causing serious reactions for most people who receive it. Because of this, it's sometimes called the universal blood donor type.

questions.Question: Human heart is made up of
questions.solution: Solution:		An organ is a group of tissues that work together to perform a specific function. In the case of heart, this function is pumping blood throughout your body. Additionally, the heart is largely made up of a type of muscle tissue called cardiac muscle.

questions.Question: Antigens 'A' and 'B' are absent in persons belong to blood group
questions.solution: Solution:		Blood group O has no antigens, but both anti-A and anti-B antibodies in the plasma, as well as some special “anti-A,B' antibodies. Blood group AB has both A and B antigens, but no antibodies.

questions.Question: A living part of the organisms environment is known as
questions.solution: Solution:		A living part of the organisms environment is known as biotic factor.

questions.Question: Secondary consumers are eaten by larger
questions.optionB: Animal in the third trophic level
questions.solution: Solution:		Secondary consumers can be sorted into two groups: carnivores and omnivores. Carnivores only eat meat, or other animals. Some secondary consumers are large predators, but even the smaller ones often eat herbivores bigger than they are in order to get enough energy.

questions.Question: Some of the conifers in our northern areas include
questions.solution: Solution:		Some of the conifers in our northern areas include Pines, Abies and Cedrus.

questions.Question: Which of these plants grow in an environment that is neither very wet nor very dry?
questions.solution: Solution:		Mesophytes are terrestrial plants which are adapted to neither a particularly dry nor particularly wet environment. An example of a mesophytic habitat would be a rural temperate meadow, which might contain goldenrod, clover, daisy, and Rosa multiflora.

questions.Question: Which statement describes decomposers?
questions.optionA: Decomposers are insignificant organisms in the ecosystem and can be absent in some ecosystems
questions.optionB: Decomposers can produce their own source of energy and can sometimes act as primary producers
questions.optionC: Decomposers are those organisms that recycle matter in the ecosystem
questions.solution: Solution:		Decomposers are organisms that break down dead or decaying organisms, and in doing so, they carry out the natural process of decomposition.

questions.Question: Which of the following blood cells carry oxygen?
questions.solution: Solution:		The main job of red blood cells, or erythrocytes, is to carry oxygen from the lungs to the body tissues and carbon dioxide as a waste product, away from the tissues and back to the lungs. Hemoglobin (Hgb) is an important protein in the red blood cells that carries oxygen from the lungs to all parts of our body.

questions.Question: In human body lymphocytes are formed in
questions.solution: Solution:		Lymphocytes develop in the thymus and bone marrow (yellow), which are therefore called central (or primary) lymphoid organs.

questions.Question: Which statement about capillaries is correct?
questions.optionA: Their walls are covered with cilia
questions.optionB: They warm and humidify inhaled air
questions.optionC: Their walls are only one cell thick
questions.optionD: They move mucus through the lungs
questions.solution: Solution:		Capillaries are tiny blood vessels connecting arteries to veins. These blood vessels carry oxygen and nutrients to individual cells. Capillaries are the smallest blood vessels in the body, and have walls only one or two cells thick.

questions.Question: The grouping of blood is based on substances called
questions.solution: Solution:		The red blood corpusclesor erythrocytes usually carry antigens and there are two types of antigens. The A group persons have antigen A in their red corpuscles and the B group have antigen B in their red corpuscles. The AB group person have both antigen A and antigen B in their erythrocytes. The 'O' group persons have no antigens in their red corpuscles.

questions.Question: Which blood group is universal acceptor?
questions.solution: Solution:		AB+ is universal acceptor.

questions.Question: Total number of bones found in child
questions.solution: Solution:		An adult has 206 bones, but a newborn baby has nearly 300 bones in her body.

questions.Question: A typical human ribcage consists of how many ribs ?
questions.solution: Solution:		A typical human ribcage consists of 12 ribs.

questions.Question: The total number of bones found in newly born human body ?
questions.solution: Solution:		A baby's body has about 300 bones at birth.

questions.Question: Which of the following bone is not found in human leg?
questions.solution: Solution:		The humerus is the long bone in the upper arm. It is located between the elbow joint and the shoulder. So, the correct option is C.

questions.Question: Which cell can contract and relax?
questions.solution: Solution:		Muscle Tissue: A collection of muscle fibers that can contract and relax to move body parts. Examples include cardiac (heart) muscle, skeletal muscle (in limbs, trunk, jaw and face) and smooth muscle (in digestive tract, eyes, blood vessels and ducts).

questions.Question: Which one of the following functions is not carried out by smooth endoplasmic reticulum?
questions.solution: Solution:		Smooth Endoplasmic Reticulumdoes not contain ribosomes on its surface for which it is regarded as smooth. So, proteins cannotbe synthesised by SER provided protein synthesis is the primary task of ribosomes.

questions.Question: Which is called the factory of ribosomes?
questions.solution: Solution:		Nucleous is called the factory of ribosomes.

questions.Question: In what organelle does cellular respiration take place?
questions.solution: Solution:		The enzymatic reactions of cellular respiration begin in the cytoplasm, but most of the reactions occur in the mitochondria. Cellular respiration occurs in the double-membrane organelle called the mitochondrion. The folds in the inner membrane are called cristae.

questions.Question: Chromosomes are present
questions.solution: Solution:		Chromosomes are thread-like structures located inside the nucleus of animal and plant cells. Each chromosome is made of protein and a single molecule of deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA). Passed from parents to offspring, DNA contains the specific instructions that make each type of living creature unique.

questions.Question: In which organelle does cellular respiration occur?
questions.solution: Solution:		The enzymatic reactions of cellular respiration begin in the cytoplasm, but most of the reactions occur in the mitochondria. Cellular respiration occurs in the double-membrane organelle called the mitochondrion. The folds in the inner membrane are called cristae.

questions.Question: In ________ cells the genetic material is without any nuclear membrane covering and is directly submerged in the cytoplasm.
questions.solution: Solution:		In bacteria cells the genetic material is without any nuclear membrane covering and is directly submerged in the cytoplasm.

questions.Question: Cyanobacteria are also known as
questions.solution: Solution:		Cyanobacteria, also known as blue-green bacteria, blue-green algae, and Cyanophyta, is a phylum of bacteria that obtain their energy through photosynthesis.

questions.Question: Branch of biology which deals with the study processing and preservation of food is called
questions.solution: Solution:		Branch of biology which deals with the study processing and preservation of food is called Food technology.

questions.Question: A viral species is a group of viruses that has
questions.solution: Solution:		A viral species is a group of viruses that has same ecological niche and same genetic information.

questions.Question: The litmus paper utilized in the chemical laboratories is made of :
questions.solution: Solution:		Litmus paper is an acid/base indicator that changes color to identify bases and acids. Litmus is a dye made from naturally occurring substances, including lichens (fungi)– the most commonly used of which is the species roccella tinctoria.

questions.Question: Bacteria are classified in the kingdom
questions.solution: Solution:		Bacteria are classified in the kingdom Monera.

questions.Question: Which of the following animals shows radial symmetry?
questions.solution: Solution:		Star Fish shows radial symmetry.

questions.Question: Who introduced the "binomial nomenclature" to name organisms?
questions.solution: Solution:		Tyrannosaurus rex is probably the most widely known binomial. The formal introduction of this system of naming species is credited to Carl Linnaeus, effectively beginning with his work Species Plantarum in 1753.

questions.Question: Aestivation is seen in
questions.solution: Solution:		Aestivation occurs in animals living in deserts and tropical regions. This is done to protect themselves from hot and dry climate, and due to the scarcity of food water. This can be seen in earthworms, molluscs, arthropods, reptiles and amphibians. A lungfish can aestivate and survive without water for three years.

questions.Question: Which one is the largest animal phylum?
questions.solution: Solution:		Arthropod, (phylum Arthropoda), any member of the phylum Arthropoda, the largest phylum in the animal kingdom, which includes such familiar forms as lobsters, crabs, spiders, mites, insects, centipedes, and millipedes. About 84 percent of all known species of animals are members of this phylum.

questions.Question: In a cell process of respiration takes place in
questions.solution: Solution:		Cellular respiration occurs in the double-membrane organelle called the mitochondrion.

questions.Question: It is the basic structure found in all membranes such as those of mitochondria and chloroplasts.
questions.solution: Solution:		Unit membrane is the basic structure found in all membranes such as those of mitochondria and chloroplasts.

questions.Question: Which one is found in a pair in each chromosome?
questions.solution: Solution:		Chromatids is found in a pair in each chromosome.

questions.Question: Ribosomes are produced in
questions.solution: Solution:		In bacterial cells, ribosomes are synthesized in the cytoplasm through the transcription of multiple ribosome gene operons. In eukaryotes, the process takes place both in the cell cytoplasm and in the nucleolus, which is a region within the cell nucleus.

questions.Question: Which cell feature is responsible for storing water ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Vacuole is responsible for storing water.

questions.Question: The bone humerus is found in
questions.solution: Solution:		The humerus is a long bone of the upper limb, which extends from the shoulder to the elbow.

questions.Question: The bone tibia is found in
questions.solution: Solution:		The tibia (shin bone) is a long bone of the leg, found medial to the fibula. It is also the the weight bearing bone of the leg, which is why it is the second largest bone in the body after the femur.

questions.Question: Longest bone found in which part of human body?
questions.solution: Solution:		The femur is one of the most researched bones in the human anatomy and forensic medicine. As the longest bone in the human body, it is well preserved in skeletal remains.

questions.Question: Which one is the longest bone in human body?
questions.solution: Solution:		The femur is one of the most researched bones in the human anatomy and forensic medicine. As the longest bone in the human body, it is well preserved in skeletal remains.

questions.Question: Number of ribs found in a typical human ribcage is
questions.solution: Solution:		The ribs are a set of twelve paired bones which form the protective 'cage' of the thorax. They articulate with the vertebral column posteriorly, and terminate anteriorly as cartilage (known as costal cartilage). Number of ribs found in a typical human ribcage is 24.

questions.Question: In Pedology we study about
questions.solution: Solution:		Pedology is defined as the science that studies the genesis, nature, distribution and use potentiality of soil resources.

questions.Question: Biological control is to check growth of
questions.solution: Solution:		Biological control is to check growth of one pest by another.

questions.Question: The biofertilizer used or the paddy crops is
questions.solution: Solution:		The bio-fertilizers used for rice crop are Azospirillum, Phosphobacteria, Blue green algae azolla and Mycorhiza.

questions.Question: Which of the following plants have root nodules?
questions.solution: Solution:		Leguminous plants have root nodules.

questions.Question: Branch of agriculture concerned with the production of crops is
questions.solution: Solution:		Agronomy is the branch of agriculture concerned with the production of crops.

questions.Question: Which lobe of human brain is associated with hearing?
questions.solution: Solution:		The temporal lobe contains the primary auditory cortex, which receives auditory information from the ears and secondary areas, and processes the information so we understand what we're hearing (e.g. words, laughing, a baby crying).

questions.Question: Which of the following organs do not have blood vessels?
questions.solution: Solution:		Cornea do not have blood vessels.

questions.Question: Receptors for hearing are located in the
questions.solution: Solution:		The cochlea contains the spiral organ of Corti, which is the receptor organ for hearing.

questions.Question: Image of object is formed on which part of eye?
questions.solution: Solution:		An image is formed on the retina with light rays converging most at the cornea and upon entering and exiting the lens. Rays from the top and bottom of the object are traced and produce an inverted real image on the retina.

questions.Question: A colour blind person has difficulty in distinguishing which of the two colours?
questions.solution: Solution:		A colour blind person has difficulty in distinguishing green & red colours.

questions.Question: Enzyme secreted by stomach digests the food but stomach is not digested by this digestive juice because
questions.optionA: Wall of stomach is lined with mucus
questions.optionB: This is made up of hard cells
questions.optionC: It is made up of steel
questions.solution: Solution:		The stomach does not digest itself because it is lined with epithial cells, which produce mucus. This forms a barrier between the lining of the stomach and the contents. Enzymes, which make up part of the digestive juices are also secreted by the stomach wall, from glands with no mucus barrier.

questions.Question: Where does most digestion take place?
questions.solution: Solution:		The majority of chemical digestion occurs in the small intestine. Digested chyme from the stomach passes through the pylorus and into the duodenum.

questions.Question: Both food and air travel through the
questions.solution: Solution:		Air, food and liquid all pass through this common passage, the oropharynx. The two passages separate again here, in the hypopharynx. Food and liquid pass backward into the esophagus on their way to the stomach. Air passes forward through the larynx and into the trachea, on its way to the lungs.

questions.Question: The enzyme which take part in digestion of milk protein is
questions.solution: Solution:		The enzyme which take part in digestion of milk protein is rennin.

questions.Question: Which one of the following is an enzyme ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Trypsin is an enzyme.

questions.Question: Psidium guajava is the scientific name of ________ .
questions.solution: Solution:		Psidium guajava, the common guava, yellow guava, or lemon guava, is an evergreen shrub or small tree native to the Caribbean, Central America and South America.

questions.Question: Grevillea Robusta is the scientific name of ________ .
questions.solution: Solution:		Grevillea robusta, commonly known as the southern silky oak, silk oak or silky oak, silver oak or Australian silver oak, is a flowering plant in the family Proteaceae. It is a tree, the largest species in its genus but is not closely related to the true oaks, Quercus.

questions.Question: Artocarpus integra is the scientific name of ________ .
questions.solution: Solution:		Artocarpus integra is the scientific name of jack fruit.

questions.Question: Which of the following is a fish?
questions.solution: Solution:		The characteristic features of fishes are aquatic, streamlined body with scales, 2-chambered heart and gills. Bombay duck, salmon and Hippocampus exhibit these features thus they belong to the class Pieces. Bombay duck or bummalo is a 'lizardfish'. It is native to the water between Mumbai and Kutch in the Arabian sea and a small numbers are also found in the Bay of Bengal. Salmon is the common name for several species of fishes.

questions.Question: What is scientific name of "Cotton" ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Gossypium Herbaceum is scientific name of "Cotton".

questions.Question: Increased RBC's in the blood leads to a condition called
questions.solution: Solution:		Polycythemia is a condition that results in an increased level of circulating red blood cells in the bloodstream.

questions.Question: Platelet is also known as
questions.solution: Solution:		Platelets, also known as thrombocytes, are blood cells. They form in your bone marrow, a sponge-like tissue in your bones. Platelets play a major role in blood clotting.

questions.Question: Antibodies are produced by
questions.solution: Solution:		Antibodies are produced by plasma cells.

questions.Question: Oxygenated blood is carried from the lungs to the ________ by the pulmonary veins.
questions.solution: Solution:		Oxygenated blood is carried from the lungs to the left auricle by the pulmonary veins.

questions.Question: Which one is the largest cells in white blood corpuscles?
questions.solution: Solution:		Monocyte is the largest cells in white blood corpuscles.

questions.Question: The food material prepared in the plants is transported to the various organs by which of the following?
questions.solution: Solution:		The food which is prepared by the process of photosynthesis in the leaves of a plant has to be transported to other parts like stem, roots, branches etc. Phloem transports this food material.

questions.Question: Cells with similar markers stick together and function as
questions.solution: Solution:		A tissue is an ensemble of similar cells and their extracellular matrix from the same origin that together carry out a specific function. Hence, Cells with similar markers stick together and function as tissues.

questions.Question: Xylem tissue is mainly concerned with the
questions.optionB: Transport of water and mineral nutrients in plants
questions.optionC: Storage of prepared foods in plants
questions.solution: Solution:		The basic function of xylem is to transport water from roots to stems and leaves, but it also transports nutrients.

questions.Question: The major constituent of connective tissue is
questions.solution: Solution:		Unlike the other tissue types (epithelium, muscle, and nerve), which consist mainly of cells, the major constituent of connective tissue is the extracellular matrix (ECM). Extracellular matrices consist of different combinations of protein fibers (collagen and elastic fibers) and ground substance.

questions.Question: The connective tissue that connects a muscle to a bone is
questions.solution: Solution:		A tendon is a fibrous connective tissue which attaches muscle to bone. Tendons may also attach muscles to structures such as the eyeball.

questions.Question: Lederberg and Tatum demonstrated conjugation in the bacteria in
questions.solution: Solution:		Bacterial conjugation was first described by Lederberg and Tatum in 1946 as a phenomenon involving the exchange of markers between closely related strains of Escherichia coli.

questions.Question: The individual chain of cells or filament in the colony of Nostoc is known as
questions.solution: Solution:		If you look at Nostoc structure under a microscope, you will see thread-like filaments, called trichomes. Each trichome is really a chain of round or bead-like cells that lack a nucleus.

questions.Question: Under the ideal environmental conditions bacterial cells divide at the rate of division per twenty
questions.solution: Solution:		Bacteria do not grow and multiply the same way as animals or humans. They take in nutrients and reproduce by dividing – one bacteria splits and becomes two bacteria, two become four, four become eight and so on. Under ideal conditions, many types of bacteria can double every 20 minutes.

questions.Question: The virus is
questions.solution: Solution:		The virus is nucleic acid and protein.

questions.Question: Which of these is a human disease caused by bacteria?
questions.solution: Solution:		Infectious diseases can be caused by: Bacteria. These one-cell organisms are responsible for illnesses such as strep throat, urinary tract infections and tuberculosis.

questions.Question: Organic Substances which, in very small amounts, control growth and development called
questions.solution: Solution:		Organic Substances which, in very small amounts, control growth and development called hormones.

questions.Question: Our major foods, fibres, spices, fruits and beverage crops are
questions.solution: Solution:		Our major foods, fibres, spices, fruits and beverage crops are flowering plants.

questions.Question: Movements due to light are shown by
questions.solution: Solution:		Flowering plants show the movement due to light.

questions.Question: Outer covering of virus made up of protein is
questions.solution: Solution:		A capsid is the protein shell of a virus, enclosing its genetic material. The proteins making up the capsid are called capsid proteins or viral coat proteins (VCP).

questions.Question: Radish is a
questions.solution: Solution:		Radish is a modified root.

questions.Question: When more than 20% of the body weight is due to fat, the person is suffering from
questions.solution: Solution:		Obesity - when body fat exceeds 30% of total weight.

questions.Question: Bone deformities occur due to the excess intake of
questions.solution: Solution:		When there is an excessive intake of fluorine in the diet, the person suffers from many dental and bone-related deformities.The long bones are affected which results in breaking and fractures in the bones.There is a reduction in bone density and elasticity which results in osteosclerosis.There are problems with dental fluorosis in cases of children during the growth of the teeth in case of a high intake of fluorine. Thus, the correct answer is option D.

questions.Question: Cellulose is a
questions.solution: Solution:		Cellulose is a carbohydrate formed by a linear polymerisation of β-D-glucose units, which in contrast to starch, is oriented with − CH2OH groups, alternating above and below the plane of the cellulose molecule, thus producing long, unbranched chains.

questions.Question: Deficiency of 'Thiamine' causes
questions.solution: Solution:		Thiamine deficiency, or beriberi, refers to the lack of thiamine.

questions.Question: Kwashiorkor disease in children is caused by
questions.optionA: Sufficient carbohydrates but less fats in diet
questions.optionB: Sufficient carbohydrates and fats but deficient proteins in diet
questions.optionC: Sufficient vitamins but deficient fats in diet
questions.optionD: Sufficient fats but deficient vitamins in diet
questions.solution: Solution:		Kwashiorkor is caused by a lack of protein in the diet. Every cell in your body contains protein. You need protein in your diet for your body to repair cells and make new cells.

questions.Question: A man whose blood group is not known meet with a serious accident and needs blood transfusion immediately. Which one of the blood group mentioned below and readily available in the hospital will be safe for transfusion?
questions.solution: Solution:		Donors with blood group O, Rh- can donate to recipients with blood types A, B, AB and O (O is the universal donor), because it does not have any antigen, thereby no reaction would occur with the antibody, which may be present in donor's body. Hence, option A is correct.

questions.Question: Which letter indicates systolic pressure?
questions.solution: Solution:		Letter A indicates systolic pressure.

questions.Question: The first heart transplantation was performed by
questions.solution: Solution:		Christiaan Barnard with his team, performed the world's first human-to-human heart transplant operation on 3 December 1967.

questions.Question: Which of the following is true about blood plasma?
questions.optionA: The main protein component is hemoglobin
questions.optionB: It is a faint yellow fluid
questions.optionC: It is the same as serum but without the clotting proteins
questions.solution: Solution:		The first option is incorrect because it is devoid of blood cell, also red blood cells so doesn’t contains haemoglobin.The second option is incorrect because plasma is colorless.The third option is also incorrect because plasma contains the clotting factors.

questions.Question: Most of the oxygen transported by the blood is
questions.optionD: In ionic form as solute in plasma
questions.solution: Solution:		Oxygen is carried in the blood in two forms: (1) dissolved in plasma and RBC water (about 2% of the total) and (2) reversibly bound to hemoglobin (about 98% of the total).

questions.Question: Number of which type of WBC is greatest in blood of human?
questions.solution: Solution:		Neutrophils are the most abundant white blood cell, constituting 60-70% of the circulating leukocytes, and including two functionally unequal subpopulations: neutrophil-killers and neutrophil-cagers. They defend against bacterial or fungal infection.

questions.Question: Blood is
questions.solution: Solution:		Blood is alkaline.

questions.Question: Blood pressure is measured with
questions.solution: Solution:		Blood pressure is measured with Sphygmomanometer.

questions.Question: Which of the following is true about veins?
questions.optionA: Veins carry blood away from the heart, while arteries carry blood to the heart
questions.optionB: Veins are more muscular than arteries
questions.optionC: Veins have valves; arteries do not
questions.optionD: Veins have a smaller diameter lumen than arteries
questions.solution: Solution:		Veins are blood vessels that carry blood toward the heart. Most veins carry deoxygenated blood from the tissues back to the heart; exceptions are the pulmonary and umbilical veins, both of which carry oxygenated blood to the heart. In contrast to veins, arteries carry blood away from the heart. Veins are less muscular than arteries and are often closer to the skin. There are valves in most veins to prevent backflow.

questions.Question: Which of the following serve as antibodies?
questions.solution: Solution:		Proteins serve as antibodies.

questions.Question: One day you wake with a sore throat and a runny nose. Your doctor takes a swab from your throat, sends it to a lab, and telephones you the next day to say that antibiotic will not help you get better. Which of the following is the most likely reason for the doctor's statement?
questions.optionA: Having waited a day, it is too late to take an antibiotic
questions.optionB: You need an antiseptic, not an antibiotic
questions.optionC: You need to be vaccinated instead of taking an antibiotic
questions.optionD: You are infected by a virus
questions.solution: Solution:		The most likely reason for the doctor's statement is that the person is infected by a virus.

questions.Question: Plants that grow under average temperature and moisture are called:
questions.solution: Solution:		Plants that grow under average temperature and moisture are called mesophytes.

questions.Question: Oxyreductases, transferases, hydrolases, lyases, isomerases and ligases are all classes of
questions.solution: Solution:		Oxyreductases, transferases, hydrolases, lyases, isomerases and ligases are all classes of enzymes.

questions.Question: Mutation is
questions.optionA: a factor responsible for plant growth
questions.optionB: a change which affects the offspring of F2 generation only
questions.optionD: a change which affects the parents
questions.solution: Solution:		A mutation is a change in a DNA sequence. Mutations can result from DNA copying mistakes made during cell division, exposure to ionizing radiation, exposure to chemicals called mutagens, or infection by viruses.

questions.Question: Pollination by wind is called
questions.solution: Solution:		Anemophily is the process when pollen is transported by air currents from one individual plant to another. About 12% of the world's flowering plants are wind-pollinated, including grasses and cereal crops, many trees, and the infamous allergenic ragweeds.

questions.Question: Pressure, pain, and temperature receptors in the skin are
questions.solution: Solution:		Pressure, pain, and temperature receptors in the skin are exteroceptors.

questions.Question: Goosebumps are caused by contractions of the
questions.solution: Solution:		Goosebumps are caused by the contraction of the tiny arrectores pilorum muscles attached to hair follicles, according to Dr. Allan L. Lorincz, a dermatologist at the University of Chicago.

questions.Question: Lacrymal glands are situated in the
questions.solution: Solution:		Lacrymal glands are situated in the buccal cavity.

questions.Question: Which of the following acts as an insulator against heat, cold and as a shock-absorber in the body?
questions.solution: Solution:		Subcutaneous fat layer acts as an insulator against heat, cold and as a shock-absorber in the body.

questions.Question: A/An ________ tissue is formed beneath the skin and between internal organs.
questions.solution: Solution:		A adipose tissue is formed beneath the skin and between internal organs.

questions.Question: During which phase or phase of cell division, the morphology of the chromosomes is best studied?
questions.solution: Solution:		Chromosomal morphology is best observed at metaphase. Metaphase is a stage of mitosis in the cell cycle in which chromosomes are at their most condensed and coiled stage.

questions.Question: Metaphase is followed by the next phase of mitosis called
questions.solution: Solution:		These phases occur in strict sequential order, and cytokinesis - the process of dividing the cell contents to make two new cells - starts in anaphase or telophase. Stages of mitosis: prophase, metaphase, anaphase, telophase. Cytokinesis typically overlaps with anaphase and/or telophase.

questions.Question: It is a process which converts a single-celled zygote into a great number of cells, which then differentiate into tissues.
questions.solution: Solution:		Mitosis is a process which converts a single-celled zygote into a great number of cells, which then differentiate into tissues.

questions.Question: Which division is responsible for the continuity of hereditary information?
questions.solution: Solution:		The purpose of mitosis is to maintain continuity among cell progeny, meaning that if a tissue is made of thousands of cells that resulted from many mitosis events, each cell has the same number of genes as the original cell.

questions.Question: The type of division which occurs in somatic cells is known as
questions.solution: Solution:		Most of the time when people refer to “cell division,” they mean mitosis, the process of making new body cells and it occurs in all somatic cells. Meiosis is the type of cell division that creates egg and sperm cells i.e. Germ cells which are helpful in sexual reproduction.

questions.Question: Which one of the following hormones is essential for the uptake of glucose by cells in the human body?
questions.solution: Solution:		Insulin is an essential hormone produced by the pancreas. Its main role is to control glucose levels in our bodies.

questions.Question: Goitre is caused by the deficiency of ________
questions.solution: Solution:		Iodine deficiency is the main cause of goitre. Iodine is essential to helping your thyroid produce thyroid hormones.

questions.Question: Endocrine glands are also known as
questions.solution: Solution:		Endocrine glands are also known as the ductless glands because of the fact that their secretions are released directly into the blood, not to any tubes or ducts.

questions.Question: Enzymes are produced by
questions.solution: Solution:		Enzymes are produced naturally in the body. For example, enzymes are required for proper digestive system function. Digestive enzymes are mostly produced in the pancreas, stomach, and small intestine.

questions.Question: Which one of following is a ductless gland?
questions.solution: Solution:		Endocrine glands are ductless glands of the endocrine system that secrete their products, hormones, directly into the blood.

questions.Question: Slow oxidative muscle fibers are best suited for
questions.solution: Solution:		Slow oxidative muscle fibers are best suited for running a marathon.

questions.Question: In which body cavities are the lungs located
questions.solution: Solution:		The lungs are located in thoracic cavity.

questions.Question: The molecule that is the main source of ATP synthesis
questions.solution: Solution:		In general, the main energy source for cellular metabolism is glucose, which is catabolized in the three subsequent processes—glycolysis, tricarboxylic acid cycle (TCA or Krebs cycle), and finally oxidative phosphorylation—to produce ATP.

questions.Question: Lungs are covered by
questions.solution: Solution:		The lungs are surrounded by two membranes, the pleurae. The outer pleura is attached to the chest wall and is known as the parietal pleura; the inner one is attached to the lung and other visceral tissues and is known as the visceral pleura. So, the correct answer is option C.

questions.Question: Accumulation of which one of the following leads to cramp?
questions.solution: Solution:		The accumulation of lactic acid is the main reason for the formation of cramps in sprinters.

questions.Question: The Mode of nutrition in which particulate food is devoured is
questions.solution: Solution:		The feeding mechanism is of several types. If it is entirely plant-like (photosynthesis),it is called holophytic. It is entirely (holo) animal-like (zoic), that is devouring already existing food, it is called holozoic.

questions.Question: They are organic compounds consisting of carbon, hydrogen and oxygen present in all living organisms.
questions.solution: Solution:		Carbohydrates are organic molecules that consist of carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen. They are made up of repeating units called saccharides. They provide cells with energy, store energy, and form structural tissues.

questions.Question: The energy released by 1 gram of glucose is
questions.solution: Solution:		The energy released by 1 gram of glucose is 4 kcal.

questions.Question: Among the given nutrients, milk is a poor source of
questions.solution: Solution:		Among the given nutrients, milk is a poor source of Vitamin C.

questions.Question: Which nutrient forms most of our body weight?
questions.solution: Solution:		Water is a nutrient that makes up 60% of our body weight.

questions.Question: Source of infection in diseases like Tuberculosis, Mumps and Whooping cough is
questions.solution: Solution:		Tuberculosis, mumps and whooping cough are the contagious types of diseases. The diseases can spread through the droplets or the aerosols which are formed during coughing or sneezing. These aerosols contain the bacterium. The bacterium may enter the other person's body who is healthy and cause infection.

questions.Question: Anopheles mosquito carries Plasmodium which causes malaria in
questions.solution: Solution:		Anopheles mosquito carries Plasmodium which causes malaria in humans.

questions.Question: Anopheles mosquito carries Plasmodium which causes malaria in
questions.solution: No explanation is given for this questionLet's Discuss on Board

questions.Question: Which is called as triple vaccine?
questions.solution: Solution:		Diphtheria is readily preventable by vaccine administration. This is included in the triple vaccine: diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis vaccine (DTP) or the quintuple diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis, polio and Hib vaccine.

questions.Question: Which of the following is an Abiotic factor?
questions.solution: Solution:		Abiotic factors are the non-living parts of the environment that can often have a major influence on living organisms. Abiotic factors include water, sunlight, oxygen, soil and temperature.

questions.Question: Every ecosystem must have
questions.solution: Solution:		Every ecosystem must have Autotrophs.

questions.Question: Silviculture is the branch of botany in which we study about
questions.solution: Solution:		Silviculture is the branch of botany in which we study about the development of forest.

questions.Question: Which of the following is an Autotroph?
questions.solution: Solution:		An autotroph is an organism that can produce its own food using light, water, carbon dioxide, or other chemicals. Algae is an autotroph.

questions.Question: The energy in most ecosystems comes from
questions.solution: Solution:		The vast majority of energy in food webs originates from the sun. Energy is not recycled in ecosystems and each ecosystem requires a continuous input of energy to sustain it. There is some energy transformed at each level of the food chain or food web in an ecosystem.

questions.Question: Study of typical behaviour of organisms in their natural habitat is called
questions.solution: Solution:		Ethology is a field of basic biology, like ecology or genetics. It focuses on the behaviors of diverse organisms in their natural environment. Comparative psychology is an extension of work done in human psychology.

questions.Question: Primary phloem develops from
questions.solution: Solution:		Primary phloem develops from provascular tissue.

questions.Question: Other than spreading malaria, anopheles mosquitoes are also vectors of
questions.solution: Solution:		Other than spreading malaria, anopheles mosquitoes are also vectors of filariasis.

questions.Question: Plants that grow in saline water are called
questions.solution: Solution:		A halophyte is a salt-tolerant plant that grows in soil or waters of high salinity, coming into contact with saline water through its roots or by salt spray, such as in saline semi-deserts, mangrove swamps, marshes and sloughs and seashores.

questions.Question: Pyorrhoea is a disease of the
questions.solution: Solution:		Pyorrhoea, or periodontal disease, to give it a proper medical term, is a disease of the gums, it is one of the most widely prevalent diseases. It affects the membrane surrounding the roots of the teeth and leads to loosening of the teeth, pus formation, and shrinkage of the gum. This disease is the primary cause for tooth loss among adults.

questions.Question: O2 released in the process of photosynthesis comes from
questions.solution: Solution:		Photosynthesis is the process by which plants use the energy of light to produce carbohydrates and molecular oxygen (O2) from carbon dioxide (CO2) and water.

questions.Question: Night Blindness is caused by deficiency of which of the following Vitamin?
questions.solution: Solution:		Vitamin A deficiency can result from inadequate intake, fat malabsorption, or liver disorders. Deficiency impairs immunity and hematopoiesis and causes rashes and typical ocular effects (eg, xerophthalmia, night blindness).

questions.Question: Organisms that feed on the excreta of other organisms are called
questions.solution: Solution:		Coprophagia or coprophagy is the consumption of faeces. Coprophagy refers to all kinds of faeces eating including eating faeces of other species (heterospecific), of other individuals (allocoprophagy), or its own (autocoprophagy), those once deposited or taken directly from the anus. So, the correct answer is 'Coprophagus'

questions.Question: Which of the following vitamin helps in clotting of blood?
questions.solution: Solution:		Vitamin K is a nutrient that the body needs to stay healthy. It's important for blood clotting and healthy bones and also has other functions in the body.

questions.Question: Anaemia is due to deficiency of
questions.solution: Solution:		Iron deficiency anaemia is a common type of anaemia a condition in which blood lacks adequate healthy red blood cells.

questions.Question: In what chief capacity does vitamin k function?
questions.solution: Solution:		Health benefits and sources of vitamin K. Vitamin K refers to a group of fat-soluble vitamins that play a role in blood clotting, bone metabolism, and regulating blood calcium levels. The body needs vitamin K to produce prothrombin, a protein and clotting factor that is important in blood clotting and bone metabolism.

questions.Question: Which of the following micro-organism causes diseases like polio and chicken pox?
questions.solution: Solution:		Serious diseases like polio and chicken pox are caused by viruses.

questions.Question: What kingdom does Amoeba belong to
questions.solution: Solution:		Amoeba belongs to kingdom protista.

questions.Question: Which bacteria cause the greatest harm in the food industry?
questions.solution: Solution:		Pathogenic bacteria cause the greatest harm in the food industry.

questions.Question: Bacteria divides by
questions.solution: Solution:		Bacteria reproduce by binary fission. In this process the bacterium, which is a single cell, divides into two identical daughter cells. Binary fission begins when the DNA of the bacterium divides into two (replicates).

questions.Question: Important plant diseases like fire-blight and crown all are caused by
questions.solution: Solution:		Important plant diseases like fire-blight and crown all are caused by bacteria.

questions.Question: In human the thickest skin is present in
questions.solution: Solution:		Epidermis varies in thickness throughout the body depending mainly on frictional forces and is thickest on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet, and thinnest in the face (eyelids) and genitalia.

questions.Question: They form the material which forms skins, muscles, hair and nails in animals.
questions.solution: Solution:		Keratinocytes make keratin, a type of protein that's a basic component of hair, skin, and nails. Keratin in the skin's outer layer helps create a protective barrier.

questions.Question: Which of the following is responsible for giving colour to human skin?
questions.solution: Solution:		The actual skin color of different humans is affected by many substances, although the single most important substance is the pigment melanin. Melanin is produced within the skin in cells called melanocytes and it is the main determinant of the skin color of darker-skin humans.

questions.Question: Which is the largest organ in the human body?
questions.solution: Solution:		Body organs aren't all internal like the brain or the heart. There's one we wear on the outside. Skin is our largest organ—adults carry some 8 pounds (3.6 kilograms) and 22 square feet (2 square meters) of it.

questions.Question: Branch of science which deals with the study of skin of man is called
questions.solution: Solution:		Dermatology is the branch of science which deals with the study of skin.

questions.Question: Deficiency of which of the following causes non-clotting of blood?
questions.solution: Solution:		Deficiency of vitamin K causes non-clotting of blood.

questions.Question: Organisms need nutrients in order to
questions.solution: Solution:		They are necessary to the lives of people, plants, animals, and all other organisms. Nutrients help break down food to give organisms energy. They are used in every process of an organism's body. Some of the processes are growth (building cells), repair (healing a wound), and maintaining life (breathing).

questions.Question: Sugar is a component of which of the following?
questions.solution: Solution:		Sugar is a component of carbohydrates.

questions.Question: The main protein found in milk is ________
questions.solution: Solution:		Casein and whey protein are the major proteins of milk.

questions.Question: Which one of the following vitamins is known as the anti sterile factor?
questions.solution: Solution:		Riboflavin is known as the anti sterile factor.

questions.Question: Infection of salivary glands by a virus leads to
questions.solution: Solution:		In general, viral infections of the salivary gland may result in reduced saliva production and/or swelling. Mumps is the most common salivary gland infection caused by paramyxovirus.

questions.Question: Which virus causes Chicken Pox?
questions.solution: Solution:		Varicella-zoster is a herpes virus that causes chickenpox, a common childhood illness. It is highly contagious. If an adult develops chickenpox, the illness may be more severe. After a person has had chickenpox, the varicella-zoster virus can remain inactive in the body for many years.

questions.Question: Besides Dog, which one is the other animal that can also cause rabies
questions.solution: Solution:		Any mammal can get rabies. The most common wild reservoirs of rabies are raccoons, skunks, bats, and foxes. Domestic mammals can also get rabies. Cats, cattle, and dogs are the most frequently reported rabid domestic animals in the United States.

questions.Question: Theilreia parva causes infection in
questions.solution: Solution:		Theilreia parva causes infection in buffalo.

questions.Question: The interferons are
questions.solution: Solution:		Interferons (IFNs) are proteins made and released by host cells in response to the presence of pathogens such as viruses, bacteria, parasites, or tumor cells.

questions.Question: In man there are how many pairs of homologous chromosomes?
questions.solution: Solution:		In humans, each cell normally contains 23 pairs of chromosomes, for a total of 46.

questions.Question: It is composed of two polynucleotide chains which are coiled around each other in the form of a double helix.
questions.solution: Solution:		DNA) is a molecule composed of two polynucleotide chains that coil around each other to form a double helix carrying genetic instructions for the development, functioning, growth and reproduction of all known organisms and many viruses. DNA and ribonucleic acid (RNA) are nucleic acids.

questions.Question: How many chromosomes are in a human gamete?
questions.solution: Solution:		In humans, each cell normally contains 23 pairs of chromosomes, for a total of 46.

questions.Question: What is the unit of heredity?
questions.solution: Solution:		A gene is the basic physical and functional unit of heredity. Genes are made up of DNA.

questions.Question: Who discovered genetic material?
questions.solution: Solution:		In the 1920s, Frederick Griffith made an important discovery. He was studying two different strains of a bacterium, called R (rough) strain and S (smooth) strain.

questions.Question: Which Vitamin is obtained from Sun rays?
questions.solution: Solution:		Vitamin D is the sunshine vitamin that has been produced on this earth for more than 500 million years. During exposure to sunlight 7-dehydrocholesterol in the skin absorbs UV B radiation and is converted to previtamin D3 which in turn isomerizes into vitamin D3.

questions.Question: The Vitamin required for the synthesis of nucleic acid is
questions.solution: Solution:		According to Stokes, folic acid may function in an enzyme system responsible for the synthesis of thymine, which in turn is used for forming nucleic acids.

questions.Question: Which of the following statements is not true about metabolism?
questions.optionA: Younger people generally have a slower metabolism than adults
questions.optionB: Basal metabolism is the amount of energy needed for sustaining life
questions.optionC: Basal metabolism is measured by the amount of calories burned when your body is inactive
questions.optionD: Metabolism is influenced by numerous factors, such as heredity and age
questions.solution: Solution:		Metabolism is the set of life-sustaining chemical transformations within the cells of organisms. The three main purposes of metabolism are the conversion of food/fuel to energy to run cellular processes, the conversion of food/fuel to building blocks for proteins, lipids, nucleic acids, and some carbohydrates, and the elimination of nitrogenous wastes. Younger people have faster metabolism than adults. Hence, the given statement 'Younger people generally have a slower metabolism than adults' is false.

questions.Question: An important function of fat in the body is to
questions.solution: Solution:		The body uses fat as a fuel source, and fat is the major storage form of energy in the body. Fat also has many other important functions in the body, and a moderate amount is needed in the diet for good health.

questions.Question: Vitamin K is required for
questions.solution: Solution:		Vitamin K is required for blood clotting.

questions.Question: Which of the following is an example of parasitism?
questions.optionA: Leeches consume blood of their host
questions.optionC: Aphid insects eat the sap of the host plant
questions.solution: Solution:		All of the above are examples of parasitism.

questions.Question: ________ is the interaction in which one species benefits and the other is neither harmed nor benefited.
questions.solution: Solution:		Commensalism is an interaction in which one individual benefits while the other is neither helped nor harmed.

questions.Question: Consider the following statements1. Different plant species grow together2. Light cannot penetrate into the lower strata full of undergrowth Which of the following type of vegetation is characterized by the above?
questions.solution: Solution:		Equatorial moist evergreen vegetation is characterized by the above statement.

questions.Question: It is the branch of biology which deals with the study of relationship between organisms and their environment.
questions.solution: Solution:		Ecology is the branch of biology, that deals with the inter-relationships amongst organism and interactions between organisms and their environment.

questions.Question: Which of the following is responsible for Vermicomposting?
questions.solution: Solution:		Worms are responsible for Vermicomposting.

questions.Question: The bacterium which reduces the fertility of soil is
questions.solution: Solution:		Bacillus dentificans is the bacterium which reduces the fertility of soil.

questions.Question: They are used in the retting of flax and hemp.
questions.solution: Solution:		Bacteria are used in the retting of flax and hemp.

questions.Question: Which of the following bacteria is responsible for the formation of curd?
questions.solution: Solution:		The preparation of curd requires a lactobacillus bacteria, while yogurt is made using two specific strains of bacteria called Lactobacillus delbrueckii subsp. bulgaricus and Streptococcus thermophilus bacteria. Other strains of lactic acid bacteria may also be added.

questions.Question: Yeast used in making bread is a
questions.solution: Solution:		Baker's yeast is the common name for the strains of yeast commonly used in baking bread and bakery products, serving as a leavening agent which causes the bread to rise (expand and become lighter and softer) by converting the fermentable sugars present in the dough into carbon dioxide and ethanol. It is a fungus.

questions.Question: Nitrogen fixation process in the soil is done by
questions.solution: Solution:		Most nitrogen fixation occurs naturally, in the soil, by bacteria.

questions.Question: In 1610, who made microscope and used it to observe very small animals?
questions.solution: Solution:		Galileo made microscope and used it to observe very small animals.

questions.Question: What three statements make up the cell theory?
questions.optionA: All living things are made up of cells
questions.optionB: New cells come frome exisiting cells
questions.optionC: Cells are the basic unit of structure/function in living things
questions.solution: Solution:		The unified cell theory states that: all living things are composed of one or more cells; the cell is the basic unit of life; and new cells arise from existing cells.

questions.Question: The outermost layer in a plant cell is
questions.solution: Solution:		The outermost layer in a plant cell is cell wall.

questions.Question: The longest cells of human body is
questions.solution: Solution:		Neurons or nerve cells can be up to 3 feet long. A typical neuron has a cell morphology called soma, hair-like structures called dendrites and an axon. Neurons are specialized in conveying knowledge throughout the body. The sensory neurons, motor neurons, and interneurons are three types of neurons.

questions.Question: They contain those enzymes which can digest the phagocytosed food particles.
questions.solution: Solution:		Lysosomes are membrane-enclosed organelles that contain an array of enzymes capable of breaking down all types of biological polymers proteins, nucleic acids, carbohydrates, and lipids.

questions.Question: In plants cells,which structure provides a definite shape to the cell and makes it right?
questions.solution: Solution:		Plant cells have a cell wall, as well as a cell membrane. In plants, the cell wall surrounds the cell membrane. This gives the plant cell its unique rectangular shape.

questions.Question: Produces a usable form of energy for the cell
questions.solution: Solution:		Mitochondria produces a usable form of energy for the cell.

questions.Question: Which among the following is also called as 'power house of the cell'?
questions.solution: Solution:		Mitochondria is also called as 'power house of the cell'.

questions.Question: Volume of blood found in a healthy person is
questions.solution: Solution:		Volume of blood found in a healthy person is 5-6 litre.

questions.Question: Which blood group is universal donor?
questions.solution: Solution:		For emergency transfusions, blood group type O negative blood is the variety of blood that has the lowest risk of causing serious reactions for most people who receive it. Because of this, it's sometimes called the universal blood donor type.

questions.Question: Filtration of blood takes place in
questions.solution: Solution:		Filtration of blood takes place in kidney.

questions.Question: In Mammal urinary bladder open into
questions.solution: Solution:		The bladder has three openings. The two ureters enter the bladder at ureteric orifices, and the urethra enters at the trigone of the bladder.

questions.Question: Nephrology is the study of
questions.solution: Solution:		Nephrology is a specialty of medicine and pediatric medicine that concerns with study of the kidneys.

questions.Question: The organs of the urinary system are
questions.solution: Solution:		The organs of the urinary system include the kidneys, renal pelvis, ureters, bladder and urethra.

questions.Question: The basic functional unit of kidney is
questions.solution: Solution:		The nephron, the functional unit of the kidney, is responsible for removing waste from the body.

questions.Question: Organisms which synthesise their own food are called
questions.solution: Solution:		An autotroph is an organism that can produce its own food using light, water, carbon dioxide, or other chemicals. Because autotrophs produce their own food, they are sometimes called producers.

questions.Question: Anaemia is caused because of deficiency of which of the following?
questions.solution: Solution:		As the name implies, iron deficiency anaemia is due to insufficient iron. Without enough iron, your body can't produce enough of a substance in red blood cells that enables them to carry oxygen (hemoglobin). As a result, iron deficiency anaemia may leave you tired and short of breath.

questions.Question: Which of the following is a good source of protein?
questions.solution: Solution:		Soyabean is a good source of protein.

questions.Question: Goitre is due to the deficiency of
questions.solution: Solution:		The most common cause of goiters worldwide is a lack of iodine in the diet. In the United States, where the use of iodized salt is common, a goiter is more often due to the over- or underproduction of thyroid hormones or to nodules in the gland itself.

questions.Question: Biological complete proteins are found in
questions.solution: Solution:		Complete proteins contain the eight essential amino acids that are needed and can be found in foods such as fish, dairy products, and eggs.

questions.Question: When the diaphragm and external intercostal muscles contract,
questions.optionA: The volume of the thorax decreases
questions.optionB: The volume of the lungs decreases
questions.optionC: The volume of the thorax increases
questions.solution: Solution:		When the diaphragm and external intercostal muscles contract, the volume of the thorax increases.

questions.Question: Blood leaving lungs, is rich in
questions.solution: Solution:		Blood leaving lungs, is rich in oxygen.

questions.Question: The organs protected by the thoracic cage include the
questions.solution: Solution:		The thoracic cage encloses and protects the organs of the thoracic cavity, including the heart and lungs.

questions.Question: By complete oxidation of glucose number of ATP molecule formed is
questions.solution: Solution:		By complete oxidation of glucose number of ATP molecule formed is 38.

questions.Question: If CO2 concentration in the blood increases, the breathing will
questions.solution: Solution:		When CO2 concentration in blood increases, breathing becomes faster and deeper.

questions.Question: When the concentration of water and solutes on either side of the cell membrane is same, the solution is said to be
questions.solution: Solution:		When the concentration of water and solutes on either side of the cell membrane is same, the solution is said to be isotonic.

questions.Question: Water molecules enter plant epidermal cells by
questions.solution: Solution:		Water enters the root hair cells by osmosis. This happens because soil water has a higher water potential than the cytoplasm of the root hair cell. Minerals enter by active transport.

questions.Question: Root pressure is developed in
questions.solution: Solution:		Root pressure, in plants, force that helps to drive fluids upward into the water-conducting vessels (xylem). It is primarily generated by osmotic pressure in the cells of the roots and can be demonstrated by exudation of fluid when the stem is cut off just aboveground.

questions.Question: What process accounts for species diversity?
questions.solution: Solution:		Meiosis is the process which accounts for species diversity. Meiosis is termed as a specialized cell division which reduces chromosomes number by half and then creates for haploid cells.

questions.Question: When are chromatids found in a cell?
questions.solution: Solution:		Chromatids are found during metaphase.

questions.Question: Sickle-cell anaemia is due to
questions.solution: Solution:		Sickle-cell anaemia is due to genes.

questions.Question: Who gave the term "Antibiotics"?
questions.solution: Solution:		The word 'antibiotics' was first used over 30 years later by the Ukrainian-American inventor and microbiologist Selman Waksman, who in his lifetime discovered over 20 antibiotics.

questions.Question: Antibody is produced by
questions.solution: Solution:		Antibody is produced by B-lymphocytes.

questions.Question: In man which organisms cause abscesses on the skin of arms or legs?
questions.solution: Solution:		In man Suinea worm cause abscesses on the skin of arms or legs

questions.Question: Which disease killed more peoples than any other death causing factors including all other diseases, natural calamities and wars?
questions.solution: Solution:		Malaria killed more peoples than any other death causing factors including all other diseases, natural calamities and wars.

questions.Question: Most common disease of poultry in India is
questions.solution: Solution:		Most common disease of poultry in India is ranikhet.

questions.Question: Most abundant tissues of our body are
questions.solution: Solution:		Among these Connective Tissue are most abundant in our body. Connective tissue is found in between other tissues everywhere in the body, including the nervous system.

questions.Question: Mumps is a disease caused by
questions.solution: Solution:		Mumps is a contagious disease that is caused by a virus. It typically starts with a few days of fever, headache, muscle aches, tiredness, and loss of appetite. Then most people will have swelling of their salivary glands.

questions.Question: Rain water helps to increase the ____ to some extent.
questions.solution: Solution:		Rain water helps to increase the calcium contents to some extent.

questions.Question: Number of chromosomes in down's syndrome is
questions.solution: Solution:		Number of chromosomes in down's syndrome is 47.

questions.Question: The trypsinogen is an enzyme secreted by the
questions.solution: Solution:		Trypsinogen is the precursor form (or zymogen) of trypsin, a digestive enzyme. It is produced by the pancreas and found in pancreatic juice, along with amylase, lipase, and chymotrypsinogen.

questions.Question: Which body part will be affected with the disease leprosy?
questions.solution: Solution:		Leprosy is a chronic bacterial infection. It affects the skin and various nervous systems of the body, particularly the peripheral nerves. Leprosy is more common in tropical and subtropical areas. The disease is curable through multi-drug therapy.

questions.Question: AIDS is caused by the Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV). The transmission of HIV infection generally occurs through
questions.optionB: Transfusion of contaminated blood and blood products
questions.solution: Solution:		The transmission of HIV requires contact with a body fluid that contains the virus or cells infected with the virus. HIV can appear in nearly any body fluid, but transmission occurs mainly through blood, semen, vaginal fluids, and breast milk.

questions.Question: Which one of the following diseases is caused by bacteria and spread through faecal matter by houseflies ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Typhoid is caused by bacteria and spread through faecal matter by houseflies.

questions.Question: Which cells are destroyed in AIDS?
questions.solution: Solution:		Lymphocytes are destroyed in AIDS.

questions.Question: Who formulated Cell theory?
questions.solution: Solution:		Cell theory was formulated by two scientists: Theodor Schwann and Matthias Jakob Schleiden.

questions.Question: Which of the following are known as the suicide bags of cells?
questions.solution: Solution:		Lysosomes are found in animal cell, they are also known as suicidal bags of the cell. A human cell contains around 300 lysosomes. They not only digest large molecules but also responsible for breaking down and getting rid of waste products of the cell. They have enzymes which allow them to carry out these processes.

questions.Question: Which feature do prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells share?
questions.solution: Solution:		The common features of prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells are: DNA, the genetic material contained in one or more chromosomes and located in a non membrane bound nucleoid region in prokaryotes and a membrane-bound nucleus in eukaryotes.

questions.Question: Which of the following contain enzymes for cellular respiration ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Mitochondria contain enzymes for cellular respiration. Mitochondria are known as the powerhouse of the cell.

questions.Question: The smallest unit that is capable of carrying out life functions is known as
questions.solution: Solution:		The cell is the smallest structural and functional unit of living organisms, which can exist on its own. Therefore, it is sometimes called the building block of life.

questions.Question: The main function of the Golgi body is
questions.solution: Solution:		A Golgi body, also known as a Golgi apparatus, is a cell organelle that helps process and package proteins and lipid molecules, especially proteins destined to be exported from the cell.

questions.Question: Which organelle is the control center of a cell?
questions.solution: Solution:		The nucleus is the largest organelle in a eukaryotic cell and is considered to be the cell's control center. It contains most of the cell's DNA, which makes up chromosomes and is encoded with the genetic instructions for making proteins.

questions.Question: Which of the following organelles of a cell is involved in photosynthesis?
questions.solution: Solution:		In plants, photosynthesis takes place in chloroplasts, which contain the chlorophyll. Chloroplasts are surrounded by a double membrane and contain a third inner membrane, called the thylakoid membrane, that forms long folds within the organelle.

questions.Question: The theory which states that all animals and plants are composed of cells and cell products is known as
questions.solution: Solution:		By the late 1830s, botanist Matthias Schleiden and zoologist Theodor Schwann were studying tissues and proposed the unified cell theory. The unified cell theory states that: all living things are composed of one or more cells; the cell is the basic unit of life; and new cells arise from existing cells.

questions.Question: Biologists mainly deal with matters relating to
questions.optionB: Non living things influencing living things
questions.optionD: All three a b and c
questions.solution: Solution:		Biologists mainly deal with matters relating to living part of nature, non living things influencing living things and how life works.

questions.Question: Vitamin present in guava fruit is
questions.solution: Solution:		Guava has a rich source of vitamin C, A and E. Guava is called the super fruit because it is said to contain four times more vitamin C than orange and three times more proteins and four times more fibre than pineapple. It is also said to have more potassium than a banana.

questions.Question: Vitamins are
questions.solution: Solution:		Vitamins are micro nutrients.

questions.Question: Which of the following vitamins acts like hormone?
questions.solution: Solution:		Vitamin D is a hormone the kidneys produce that controls blood calcium concentration and impacts the immune system. It is also known as calcitriol, ergocalciferol, calcidiol and cholecalciferol. Of those, calcidiol is the form doctors most commonly focus on when measuring vitamin D levels in the blood.

questions.Question: Which of the following vitamins are water soluble?
questions.solution: Solution:		The water-soluble vitamins include ascorbic acid (vitamin C), thiamin, riboflavin, niacin, vitamin B6 (pyridoxine, pyridoxal, and pyridoxamine), folacin, vitamin B12, biotin, and pantothenic acid.

questions.Question: Lathyrism is caused by excess consumption of ________
questions.solution: Solution:		Lathyrism is a disease caused by eating seeds of species of Lathyrus (the grass pea), mainly L. sativus (the chickpea or khesari).

questions.Question: The term biology was first coined by
questions.solution: Solution:		Lamark and Treviranus coined the term biology for the first time.

questions.Question: The largest invertebrate is
questions.solution: Solution:		The giant squid remains largely a mystery to scientists despite being the biggest invertebrate on Earth. The largest of these elusive giants ever found measured 59 feet in length and weighed nearly a ton.

questions.Question: The tallest moss in the world is
questions.solution: Solution:		The tallest moss in the world is Dawsonia.

questions.Question: The unique feature of bryophytes compared to other green plants groups is that
questions.optionD: Their sporophytes is attached to gametophyte
questions.solution: Solution:		The unique feature of bryophytes compared to other green plant group is that it contains no xylem for conducting water through the plant, instead it conducts water and nutrients through the leaves. Therefore, these are termed as non vascular terrestrial plants.

questions.Question: Animals/organisms floating on the surface of water are
questions.solution: Solution:		Animals or organism floating on the surface of water is plankton.

questions.Question: Which of the following plants produce only seeds but no fruit?
questions.solution: Solution:		Cycas and Pinus are Gymnosperms, those have seeds but not fruits or flowers.

questions.Question: Consider the following plant1. Guava2. Mint3. Sweet potatoThe roots of which of these plants bear adventitious buds that developed into new individuals under favourable conditions.
questions.solution: Solution:		The roots of sweet potato bear adventitious buds that developed into new individuals under favourable conditions.

questions.Question: Potato is a
questions.solution: Solution:		Potatoes are stem tubers. Enlarged stolons thicken to develop into storage organs. The tuber has all the parts of a normal stem, including nodes and internodes.

questions.Question: The "eyes" of potato tubers are
questions.solution: Solution:		The axillary buds of the potato tuber are called “eyes” in common language. They are found at the nodes of the stem tuber.

questions.Question: Which of the following is responsible for transport of food and other substances in plants?
questions.solution: Solution:		The food which is prepared by the process of photosynthesis in the leaves of a plant has to be transported to other parts like stem, roots, branches etc. Therefore this food is transported to other parts of the plant through a kind of tubes called phloem.

questions.Question: Plant bends towards the source of light on account of the movement of curvature known as
questions.solution: Solution:		Phototropism is one of the many plant tropisms or movements which respond to external stimuli. Growth towards a light source is called positive phototropism, while growth away from light is called negative phototropism (skototropism).

questions.Question: Plant have ____ while animals lack it.
questions.solution: Solution:		Plant have cellulose while animals lack it.

questions.Question: Osmosis is the flow of solution from higher concentration to a solution of lower concentration through a semi permeable membrane. What is incorrect in this statement?
questions.optionA: Exact concentration of solution is not given
questions.optionB: Character of semi permeable membrane is not given
questions.optionC: The flow of solution is not possible through semi permeable membrane
questions.solution: Solution:		Osmosis is defined as the flow of solvent molecules from a region of their higher concentration to a region of their lower concentration across a semipermeable membrane. Osmosis does not explains movement of solute particles or solution.

questions.Question: Photosynthesis is a process
questions.solution: Solution:		Photosynthesis is a process which is reductive, endergonic and anabolic.

questions.Question: On which of the following plants did Gregor Mendal perform his classical experiment?
questions.solution: Solution:		Gregor Mendal performed his classical experiment on pea.

questions.Question: The female sex organs in a flower is the ________ .
questions.solution: Solution:		As a plant's reproductive part, a flower contains a stamen (male flower part) or pistil (female flower part), or both, plus accessory parts such as sepals, petals, and nectar glands. The stamen is the male reproductive organ.

questions.Question: The male sex organs in a flower is the ________ .
questions.solution: Solution:		As a plant's reproductive part, a flower contains a stamen (male flower part) or pistil (female flower part), or both, plus accessory parts such as sepals, petals, and nectar glands. The stamen is the male reproductive organ. It consists of a pollen sac (anther) and a long supporting filament.

questions.Question: Which part of flower produces pollen grains that are generally yellowish in colour?
questions.solution: Solution:		Stamens are the part of the flower that produces pollen. Pollen is fine yellowish dust made by stamens inside a flower that contains the male sperm cells.

questions.Question: Which one of the following is the longest flower in the world?
questions.solution: Solution:		The flower with the world's largest bloom is the Rafflesia arnoldii. This rare flower is found in the rainforests of Indonesia. It can grow to be 3 feet across and weigh up to 15 pounds. It is a parasitic plant, with no visible leaves, roots, or stem.

questions.Question: Usually the conspicuous, coloured, attractive part of flower is termed as
questions.solution: Solution:		The parts of a flower that are often conspicuously coloured are called petals.

questions.Question: Who discovered the insecticidal properties of DDT?
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1939 the Swiss chemist Paul Müller discovered the insecticidal properties of DDT.

questions.Question: There is no bacteria activity in which of the following process?
questions.solution: Solution:		There is no bacteria activity in the ripening of cheese.

questions.Question: ________ reproduces by binary fission.
questions.solution: Solution:		Amoeba reproduces by binary fission.

questions.Question: The DNA of the bacterium is found present in a distinct nuclear region called
questions.solution: Solution:		The nucleoid (meaning nucleus-like) is an irregularly-shaped region within the cell of a prokaryote that contains all or most of the genetic material. In contrast to the nucleus of a eukaryotic cell, it is not surrounded by a nuclear membrane.

questions.Question: In autotrophic bacteria, where is chlorophyll located?
questions.solution: Solution:		In autotrophic bacteria, chlorophyll is located in the infolded plasma membrane.

questions.Question: Plants are killed in winter by frost
questions.optionA: because of desiccation and mechanical damage to the tissues
questions.optionB: because no photosynthesis takes place at such low temperature
questions.optionC: because respiration ceases at such low temperature
questions.solution: Solution:		Plants are killed in winter by frost as there is desiccation and mechanical damage to the tissues. Desiccation is the state of extreme dryness, or the process of extreme drying.

questions.Question: One of the following is most suitable for study of mutations
questions.solution: Solution:		Haploids are more suitable for mutation studies than the diploids.

questions.Question: Pulses are a good source of
