questions.solution: Solution:		Pulses are a great source of protein. They can be particularly important for people who do not get protein by eating meat, fish or dairy products. Pulses include beans, lentils and peas.

questions.Question: Oxygen in our blood is transported by a protein named
questions.solution: Solution:		Oxygen in our blood is transported by a protein named Haemoglobin.

questions.Question: Nymph is the name of young one of
questions.solution: Solution:		Nymph is the name of young one of cockroach.

questions.Question: The genotype of a plant showing a dominant phenotype can be determined by
questions.solution: Solution:		The zygosity of F1 generation can be checked by test cross method. In a test cross : The organism with the dominant trait is always crossed with an organism with the recessive trait. If any offspring show the recessive trait, the unknown genotype is heterozygous. If all the offspring have the dominant trait, the unknown genotype is homozygous dominant. Large numbers of offspring are needed for reliable results.

questions.Question: Which of the following is not true about colour blindness?
questions.optionA: Colour blind people learn to rely on shapes, patterns, and positions of signs and signals
questions.optionB: Red-green colour blindness is the most common type of colour blindness
questions.optionC: A colour blind person cannot see any colours
questions.optionD: For some people, it might be difficult to recognize colours of traffic lights and signs
questions.solution: Solution:		A colour blind person cannot see any colors is not true of colour blindness.

questions.Question: Stem Cell Therapy (SCT) is not useful for the treatment of which one of the following ailments?
questions.solution: Solution:		Stem Cell Therapy (SCT) is not useful for the treatment of Vision impairment.

questions.Question: Which part of human eye controls the amount of light entering the eye?
questions.solution: Solution:		 When there is bright light, the iris closes the pupil to let in less light. And when there is low light, the iris opens up the pupil to let in more light. Focuses light rays onto the retina.

questions.Question: What is the distance of distinct vision (DDV) of a normal human eye?
questions.solution: Solution:		The minimum distance from the eye at which an object appears to be distinct i.e., a very clear image of the object is formed is called the distance of distinct vision. This distance is about 25 cm from the eye.

questions.Question: Which one of the following completes the given statement correctly ?Cretinism is a human disorder which is due to the under secretion of
questions.solution: Solution:		Cretinism is a human disorder which is due to the under secretion of Thyroxin hormone.

questions.Question: The thyroid hormone that regulates carbohydrate metabolism is
questions.solution: Solution:		The thyroid hormone that regulates carbohydrate metabolism is thyroxin.

questions.Question: Which of the following hormones contains Iodine?
questions.solution: Solution:		Thyroxine hormone contains iodine. The thyroid gland produces two primary hormones - thyroxine and tri-iodothyronine.

questions.Question: Which of the following is not an Endocrine Gland?
questions.solution: Solution:		Spleen is not an Endocrine Gland.

questions.Question: Pineal gland is situated in
questions.solution: Solution:		The pineal gland is located deep in the brain in an area called the epithalamus, where the two halves of the brain join.

questions.Question: Which of the following hormone is called the emergency hormone ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Adrenaline, also known as epinephrine, is a hormone and medication. Adrenaline is normally produced by both the adrenal glands and a small number of neurons in the medulla oblongata, where it acts as a neurotransmitter involved in regulating visceral functions.

questions.Question: Which cells secrete hormones?
questions.solution: Solution:		Glands secrete hormones.

questions.Question: Insulin is secreted from which gland or organ of human body?
questions.solution: Solution:		The most important hormone that the pancreas produces is insulin. Insulin is released by the 'beta cells' in the islets of Langerhans in response to food.

questions.Question: Which one of the following crops would be preferred for sowing in order to enrich soil with nitrogen?
questions.solution: Solution:		The "gram crops" would be preferred for sowing in order to enrich the "soil with nitrogen".

questions.Question: Censor mechanism of dispersal of seeds is found in
questions.solution: Solution:		Censor mechanism of seed dispersal is a type of dispersal by wind, which generally occur in poppy. Its seeds bear hairy fibers outside and are very light in weight, which aid in easy dispersal by wind.

questions.Question: What does the central nervous system consists of?
questions.solution: Solution:		The central nervous system is made up of the brain and spinal cord. The peripheral nervous system is made up of nerves that branch off from the spinal cord and extend to all parts of the body.

questions.Question: How many pair of nerves arises from vertebral column?
questions.solution: Solution:		31 pair of nerves arises from vertebral column.

questions.Question: Which one is the biggest part of the brain?
questions.solution: Solution:		The largest part of the brain, the cerebrum has two hemispheres (or halves). The cerebrum controls voluntary movement, speech, intelligence, memory, emotion, and sensory processing.

questions.Question: The brain is a part of which organ system?
questions.solution: Solution:		The nervous system is made up of the central nervous system and the peripheral nervous system: The brain and the spinal cord are the central nervous system. The nerves that go through the whole body make up the peripheral nervous system.

questions.Question: Asexual reproduction differs from sexual reproduction in that in asexual reproduction, ________
questions.optionA: The new organisms are genetically identical to the parent
questions.optionB: The gametes are produced in reproduction
questions.solution: Solution:		Sexual reproduction just means combining genetic material from two parents. Asexual reproduction produces offspring genetically identical to the one parent.

questions.Question: A seed is ripened ________
questions.solution: Solution:		A seed is a small embryonic plant enclosed in a covering called the seed coat, usually with some stored food. It is the product of the ripened ovule of gymnosperm and angiosperm plants which occurs after fertilization and some growth with in the mother plant.

questions.Question: Which among the following is not a true fruit?
questions.solution: Solution:		Technically, apple is not a true fruit. A fruit is a ripened ovary. Inside the apple fruit , the structure holding the seeds is actually the fruit while the edible fleshy part is actually the swollen wall material of ovary.

questions.Question: Which of these is unique to flowering plants?
questions.optionB: An embryo surrounded by nutritive tissue
questions.solution: Solution:		In flowering plants one sperm nucleus fertilizes the egg and the other sperm nucleus fuses with two other nuclei found within the ovule, thus forming triploid endosperm. Hence, double fertilization is unique to flowering plants.

questions.Question: The pollination by snails is called
questions.solution: Solution:		Pollination is a crucial ecological process that aids sexual reproduction in flowering plants. Although a variety of animals are known to bring about pollen transfer, pollination by snails (malacophily) has remained a rare and obscure phenomenon.

questions.Question: Which one of the following completes the given statement correctly?A seed is a ripened _______
questions.solution: Solution:		A seed is a ripened ovule.

questions.Question: Which group of organisms serves as the best indicator of pollution in a water body?
questions.solution: Solution:		Plankton serves as the best indicator of pollution in a water body.

questions.Question: In female a small portion oviduct is removed and cut end is ligated by surgical operation is called
questions.solution: Solution:		Surgical methods, also called as sterilisation, are generally advised for the male/female partner as a terminal method to prevent any more pregnancies.Surgical intervention blocks gamete transport and thereby prevent conception. Sterilisation procedure in the male is called as vasectomy and that in the female, tubectomy.

questions.Question: Which of the following would cause gene flow?
questions.solution: Solution:		Gene flow means migration of genes from one to another. This gene flow is caused by individuals moving into population.

questions.Question: Oral pills of birth control prevent
questions.solution: Solution:		Oral contraceptives (birth-control pills) are used to prevent pregnancy. Estrogen and progestin are two female sex hormones. Combinations of estrogen and progestin work by preventing ovulation (the release of eggs from the ovaries).

questions.Question: Study of population is
questions.solution: Solution:		The field of science interested in collecting and analyzing numbers related to population is known as demography.

questions.Question: The audible sounds of heart are made by the closing of the
questions.solution: Solution:		Closure of the heart valves is associated with an audible sound, called the heartbeat.

questions.Question: Which one is the largest artery in the human body
questions.solution: Solution:		Most arteries carry oxygenated blood. The largest artery is the aorta, which is connected to the heart and extends into the abdomen.

questions.Question: Which veins do not carry deoxygenated blood?
questions.solution: Solution:		Veins are blood vessels that carry blood towards the heart. Most veins carry deoxygenated blood from the tissues back to the heart; exceptions are the pulmonary and umbilical veins, both of which carry oxygenated blood to the heart.

questions.Question: Muscular wall of the heart is externally covered by
questions.solution: Solution:		The wall of the heart consists of three layers: the epicardium (external layer), the myocardium (middle layer) and the endocardium (inner layer).

questions.Question: The deposition of cholesterol on the walls of blood vessels causes the arteries to lose their elasticity and get stiffened is called
questions.solution: Solution:		Atherosclerosis, sometimes called "hardening of the arteries," occurs when fat, cholesterol, and other substances build up in the walls of arteries.

questions.Question: In test tube baby
questions.optionA: Fertilization of ova and development takes place in test tube
questions.optionB: Fertilization of ova takes place in test tube which development of embryo occur in uterus
questions.optionC: Fertilization takes place in uterus while development takes place in test tube
questions.optionD: Development of ova take place in test tube without fertilization
questions.solution: Solution:		In test tube baby fertilization of ova takes place in test tube and development of embryo occur in uterus.

questions.Question: In uterus embryo get their nutrition through a structure called
questions.solution: Solution:		The placenta is the structure which attaches the developing embryo with the mother. This is the structure which is attached to the umbilical cord of the embryo. The placenta helps to provide nutrition to the embryo. This structure also carries oxygen to the embryo and the wastes away from the embryo.

questions.Question: Study of female reproductive system is
questions.solution: Solution:		Study of female reproductive system is gyneocology.

questions.Question: Which among the following is/are female hormones?(i) Estrogen(ii) Progesterone(iii) Testosterone
questions.solution: Solution:		Estrogen and Progesterone are female hormones.

questions.Question: Fertilization in human takes place inside
questions.solution: Solution:		Fertilization in human takes place inside oviduct.

questions.Question: Biological membranes are composed of
questions.solution: Solution:		Biological membranes are composed of Phospholipids,proteins and carbohydrate groups.

questions.Question: Biological membranes are composed of
questions.solution: Solution:		Biological membranes are composed of 60% proteins and 40% lipids.

questions.Question: They are double membrane structures that are commonly oval or disc shaped.
questions.solution: Solution:		Ribosomes are double membrane structures that are commonly oval or disc shaped.

questions.Question: The cell wall of plants is generally made up of cellulose and is differently structured than that of a
questions.solution: Solution:		The cell wall of plants is generally made up of cellulose and is differently structured than that of a bacterium.

questions.Question: Which cell feature is responsible for making proteins?
questions.solution: Solution:		Ribosomes is responsible for making proteins.

questions.Question: Most of the digestion occur in which part of alimentary canal of man
questions.solution: Solution:		Most of the digestion of food takes place in the small intestine which is the longest part of the GI tract. A major digestive organ is the stomach. Within its mucosa are millions of embedded gastric glands.

questions.Question: Which of the following is not an enzyme?
questions.solution: Solution:		Oxytocin is not an enzyme.

questions.Question: Man has ________ pairs of salivary glands.
questions.solution: Solution:		There are three pairs of major salivary glands: the parotid glands, the submandibular glands, and the sublingual glands.

questions.Question: All enzymes are
questions.solution: Solution:		Enzymes are proteins that act as biological catalysts (biocatalysts). Catalysts accelerate chemical reactions.

questions.Question: Which one of the following is the correct sequence in the order of decreasing length of the structural parts given below of small intestine in the human body?
questions.solution: Solution:		Ileum-Jejunum-Duodenum is the correct sequence.

questions.Question: Photosynthesis takes place in the presence of chlorophyll and ________
questions.solution: Solution:		Photosynthesis takes place in the presence of chlorophyll and sunlight.

questions.Question: One of the following cannot be performed by animals.
questions.solution: Solution:		Photosynthesis cannot be performed by animals.

questions.Question: Green pigment is called
questions.solution: Solution:		Green pigment is called Chlorophyll.

questions.Question: Plants utilise ________ from the atmosphere for photosynthesis.
questions.solution: Solution:		During photosynthesis, plants take in carbon dioxide (CO2) and water (H2O) from the air and soil. Within the plant cell, the water is oxidized, meaning it loses electrons, while the carbon dioxide is reduced, meaning it gains electrons. This transforms the water into oxygen and the carbon dioxide into glucose.

questions.Question: In Photosynthesis
questions.optionA: Light energy is converted into chemical energy
questions.optionB: Chemical energy is converted into light energy
questions.optionC: Chemical energy is converted into electrical energy
questions.optionD: Light energy is converted into mechanical eneargy
questions.solution: Solution:		In Photosynthesis light energy is converted into chemical energy.

questions.Question: All insects have how many parts of legs?
questions.solution: Solution:		All insects have 3 parts of a leg.

questions.Question: All living things except bacteria and blue green algae are termed as
questions.solution: Solution:		All living things except bacteria and blue green algae are termed as eukaryotes.

questions.Question: There are how many species of fungi?
questions.solution: Solution:		There are 80,000 species of fungi.

questions.Question: Which of the following is true of annelids?
questions.optionA: They have an open circulatory system
questions.optionC: They perform gas exchange across their skin
questions.solution: Solution:		Annelids perform gas exchange across their skin.

questions.Question: Which of the following has the largest number of chromosomes?
questions.solution: Solution:		Pteridophytes has the largest number of chromosomes.

questions.Question: During which phase centromeres divide and chromatids separate into chromosomes?
questions.solution: Solution:		During anaphase, the “upward phase,” the cohesin proteins degrade, and the sister chromatids separate at the centromere. Each chromatid, now called a chromosome, is pulled rapidly toward the centrosome to which its microtubule is attached.

questions.Question: The shape of chromosome is clearly visible at
questions.solution: Solution:		The shape of chromosome is clearly visible at metaphase.

questions.Question: How many daughter cells are formed after the completion mitosis?
questions.solution: Solution:		At the end of mitosis, two daughter cells will be formed which are exact copies of the original cell. Each daughter cell will have 30 chromosomes.

questions.Question: Pollen is produced by the process of
questions.solution: Solution:		Pollen development is a postmeiotic process that produces immature pollen grains from microspores. The maturation process can be dissected into various stages. During microspore mitosis, the pollen first develops a large vacuole that mediates nuclear migration to produce polarized cells.

questions.Question: How many daughter cells reproduces after the completion of Meiosis II?
questions.solution: Solution:		Completion of meiosis II results in the production of four haploid daughter cells, each of which contains only one copy of each chromosome.

questions.Question: What does stomach acid mostly consist of?
questions.solution: Solution:		Your stomach has a nifty way of digesting proteins and it's called stomach acid, though you might know it as gastric juice or simply acid. It mainly consists of hydrochloric acid, a potent chemical produced by the cells lining the stomach (parietal cells) and your gastric glands.

questions.Question: Which one of the following is a digestive hormone?
questions.solution: Solution:		Gastrin is a digestive hormone.

questions.Question: The teeth lacking in herbivorous animals is
questions.solution: Solution:		Premolar teeth are lacking in herbivorous animal.

questions.Question: Alimentary canal runs from mouth to
questions.solution: Solution:		The digestive system is made up of the alimentary canal (also called the digestive tract) and other organs, such as the liver and pancreas. Alimentary canal runs from mouth to anus.

questions.Question: Which one is the longest part of the alimentary canal?
questions.solution: Solution:		The longest part of the alimentary canal, the small intestine is about 3.05 meters (10 feet) long in a living person (but about twice as long in a cadaver due to the loss of muscle tone).

questions.Question: Pepsin is a
questions.solution: Solution:		Pepsin is a stomach enzyme that serves to digest proteins found in ingested food. Gastric chief cells secrete pepsin as an inactive zymogen called pepsinogen. Parietal cells within the stomach lining secrete hydrochloric acid that lowers the pH of the stomach.

questions.Question: The hormone which stimulates the stomach for the production of digestive juice is
questions.solution: Solution:		Gastrin is a hormone produced by the stomach, which stimulates the release of gastric acid.

questions.Question: Most absorption of nutrients occurs in the
questions.solution: Solution:		Most absorption of nutrients occurs in the small intestine.

questions.Question: Which of the following is the largest digestive gland in humans?
questions.solution: Solution:		Hepato-Pancreas is the largest digestive gland.

questions.Question: Which one among the following is the hardest part of our body ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Enamel of teeth is the hardest part of our body.

questions.Question: Tracheids are conducting cells of which tissue?
questions.solution: Solution:		Tracheids (top) and vessel elements (bottom) are the water conducting cells of xylem tissue.

questions.Question: The main function of the inner bark of a woody plant is to
questions.optionA: Transport minerals and water from the roots to the leaves
questions.optionB: Act as a membrane impermeable to water and gas
questions.optionC: Transport food from the leaves to the other parts of the plant
questions.optionD: Protect the plant from herbivorous animals
questions.solution: Solution:		The inner bark is composed of living tissues, which help translocate the sugars created in the leaves to other parts of the plant. This happens in the secondary phloem.

questions.Question: Which one of the following tissues is responsible for increase of girth in the stem of a plant?
questions.solution: Solution:		Cork cambium and vascular cambium are responsible for the increase in diameter of the stem and root of a plant. These are present in dicot plants. These are the lateral meristem and are responsible for the secondary growth of the plant.

questions.Question: Which of the following transports water from the roots of the plant to its leaves?
questions.solution: Solution:		Xylem transports water from the roots of the plant to its leaves.

questions.Question: The water and mineral salts are transported to the various organs by which of the following?
questions.solution: Solution:		Xylem transports water and mineral salts from the roots up to other parts of the plant, while phloem transports sucrose and amino acids between the leaves and other parts of the plant.

questions.Question: The process in which energy stored in carbohydrates is released
questions.solution: Solution:		Photosynthesis absorbs energy from sunlight to build carbohydrates in the chloroplasts, and aerobic cellular respiration releases that stored energy by using oxygen to break down carbohydrates.

questions.Question: What is the purpose of the mucus in your nose?
questions.solution: Solution:		Mucus has a pretty important job — it keeps the lining of your nose moist and warms the air you breathe. Mucus also protects the lungs. When you breathe in air through your nose, it contains lots of tiny things, like dust, dirt, germs, and pollen.

questions.Question: Precentage of CO2 found in exhaled air is
questions.solution: Solution:		Precentage of CO2 found in exhaled air is 0.04.

questions.Question: Muscles get tired when there is shortfall of ________ .
questions.solution: Solution:		Muscles get tired when there is shortfall of ATP.

questions.Question: Cellular respiration is best associated with the
questions.solution: Solution:		Cellular respiration is best associated with the organelle mitochondrion.

questions.Question: Late blight of potato is caused by
questions.solution: Solution:		Late blight is caused by the oomycete Phytophthora infestans. Oomycetes are fungus-like organisms also called water molds, but they are not true fungi.

questions.Question: Amoeba proteus was discovered by
questions.solution: Solution:		The earliest record of an amoeboid organism was produced in 1755 by August Johann Rösel von Rosenhof, who named his discovery "Der Kleine Proteus" ("the Little Proteus").

questions.Question: Which of the fungi is commonly called as bread mould?
questions.solution: Solution:		Rhizopus stolonifer is commonly known as black bread mold. It is a member of Zygomycota and considered the most important species in the genus Rhizopus.

questions.Question: In N2 - fixation process, nitrite is converted to nitrate by
questions.solution: Solution:		In N2 - fixation process, nitrite is converted to nitrate by nitrobacter.

questions.Question: Green mould is common name for
questions.solution: Solution:		 Green mould is common name for Penicillium digitatum.

questions.Question: Pellagra and Scurvy are caused by which pair of vitamin deficiency respectively ________
questions.solution: Solution:		Pellagra and Scurvy are caused by Vitamin B-12 and Vitamin Cdeficiency respectively.

questions.Question: The kilo calories of energy released from one gram of fats is
questions.solution: Solution:		Carbohydrates provide 4 calories per gram, protein provides 4 calories per gram, and fat provides 9 calories per gram.

questions.Question: Deficiency of fluoride leads to which one of the following health problems?
questions.solution: Solution:		Fluoride deficiency is a disorder which may cause increased dental caries due to a lack of fluoride in the diet. Dental caries or tooth decay is the breakdown of dental tissues by the acidic products released by the "bacterial fermentation of dietary carbohydrates”.

questions.Question: Which of the following is not a function of proteins?
questions.optionA: Build tissues such as bone and muscle
questions.solution: Solution:		Store and transmit heredity is not a function of proteins.

questions.Question: Bleeding of gums, falling of teeth, fragile bones and delayed wound healing occur due to the deficiency of which one of the following vitamins?
questions.solution: Solution:		Deficiency of Vitamin C causes Scurvy, Swelling of gums etc.Vitamin K causes Non-clotting of blood ,Vitamin D causes Rickets in children and Osteomalasia in adults, Vitamin B 1 causes Beriberi,B2 causes Cracking of skin,reddish eye,cracking of tongue,B3 causes Whitening of hair ,mentally retardness ,B5 causes Pallagra or 4D syndrome,B6 causes Anemia,skin disease ,B7 causes Paralysis,hair falling,B11 causes Dysentery and B12 causes Jaundice and Teroile Glutemi.

questions.Question: Rate of transpiration can be measured by
questions.solution: Solution:		The uptake of water can be measured using a potometer. Under normal circumstances, the rate of water uptake gives a measure of the rate of transpiration . A simple potometer is a piece of capillary tubing to which a plant has been connected. Ganong's potometer is the right answer.

questions.Question: Most highly intelligent mammals are
questions.solution: Solution:		Dolphins are the most highly intelligent mammals.

questions.Question: Plant development is influenced by
questions.optionD: quality, quantity and duration of light
questions.solution: Solution:		Plant development is influenced by quality, quantity and duration of light. Plants cannot get too much light, but they can get too much of the heat energy that comes with the light.

questions.Question: Prokaryotic cells lack
questions.solution: Solution:		Prokaryotic cells lack nucleolus, nuclear membrane and membrane bound by organelles.

questions.Question: Photosynthesis takes place faster in
questions.solution: Solution:		As far as the rate of photosynthesis is concerned, it is fastest in white light making the rate of photosynthesis maximum. After white, we have violet light where photosynthesis occur to a higher extent as it has the shortest wavelength hence has the max energy.

questions.Question: Nucleus, the genetic material containing rounded body in each cell, was first discovered in 1831 by
questions.solution: Solution:		Nucleus, the genetic material containing rounded body in each cell, was first discovered in 1831 by Robert Brown.

questions.Question: Study of process of ageing
questions.solution: Solution:		Gerontology, the study of the aging process, is devoted to the understanding and control of all factors contributing to the finitude of individual life.

questions.Question: Sweating is important
questions.optionB: To open the pore of skin
questions.optionC: To control the temperature of body
questions.optionD: To excret the smell of body
questions.solution: Solution:		The main function of sweating is to control body temperature. As the water in the sweat evaporates, the surface of the skin cools. An additional function of sweat is to help with gripping, by slightly moistening the palms.

questions.Question: The outermost layer of skin is
questions.solution: Solution:		The stratum corneum is the outermost layer of the epidermis, and is made up of 10 to 30 thin layers of continually shedding, dead keratinocytes.

questions.Question: Homeostasis is the condition in which the body maintains
questions.optionA: A relatively stable internal environment within limits
questions.optionB: A changing state within an unlimited range
questions.optionD: A static state with no deviation from preset points
questions.solution: Solution:		Homeostasis is the condition in which a system such as the human body is maintained in a more-or-less steady state.

questions.Question: The normal temperature of human body on the Kelvin scale is
questions.solution: Solution:		The normal temperature of human body on the Kelvin scale is 310K.

questions.Question: The phenomenon of summer sleep by animals is called
questions.solution: Solution:		Aestivation is a state of animal dormancy, similar to hibernation, although taking place in the summer rather than the winter.

questions.Question: Animals who have constant body temperature are
questions.solution: Solution:		Animals who have constant body temperature are homeothermic.

questions.Question: Which type of cell, skin is made up of:
questions.solution: Solution:		Skin is made up of epidermal cells.

questions.Question: Cold blooded animals are known as
questions.solution: Solution:		Cold blooded animals are known as Poikilotherms.

questions.Question: Ginger is a stem and not a root because
questions.solution: Solution:		Ginger is a stem which can be differentiated from root because it (1) Grows parallel to ground. (2) Stores food. (3) Lacks chlorophyll. (4) Has nodes and internodes.

questions.Question: Grassland with scattered tree is known as
questions.solution: Solution:		Savanna is grassland with scattered individual trees.

questions.Question: Dr. Birbal Sahni; a famous Indian botanist is concerned with ________ studies.
questions.solution: Solution:		Birbal Sahni (14 November 1891 – 10 April 1949) was an Indian paleobotanist who studied the fossils of the Indian subcontinent. He also took an interest in geology and archaeology. He founded what is now the Birbal Sahni Institute of Palaeobotany at Lucknow in 1946.

questions.Question: Plants which grow on saline soils are known as
questions.solution: Solution:		A halophyte is a salt-tolerant plant that grows in soil or waters of high salinity, coming into contact with saline water through its roots or by salt spray, such as in saline semi-deserts, mangrove swamps, marshes and sloughs and seashores.

questions.Question: Which of the following organisms fix nitrogen in aquatic ecosystems?
questions.solution: Solution:		Fungi fix nitrogen in aquatic ecosystems.

questions.Question: Which ecological pyramid can never be inverted
questions.solution: Solution:		The pyramid of energy can never be inverted. The pyramid represents the amount of energy at each trophic level of the food chain.

questions.Question: Most of the red, blue and purple colours of plants are due to a pigment called
questions.solution: Solution:		Anthocyanin - A blue, violet, or red flavonoid pigment found in plants.

questions.Question: Plants developing in dry conditions are
questions.solution: Solution:		Xerophytes are adapted to survive in hot deserts where there is very little water. Xerophytes are common in coastal areas and thrive in saline water.

questions.Question: Plants growing on sand are called as
questions.solution: Solution:		Psammophytes are plants that preferentially grow in sand.

questions.Question: Our skin, when exposed to excess sunlight, becomes dark. This is because of our skin pigments called
questions.solution: Solution:		Within the skin's epidermal (outer) layer are cells that contain the pigment melanin. Suntanning occurs because exposure to sunlight causes the skin to produce more melanin and to darken. The tan fades as these cells move toward the surface and are sloughed off.

questions.Question: Ramapithecus and Cro-Magnon man are considered
questions.solution: Solution:		Ramapithecus and Cro-Magnon man are considered ancestors of modern man.

questions.Question: Which one of the following is not a genetic disorder?
questions.solution: Solution:		Xerophthalmia is not a genetic disorder.

questions.Question: Who is known as Father of Modern Genetics?
questions.solution: Solution:		Gregor Mendel is known as Father of Modern Genetics.

questions.Question: How many pairs of chromosomes are found in a human cell?
questions.solution: Solution:		A human cell has 23 pairs of chromosomes.

questions.Question: The experimental material used by Gregor Mendel is ________
questions.solution: Solution:		Mendel carried out his key experiments using the garden pea, Pisum sativum, as a model system.

questions.Question: Mendel's second law is the law of
questions.solution: Solution:		The results of Mendel's second set of experiments led to his second law. This is the law of independent assortment. It states that factors controlling different characteristics are inherited independently of each other.

questions.Question: What prevents food from entering the windpipe?
questions.solution: Solution:		In the second stage of swallowing, an important small flap of tissue called the epiglottis, folds over the voice box (larynx) at the entrance to the windpipe (trachea), preventing food from going down the wrong way.

questions.Question: Which of the following is true of enzymes?
questions.optionA: Enzymes lowers the activation energy for the chemical reaction
questions.optionB: Enzymes speed up the rate of a chemical reaction
questions.solution: Solution:		Enzymes lowers the activation energy for the chemical reaction and speed up the rate of a chemical reaction.

questions.Question: The substances, which assist enzymes act, are called
questions.solution: Solution:		Catalysts accelerate chemical reactions. The molecules upon which enzymes may act are called substrates, and the enzyme converts the substrates into different molecules known as products.

questions.Question: Biological catalysis in living organisms are known as
questions.solution: Solution:		Enzymes are biological catalysts produced by all living organisms. They facilitate the biochemical reactions that enable microbes, plants and animals to function.

questions.Question: Which of the following is not a function of saliva?
questions.optionA: Contains fluoride to harden the tooth enamel
questions.optionB: Moistens food and helps stick it together to make it easier to swallow
questions.optionC: Begins the chemical breakdown of starches
questions.solution: Solution:		Contains fluoride to harden the tooth enamel is not a function of saliva.

questions.Question: Which structure is specific to eukaryotic cells?
questions.solution: Solution:		Nucleus is specific to eukaryotic cell.

questions.Question: Which of these statements is true of the kingdom protista?
questions.solution: Solution:		The statement that is true of the kingdom protists is that all are eukaryotic.

questions.Question: Study of internal structure of organism is called
questions.solution: Solution:		Anatomy is the branch of biology concerned with the study of the structure of organisms and their parts.

questions.Question: Biology is the scientific study of
questions.solution: Solution:		Biology is a natural science concerned with the study of life and living organisms.

questions.Question: Which of the following does not have blood but undergoes respiration?
questions.solution: Solution:		Cockroach has blood known as homocoel, snails and kangaroos also have blood in their bodies. But hydra does not contain any blood but still it respires. It does not have any respiratory organs but it respires and thus exchanges gases throughout its body.

questions.Question: The outer white part of the eye which is supporting wall of the eyeball is known as
questions.solution: Solution:		The eye has three main layers. These layers lie flat against each other and form the eyeball. The outer layer of the eyeball is a tough, white, opaque membrane called the sclera (the white of the eye). The slight bulge in the sclera at the front of the eye is a clear, thin, dome-shaped tissue called the cornea.

questions.Question: Human eye can differentiate between colours due to
questions.solution: Solution:		Normal cones and pigment sensitivity enable an individual to distinguish all the different colours as well as subtle mixtures of hues. This type of normal colour vision is known as trichromacy and relies upon the mutual interaction from the overlapping sensitivity ranges of all three types of photoreceptor cone.

questions.Question: The outer membrane that covers the brain is
questions.solution: Solution:		Three layers of membranes known as meninges protect the brain and spinal cord. The delicate inner layer is the pia mater. The middle layer is the arachnoid, a web-like structure filled with fluid that cushions the brain. The tough outer layer is called the dura mater.

questions.Question: The innermost membrane that covers the brain is
questions.solution: Solution:		The pia mater is the innermost layer of meninges. This thin, delicate membrane is tightly bound to the surface of the brain and spinal cord and cannot be dissected away without damaging the surface. Meningiomas are tumors of the nerve tissue covering the brain and spinal cord.

questions.Question: Which systems comprise the nervous system?
questions.solution: Solution:		The nervous system has two main parts: The central nervous system is made up of the brain and spinal cord. The peripheral nervous system is made up of nerves that branch off from the spinal cord and extend to all parts of the body.

questions.Question: Which is the innermost layer of the heart?
questions.solution: Solution:		The inner layer of the heart wall is the endocardium, composed of endothelial cells that provide a smooth, elastic, non-adherent surface for blood collection and pumping.

questions.Question: ________ is a hormone that regulates the amount of glucose in the blood.
questions.solution: Solution:		Insulin is a peptide hormone made in the beta cells of the pancreas that is central to regulating carbohydrate metabolism in the body. After a meal, insulin is secreted into the bloodstream.

questions.Question: Which one of following is known as pace maker of endocrine gland?
questions.solution: Solution:		Thyroxin is secreted by thyroid gland (the largest gland), situated in neck region. Thyroxine regulates the metabolic rate, thus, called as pacesetter of the body. If there's more of thyroxine present in the blood, processes take place at a faster rate, energy is utilized at a faster rate, and if the amount of thyroxine secreted is less than required, the processes of the body take place at a slower pace, lesser energy utilization. Thus, functioning of thyroid gland has major effect on all the organs of our body.

questions.Question: The rate of heartbeat is accelerated by the hormone
questions.solution: Solution:		The rate of heartbeat is accelerated by the hormone. The hormone adrenaline also called epinephrine is known as a stress hormone. In emotional upsets( like fear, anger etc.) this hormone is poured into the blood and it accelerates heart beat.

questions.Question: Cortisol is secreted by
questions.solution: Solution:		Cortisol is released from the adrenal cortex and allows the body to continue to stay on high alert.

questions.Question: Reflex actions are controlled by
questions.solution: Solution:		A reflex arc is a neural pathway that controls a reflex. In vertebrates, most sensory neurons do not pass directly into the brain, but synapse in the spinal cord. This allows for faster reflex actions to occur by activating spinal motor neurons without the delay of routing signals through the brain.

questions.Question: What part of the body controls balance?
questions.solution: Solution:		The cerebellum, in the back of the brain, controls balance, coordination and fine muscle control (e.g., walking). It also functions to maintain posture and equilibrium.

questions.Question: Which part of the brain is responsible for consciousness?
questions.solution: Solution:		The cerebrum is the largest brain structure and part of the forebrain (or prosencephalon). Its prominent outer portion, the cerebral cortex, not only processes sensory and motor information but enables consciousness, our ability to consider ourselves and the outside world.

questions.Question: Which part of Nervous system controls involuntary actions?
questions.solution: Solution:		Medulla oblongata controls involuntary actions.

questions.Question: The brain is covered by
questions.solution: Solution:		The brain is covered by meninges, skin and bone.

questions.Question: Which of the following glands is both endocrine and exocrine?
questions.solution: Solution:		The liver and pancreas are both exocrine and endocrine glands; they are exocrine glands because they secrete products—bile and pancreatic juice—into the gastrointestinal tract through a series of ducts, and endocrine because they secrete other substances directly into the bloodstream.

questions.Question: Which hormone causes emotional disturbance?
questions.solution: Solution:		Oxytocin causes emotional disturbance.

questions.Question: Haemophilia is a hereditary disease carried by
questions.solution: Solution:		Haemophilia is a hereditary disease carried by females and expressed by males.

questions.Question: The sex of a newborn baby is determined by the chromosome inherited from
questions.solution: Solution:		The sex of a baby is determined by two sex chromosomes inherited from both the genetic parents. A baby will normally inherit one sex chromosome from the mother and one from the father. A woman has two X chromosomes and thus gives either of her X chromosomes. The father has one X chromosome and one Y chromosome, can give either his X or Y chromosome. The egg (from the mother) already contains an X chromosome. Therefore the sex of a baby is determined by the X or Y chromosome of thesperm cell from the father.

questions.Question: The chromosome number 2n is known as
questions.solution: Solution:		In sexually reproducing organisms, the number of chromosomes in the body (somatic) cells typically is diploid (2n; a pair of each chromosome), twice the haploid (1n) number found in the sex cells, or gametes.

questions.Question: Reflex actions are controlled by :
questions.solution: Solution:		A reflex arc is a neural pathway that controls a reflex. In vertebrates, most sensory neurons do not pass directly into the brain, but synapse in the spinal cord. This allows for faster reflex actions to occur by activating spinal motor neurons without the delay of routing signals through the brain.

questions.Question: Which one of the following is not an insect:
questions.solution: Solution:		Spiders are arachnids. So are scorpions, mites, and ticks. Arachnids are classified primarily by having eight legs and two distinct body regions, the cephalothorax (which is a fusion of the head and thorax), and the abdomen.

questions.Question: Which cell organelles are involved in photosynthesis?
questions.solution: Solution:		In plants, photosynthesis takes place in chloroplasts, which contain the chlorophyll. Chloroplasts are surrounded by a double membrane and contain a third inner membrane, called the thylakoid membrane, that forms long folds within the organelle.

questions.Question: It consists of an aqueous ground substance containing a variety of cell organelles and other inclusions such as wastes and storage products.
questions.solution: Solution:		Cytoplasm consists of an aqueous ground substance, the cytosol, containing a variety of cell organelles and other inclusions such as insoluble waste and storage products (starch, glycogen, lipid, etc.)

questions.Question: The study of structures of organisms, their cells and their organelles at molecular level is known as
questions.solution: Solution:		Study of cell structure and function is called cell biology. Cell biology is a branch of biology that studies cells, their physiological properties, their structure, the organelles they contain, interactions with their environment, their life cycle, division, death and cell function.

questions.Question: Virus range in size from
questions.solution: Solution:		A virus is an infectious agent of small size and simple composition that can multiply only in living cells of animals, plants, or bacteria. They range in size from about 20 to 300 nanometres in diameter.

questions.Question: Virus was discovered by
questions.solution: Solution:		Two scientists contributed to the discovery of the first virus, Tobacco mosaic virus. Ivanoski reported in 1892 that extracts from infected leaves were still infectious after filtration through a Chamberland filter-candle.

questions.Question: The study of microorganisms is termed as
questions.solution: Solution:		Technically a microorganism or microbe is an organism that is microscopic. The study of microorganisms is called microbiology.

questions.Question: Entamoeba Histolytica is a
questions.solution: Solution:		Entamoeba histolytica is a protozoan parasite that accounts for an estimated 100,000 annual deaths globally.

questions.Question: Amoeba belongs to which group
questions.solution: Solution:		Amoeba belongs to which group protozoa.

questions.Question: Photosynthesis occurs in
questions.solution: Solution:		In plants, photosynthesis takes place in chloroplasts, which contain the chlorophyll. Chloroplasts are surrounded by a double membrane and contain a third inner membrane, called the thylakoid membrane, that forms long folds within the organelle.

questions.Question: Sulphur Dioxide pollution is indicated by an excessive growth of which of the following?
questions.solution: Solution:		If air is polluted with sulphur dioxide, then lichens will die in that particular environment. Since the era of industrialization, many species of lichens have gone extinct. Due to this property, lichens are considered to be the indicators of the air pollution.

questions.Question: Food wrapped in news paper is likely to get contaminated by
questions.solution: Solution:		Food wrapped in newspaper is likely to get contaminated with lead.

questions.Question: What is full form of BOD?
questions.solution: Solution:		Biological Oxygen Demand is full form of BOD.

questions.Question: The non-biotic pollutant of underground water is
questions.solution: Solution:		The non-biotic pollutant of underground water is arsenic.

questions.Question: Which of the following organelles contain enzymes that have digestive action?
questions.solution: Solution:		Lysosomes are membrane-enclosed organelles that contain an array of enzymes capable of breaking down all types of biological polymers—proteins, nucleic acids, carbohydrates, and lipids.

questions.Question: They are also concerned with the formation and storage of certain compounds secreted by the cell.
questions.solution: Solution:		Golgi Bodies are also concerned with the formation and storage of certain compounds secreted by the cell.

questions.Question: Carbon monoxide has ________ greater affinity for haemoglobin as compared to oxygen.
questions.solution: Solution:		Carbon monoxide has 210 times greater affinity for haemoglobin than oxygen.

questions.Question: Sphygmomanometer measures the blood pressure in the
questions.solution: Solution:		A sphygmomanometer has three parts: a cuff that can be inflated with air, a pressure meter (manometer) for measuring air pressure in the cuff, and. a stethoscope for listening to the sound the blood makes as it flows through the brachial artery (the major artery found in your upper arm).

questions.Question: Which statement best describes arteries?
questions.optionA: They have thin walls and transport blood away from the heart
questions.optionB: They have thick walls and transport blood toward the heart
questions.optionC: They have thin walls and transport blood toward the heart
questions.optionD: They have thick walls and transport blood away from the heart
questions.solution: Solution:		They have thick walls and transport blood away from the heart.

questions.Question: In plants, chloroplasts are necessary for
questions.solution: Solution:		In plants and algae, which developed much later, photosynthesis occurs in a specialized intracellular organelle - the chloroplast.

questions.Question: In which of the following organelles does photosynthesis take place?
questions.solution: Solution:		Photosynthesis take place in chloroplast.

questions.Question: It is a heredity material and contains the genetic information which is passed on from one generation to another.
questions.solution: Solution:		DNA is a heredity material and contains the genetic information which is passed on from one generation to another.

questions.Question: Where is the genetic information of the cell stored?
questions.solution: Solution:		The genetic information of an organism is stored in DNA molecules.

questions.Question: Where does protein synthesis take place in a cell?
questions.solution: Solution:		Protein synthesis takes place in ribosomes of a cell.

questions.Question: Name the part of neuron where information is acquired.
questions.solution: Solution:		The part of neuron where the information is acquired is ends of dendrites.

questions.Question: The basic unit of the nervous system is the
questions.solution: Solution:		The basic unit of the nervous system is a nerve cell, or neuron. The human brain contains about 100 billion neurons.

questions.Question: The weight of the brain in the total weight of the body is about
questions.solution: Solution:		The adult human brain weighs about 3 pounds (1,300-1,400 g). The adult human brain is about 2 % of the total body weight. The average human brain is 140 mm wide. So, the correct answer is 2%.

questions.Question: Cerebrum is located in which part of brain?
questions.solution: Solution:		Cerebrum is located in fore front of brain.

questions.Question: The smallest structural and functional unit of nervous system is
questions.solution: Solution:		The smallest functional unit of the nervous system is the neuron. Neurons are specialized cells that send out neurotransmitters to other neurons.

questions.Question: A typical chromosome has two parts a centrifuge and ________
questions.solution: Solution:		A typical chromosome has two parts a centrifuge and Centrosome.

questions.Question: How does a Unicellular Organism reproduce?
questions.solution: Solution:		In unicellular eukaryotes, reproduction can occur by mitosis and cytokinesis—the other form of cell division.

questions.Question: Healing of wounds is dependent upon the ________ division of underlying cells.
questions.solution: Solution:		Healing of wounds is dependent upon the mitotic division of underlying cells.

questions.Question: It is formed by a repeating nucleosome units, which are closely attached to each other to a continuous fibre.
questions.solution: Solution:		Chromatin is formed by a repeating nucleosome units, which are closely attached to each other to a continuous fibre.

questions.Question: It is the site of chromosome attachment to the fibres of spindle.
questions.solution: Solution:		The centromere is the part of a chromosome where the sister chromatids are linked together during the cell division. In mitosis, spindle fibres attach to the centromere via the kinetochore. Centromeres were first defined as genetic loci that direct the behaviour of chromosomes.

questions.Question: Which statement regarding the mammalian heart is correct?
questions.optionA: Blood is pumped from the heart via the atria
questions.optionB: Oxygen-loaded blood moves only through the right side of the heart
questions.optionC: When the right atrium contracts, it forces blood into the left atrium
questions.optionD: In the adult heart, blood in the right chambers of the heart cannot enter the left chambers without passing through the lungs
questions.solution: Solution:		In the adult heart, blood in the right chambers of the heart cannot enter the left chambers without passing through the lungs.

questions.Question: An individual whose blood type is B may in an emergency, donate blood to a person whose blood type is
questions.solution: Solution:		An individual whose blood type is B may in an emergency, donate blood to a person whose blood type is AB or B.

questions.Question: Which of the following carries oxygen to various parts of human body?
questions.solution: Solution:		Hemoglobin is the protein inside red blood cells that carries oxygen to various parts of human body.

questions.Question: Instrument used to measure blood pressure is
questions.solution: Solution:		You can measure your blood pressure on your own using a digital blood pressure monitor for automated readings or an instrument called a sphygmomanometer for manual readings.

questions.Question: Lymph carries digested and absorbed fat from ________ .
questions.solution: Solution:		Lymph carries digested and absorbed fat from intestine and drains excess fluid from extra cellular space back into the blood.

questions.Question: They are probably the simplest and the smallest living organisms possessing cellular organisation.
questions.solution: Solution:		Bacteria are probably the simplest and the smallest living organisms possessing cellular organisation.

questions.Question: Sexual reproduction in Algae that takes place through fusion of two dissimilar size gametes is called
questions.solution: Solution:		Anisogamy (also called heterogamy) is the form of sexual reproduction that involves the union or fusion of two gametes, which differ in size and/or form.

questions.Question: Floridian starch is characteristic energy storage material of which algae?
questions.solution: Solution:		The floridian starch is reserve food materials in the red algae or the members of class Rhodophytae. It is a characteristic feature of this group.

questions.Question: Which of the following does not have any enzymes in its cells?
questions.solution: Solution:		Virus is not a cell; it remains just in the form of a genetic material or encapsulated on outside with a protein capsid. It generally injects its genetic material into host cells wherein the viral proteins get synthesised.

questions.Question: Statement which is true about bacteria ?
questions.optionB: Most of them are heterotrophs but some are autotrophs
questions.solution: Solution:		Most of the bacteria are heterotrophs but some are autotrophs.

questions.Question: Where the mature sperm are produced?
questions.solution: Solution:		The structure on top of the seminiferous tubules in the testes is the epididymis. The sperm migrate from of the seminiferous tubules to the epididymis. Within the epididymis, the sperm mature while they are stored in this structure.

questions.Question: During rainy season wooden doors are difficult to open or closure because of ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Imbibition is a process in which the biological colloidal substances absorb water and show swelling and increase in volume. This happens when the wood of doors and window absorb water and swell during rainy season and cause problems as these do not fit in the frame and do not get closed.

questions.Question: Which statement concerning the diagnosis of ADHD is true?
questions.optionA: Boys are more likely to be diagnosed with ADHD than girls
questions.optionC: About 20 percent of school-age children are diagnosed with ADHD
questions.optionD: Racial minority status is a good predictor of being diagnosed with ADHD
questions.solution: Solution:		Boys are more likely to be diagnosed with ADHD than girls. Racial minority status is a good predictor of being diagnosed with ADHD.

questions.Question: According to Erikson, the goal of adolescence is to
questions.solution: Solution:		Identity versus confusion is the fifth stage of ego according to psychologist Erik Erikson's theory of psychosocial development. This stage occurs during adolescence between the ages of approximately 12 and 18. During this stage, adolescents explore their independence and develop a sense of self.

questions.Question: Which one of the following weeds is effective in controlling water pollution caused by industrial effluents?
questions.solution: Solution:		Parthenium is effective in controlling water pollution caused by industrial effluents.

questions.Question: Movement of cell against concentration gradient is called
questions.solution: Solution:		Active transport, this is the only transport method that can move species against their concentration gradient (from low to high concentration). Facilitated diffusion only moves species down their concentration gradient from high to low concentration.

questions.Question: Photosynthesis generally takes place in which parts of the plant?
questions.optionA: Leaf and other chloroplast bearing parts
questions.solution: Solution:		In plants, the process of photosynthesis takes place in the mesophyll of the leaves, inside the chloroplasts. Chloroplasts contain disc-shaped structures called thylakoids, which contain the pigment chlorophyll.

questions.Question:
Most fish do not sink in water because of the presence of:
I. swim bladder
II. air bladder
III. air sacs
IV. air in spongy bones
questions.optionD: I, II, III and IV are correct
questions.solution: Solution:		Fishes have a swim bladder or air bladder which helps them to remain buoyant without sinking in water. They are present in the body cavity.

questions.Question: Plants synthesis protein from
questions.solution: Solution:		We know that, proteins are polymers of amino acids. So, plants are also used to synthesise protein from amino acids. Hence, plants synthesis protein from amino acids in the presence of ATP by specific synthetases.

questions.Question: Plants absorb dissolved nitrates from soil and convert them into
questions.solution: Solution:		The plant cells absorb nitrates from the soil and convert them into ammonia which ultimately reduced to ammonium ions (NH4+). These ammonium ions are then combined with organic compounds to form amino acids such as glutamine i.e., free nitrogen. This process of conversion is known as nitrogen fixation.

questions.Question: The plant body not differentiated into root, shoot and stem is termed as
questions.solution: Solution:		The plant body not differentiated into root, shoot and stem is termed as thallus.

questions.Question: Capitulum is also given another name
questions.solution: Solution:		Capitulum is also given another name called head.

questions.Question: In all arthropods,the body is covered with a chittinous cuticle which is secreted by the
questions.solution: Solution:		In all arthropods,the body is covered with a chittinous cuticle which is secreted by the epidermis.

questions.Question: Scientist who is known as father of botany.
questions.solution: Solution:		When Aristotle fled Athens, Theophrastus took over as head of the Lyceum. Theophrastus presided over the Peripatetic school for thirty-six years, during which time the school flourished greatly. He is often considered the father of botany for his works on plants.

questions.Question: In which of the following chlorophyll does not exist?
questions.solution: Solution:		Algae, Bryophytes and Pteridophytes are true plants and contain chlorophyll . While fungi have characteristics that put this kingdom more close to animals, one of the features is that all fungi are heterotrophs and contain no chlorophyll.

questions.Question: Which of the following is a fresh water sponge?
questions.solution: Solution:		Spongilla is a genus of fresh water sponges, found in lakes and slow streams. Sponges of the genus Spongilla attach themselves to rocks and logs and filter the water for various small aquatic organisms. It has monaxons spicules, which are like single pointed shaft. These spicules are present in large numbers.

questions.Question: The kingdom Protista is primarily made up of organisms that are
questions.solution: Solution:		All single-celled eukaryotes are placed under Protista. This kingdom forms a link with others dealing with plants, animals and fungi.

questions.Question: Marsupial Kangaroo is
questions.solution: Solution:		The kangaroo is a marsupial from the family Macropodidae. In common use the term is used to describe the largest species from this family, the red kangaroo, as well as the antilopine kangaroo, eastern grey kangaroo, and western grey kangaroo.

questions.Question: Which one of the following has a bilateral symmetry in its body organization?
questions.solution: Solution:		Asterias has bilateral symmetry only at larval stagebut fivefold symmetry (pentamerism, a special type of radial symmetry) as adults.Nereis do not possess any symmetry elements in their body organisation.

questions.Question: Branch of biology which deals with the study of identification, nomenclature and classification of organisms is
questions.solution: Solution:		Taxonomy is that branch of biology dealing with the identification and naming of organisms.

questions.Question: Gametes are produced by the process of
questions.solution: Solution:		Meiosis is a type of cell division that reduces the number of chromosomes in the parent cell by half and produces four gamete cells. This process is required to produce egg and sperm cells for sexual reproduction.

questions.Question: In each pollen sacs a large number of pollens or microspores are produced by
questions.solution: Solution:		In a process called microsporogenesis, four haploid microspores are produced from each diploid sporogenous cell (microsporocyte, pollen mother cell or meiocyte), after meiotic division. After the formation of the four microspores, which are contained by callose walls, the development of the pollen grain walls begins.

questions.Question: Synapsis occurs during
questions.solution: Solution:		Synapsis (also called syndesis) is the pairing of two homologous chromosomes that occurs during meiosis.

questions.Question: Which cell division of phase of cell division maintains the chromosomes number constant from generation to generation?
questions.solution: Solution:		In summary, meiosis is a form of cell division that results in half the normal number of chromosomes in sex cells, or gametes, thus maintaining the chromosome number of a species from generation to generation.

questions.Question: Mitosis cannot take place bacteria because they lack ________
questions.solution: Solution:		There are many differences between prokaryotic and eukaryotic cell division. Bacteria have a single, circular DNA chromosome and no nucleus. Therefore, mitosis is not necessary in bacterial cell division.

questions.Question: Salts and sugars works to preserve foods by creating a
questions.solution: Solution:		Salts and sugars work to preserve foods by creating a hypertonic environment.

questions.Question: Movement of cell against concentration gradient is called
questions.solution: Solution:		During active transport, substances move against the concentration gradient, from an area of low concentration to an area of high concentration. This process is “active” because it requires the use of energy (usually in the form of ATP). It is the opposite of passive transport.

questions.Question: Which one among the following Indian scientist proposed a theory for long distance transport of water in plants?
questions.solution: Solution:		N.S. Parihar proposed a theory for long distance transport of water in plants.

questions.Question: The movement of materials across the cell membrane with the help of biological energy provided by ATP is called
questions.solution: Solution:		Primary active transport moves ions across a membrane and creates a difference in charge across that membrane. The primary active transport system uses ATP to move a substance, such as an ion, into the cell, and often at the same time, a second substance is moved out of the cell.

questions.Question: Which process requires no energy from the cell?
questions.solution: Solution:		Passive transport requires no energy from the cell. Examples include the diffusion of oxygen and carbon dioxide, osmosis of water, and facilitated diffusion.

questions.Question: Pair of ribs found in man
questions.solution: Solution:		Pair of ribs found in man is 12.

questions.Question: Strongest bone of body is found in
questions.solution: Solution:		The femur bone is the longest and strongest bone in the body. Located in the thigh, it spans the hip and knee joints and helps maintain upright posture by supporting the skeleton

questions.Question: Smallest bone of human body is
questions.solution: Solution:		The 3 smallest bones in the human body--malleus, incus, and stapes--are located in the middle ear. At 3 x 5 mm in size, the stapes is the smallest bone in the human body.

questions.Question: Study of bone is called
questions.solution: Solution:		A subdiscipline of anatomy, anthropology, and paleontology, osteology is a detailed study of the structure of bones, skeletal elements, teeth, microbone morphology, function, disease, pathology, the process of ossification (from cartilaginous molds), and the resistance and hardness of bones (biophysics).

questions.Question: Tissue that connects muscle to bone
questions.solution: Solution:		A tendon is a fibrous connective tissue which attaches muscle to bone. Tendons may also attach muscles to structures such as the eyeball.

questions.Question: Red snow causing alga is
questions.solution: Solution:		It is the algae that give the snow its red tinge. This alga species, Chlamydomonas nivalis, exists in snow in the polar and glacial regions, and carries a red pigment to keep itself warm .

questions.Question: Cork-screw shaped bacteria are known as
questions.solution: Solution:		 The bacteria which are twisted, helical or spiral in shape and called spirilla.

questions.Question: Ringworm is a disease caused by
questions.solution: Solution:		Ringworm is a common infection of the skin and nails that is caused by fungus. The infection is called “ringworm” because it can cause an itchy, red, circular rash.

questions.Question: Rod shaped bacteria are known as
questions.solution: Solution:		Bacilli are rod-shaped bacteria. Bacilli all divide in one plane producing a bacillus, streptobacillus, or coccobacillus arrangement.

questions.Question: Virus is not regarded as a cell, because
questions.optionA: It is anactive unless it finds a host to multiply
questions.optionB: Most of the cellular activity is absent
questions.optionC: The genetic material does not replicate on its own
questions.solution: Solution:		Viruses are not made out of cells, they can't keep themselves in a stable state, they don't grow, and they can't make their own energy. Even though they definitely replicate and adapt to their environment, viruses are more like androids than real living organisms.

questions.Question: Study of parasitic organism is called
questions.solution: Solution:		Medical parasitology traditionally has included the study of three major groups of animals: parasitic protozoa, parasitic helminths (worms), and those arthropods that directly cause disease or act as vectors of various pathogens.

questions.Question: The study of relation of animals and plants to their surroundings is called ________
questions.solution: Solution:		Ecology term was coined by Ernst Heckel. It studies the interaction of living beings with their environment.

questions.Question: Amarbel is an example of
questions.solution: Solution:		Amarbel is an example of the parasite. Cuscuta reflexa is the botanical name for the amarbel. It is also known as giant dodder. It grows in a creative manner over host plants and this species has the capability of producing numerous branches within a short period of time.

questions.Question: When we consume the goat or sheep beef then we are
questions.solution: Solution:		Goats, sheep and other herbivores are the primary consumers or heterotrophs. Any animal that eats primary consumers are the secondary consumers or heterotrophs.

questions.Question: Branch of biology in which we study about relationship between living and their environment.
questions.solution: Solution:		Ecology is the branch of biology that explains the relationship between organisms and their environments.

questions.Question: Kelps are obtained from
questions.solution: Solution:		Kelps is obtained from marine brown algae.

questions.Question: Blue green algae possess chlorophlyll along with a pigment known as
questions.solution: Solution:		Blue-green Algae, now known as Cyanobacteria, are named for the blue-green pigment phycocyanin which along with chlorophyll a gives them a blue-green appearance. In the marine environment some Cyanobacteria trap and bind together sediment while they simultaneously precipitate carbonate.

questions.Question: A cell wall material present only in blue green algae and bacteria is
questions.solution: Solution:		There are many similarities between cyanobacterium and bacterium. They both posses saparophytic mode of life. They both lack true cell organelles. They both posses nucleoid instead of true nucleus. In both bacteria and blue green algae, the cell wall is made up of muramic acid and diaminopimelic acid. Thus, the correct answer is 'Muramic acid.'

questions.Question: Liver fluke is parasite in the liver of
questions.solution: Solution:		A liver fluke is a parasitic worm. Infections in humans usually occur after eating contaminated raw or undercooked freshwater fish or watercress. After liver flukes have been ingested, they travel from your intestines to your bile ducts in your liver where they then live and grow. Hence D is the correct answer.

questions.Question: Most bacteria reproduce by
questions.solution: Solution:		Most bacteria reproduce by binary fission.

questions.Question: When a foreign body inter into blood circulatory system the reaction is started by
questions.solution: Solution:		When a foreign body inter into blood circulatory system the reaction is started by white blood cells.

questions.Question: How many chambers does a human heart have?
questions.solution: Solution:		Human heart has 4 chambers.

questions.Question: The muscle which separate the right side and left side of heart is known as
questions.solution: Solution:		A wall of muscle called the septum separates the left and right atria and the left and right ventricles.

questions.Question: What is the pH value range of human blood?
questions.solution: Solution:		Blood is normally slightly basic, with a normal pH range of about 7.35 to 7.45. Usually the body maintains the pH of blood close to 7.40.

questions.Question: The main function of hemoglobin is
questions.solution: Solution:		About 70 percent of your body's iron is found in the red blood cells of your blood called hemoglobin and in muscle cells called myoglobin. Hemoglobin is essential for transferring oxygen in your blood from the lungs to the tissues.

questions.Question: Which vitamin is necessary for blood clotting?
questions.solution: Solution:		Vitamin K is necessary for blood clotting.

questions.Question: Most of the enzymes are
questions.solution: Solution:		Structurally, the vast majority of enzymes are proteins. Also RNA molecules have catalytic activity (ribozymes). Coenzymes are small nonprotein molecules that are associated to some enzymes.

questions.Question: The disease Rickets is caused by the deficiency of
questions.solution: Solution:		The most common cause of rickets is a lack of vitamin D or calcium in a child's diet.

questions.Question: Which vitamin also act as coenzymes?
questions.solution: Solution:		Vitamin B12 act as coenzymes.

questions.Question: Amoeba is ________ in nutrition
questions.solution: Solution:		Amoeba takes its nutrition through a process called phagocytosis where the entire organism swallows the food it plans on eating up. The mode through which an amoeba engulfs nutrition is known as holozoic nutrition.

questions.Question: The total number of pairs of Peripheral nerves in man are
questions.solution: Solution:		The total number of pairs of Peripheral nerves in man are 43.

questions.Question: Medulla oblongata is a part of which of the following?
questions.solution: Solution:		Medulla oblongata is a part of brain.

questions.Question: Acetylcholine is
questions.solution: Solution:		Acetylcholine is an organic chemical that functions in the brain and body of many types of animals as a neurotransmitter—a chemical message released by nerve cells to send signals to other cells, such as neurons, muscle cells and gland cells.

questions.Question: The pair of spinal nerves in man are
questions.solution: Solution:		Spinal nerve, in vertebrates, any one of many paired peripheral nerves that arise from the spinal cord. In humans there are 31 pairs of spinal nerve.

questions.Question: How many bones are there in the human cranium?
questions.solution: Solution:		There are 8 bones in the human cranium.

questions.Question: ________ helps the eye to adjust the focal length of the lens.
questions.solution: Solution:		Ciliary muscles help in changing the focal length of the eye lens.

questions.Question: Eustachian Tube is located in which part of human body?
questions.solution: Solution:		The eustachian tube is a canal that connects the middle ear to the nasopharynx, which consists of the upper throat and the back of the nasal cavity. It controls the pressure within the middle ear, making it equal with the air pressure outside the body.

questions.Question: Glomerulus and Bowman's capsule constitute
questions.solution: Solution:		Glomerulus and Bowman's capsule constitute Malpighian tubule.

questions.Question: The kidneys are stimulated to produce renin
questions.optionA: When the pH of the urine decreases
questions.optionB: When the specific gravity of urine rises above 1.10
questions.optionC: When the peritubular capillaries are dilated
questions.optionD: By a decrease in the blood pressure
questions.solution: Solution:		The secretion of renin is stimulated by the following three factors: When a fall in arterial blood pressure is detected by pressure sensitive receptors (baroreceptors) in the arterial vessels. When a decrease in sodium chloride (salt) is detected in the kidney by the macula densa in the juxtaglomerular apparatus.

questions.Question: In mammals, an important role of excretion is played by ________
questions.solution: Solution:		The kidneys are bean-shaped organs that serve several excretory roles apart from the essential regulatory roles in mammals. They remove from the blood the nitrogenous wastes such as urea, as well as salts and excess water, and excrete them in the form of urine. In producing urine, the kidneys excrete nitrogenous wastes such as urea and ammonium.

questions.Question: Antigen is present in
questions.solution: Solution:		Antigen is present in red blood cells.

questions.Question: Agro forestry is
questions.optionC: Growing of tree with cultivation of crop in the same field
questions.solution: Solution:		Agroforestry is the management and integration of trees, crops and/or livestock on the same plot of land and can be an integral component of productive agriculture. It may include existing native forests and forests established by landholders.

questions.Question: Agrostology is the study of
questions.solution: Solution:		Agrostology, the branch of botany concerned with the study of grasses, especially their classification.

questions.Question: The primary goal of conservation biology is to
questions.optionB: Estimate the total number of species that exist
questions.optionC: Integrate human culture back into nature
questions.solution: Solution:		As a distinct scientific field, conservation biology is an integrated, multidisciplinary subject that developed in response to the challenge of preserving populations, species, ecosystems, and biological interactions. The main aim of conservation biology is to ensure the long-term preservation of biodiversity.

questions.Question: Distribution of plant on the various part of earth
questions.solution: Solution:		Phytogeography or botanical geography is the branch of biogeography that is concerned with the geographic distribution of plant species and their influence on the earth's surface.

questions.Question: Study of pulse and arterial blood pressure is called
questions.solution: Solution:		Study of pulse and arterial blood pressure is called Sphygmology.

questions.Question: Longest artery found in the body of human is
questions.solution: Solution:		Longest artery found in the body of human is Aorta.

questions.Question: Oxygen in our blood is transported by a protein named
questions.solution: Solution:		Hemoglobin, or Hb, is a protein molecule found in red blood cells (erythrocytes) made of four subunits: two alpha subunits and two beta subunits.

questions.Question: Who was the discoverer of human blood groups ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Landsteiner discovered human blood groups.

questions.Question: Study of blood is called
questions.solution: Solution:		Hematology is the study of blood and blood disorders.

questions.Question: The colour of Hemoglobin is
questions.solution: Solution:		The colour of Hemoglobin is red.

questions.Question: The elastic vessels which transport blood to the heart is known as
questions.solution: Solution:		The elastic vessels which transport blood to the heart is known as veins.

questions.Question: The elastic vessels which transport blood from the heart is known as
questions.solution: Solution:		The elastic vessels which transport blood from the heart is known as arteries.

questions.Question: White blood cell act
questions.optionD: As a medium for oxygen transport from lung to tissues
questions.solution: Solution:		White blood cell, also called leukocyte or white corpuscle, a cellular component of the blood that lacks hemoglobin, has a nucleus, is capable of motility, and defends the body against infection and disease by ingesting foreign materials and cellular debris, by destroying infectious agents and cancer cells.

questions.Question: The top chambers of human heart are called
questions.solution: Solution:		The top chambers of human heart are called atrium.

questions.Question: The plants which live in soil, but depends on water for reproduction is known as
questions.solution: Solution:		Bryophytes include the various mosses and liverworts that are found commonly growing in moist shaded areas in the hills. Bryophytes are also called amphibians of the plant kingdom because these plants can live in soil but are dependent on water for sexual reproduction.

questions.Question: The branch of botany which deals with identification, nomenclature and classification of an organism is known as
questions.solution: Solution:		The 'branch of botany' which deals with the classification 'nomenclature and identification' is taxonomy.

questions.Question: Who is known as the father of Taxonomy?
questions.solution: Solution:		Carolus Linnaeus is known as the father of Taxonomy.

questions.Question: Bat can fly in dark because they
questions.solution: Solution:		Bats can fly in dark because they produce ultrasonic waves. The bats possess very poor vision. It cannot see in dark. It produces ultrasonic waves which strike with the obstacles present on its way. The bat receives its echo and changes its path to protect itself from collision.

questions.Question: The term "taxon" is first used by
questions.solution: Solution:		The term taxon was first used in 1926 by Adolf Meyer-Abich for animal groups, as a backformation from the word Taxonomy.

questions.Question: Sponges belong to the phylum
