questions.solution: Solution:		The phylum of sponges (Porifera) contains sessile organisms, most of which live in marine habitats. The few species of freshwaters all belong to the class of demosponges (Demospongiae).

questions.Question: Study of algae is called
questions.solution: Solution:		Phycology, also called algology, the study of algae, a large heterogeneous group of chiefly aquatic plants ranging in size from microscopic forms to species as large as shrubs or trees. The discipline is of immediate interest to humans because of algae's importance in ecology.

questions.Question: Study of butterfly is
questions.solution: Solution:		Study of butterfly is Lapidopterology.

questions.Question: Which one of the following is the largest phylum in the animal kingdom?
questions.solution: Solution:		Arthropod, (phylum Arthropoda), any member of the phylum Arthropoda, the largest phylum in the animal kingdom, which includes such familiar forms as lobsters, crabs, spiders, mites, insects, centipedes, and millipedes.

questions.Question: When a Cuttlefish is described as a Molluscs, it is at which level of classification?
questions.solution: Solution:		Cuttlefish is at mollusc level of classification.

questions.Question: Metal present in Haemoglobin
questions.solution: Solution:		The heme group (a component of the hemoglobin protein) is a metal complex, with iron as the central metal atom, that can bind or release molecular oxygen.

questions.Question: The right portion of human heart receives ________ blood.
questions.solution: Solution:		The right portion of human heart receives impure blood.

questions.Question: Arteries supplying blood to the heart are called
questions.solution: Solution:		Coronary arteries supply blood to the heart muscle. Like all other tissues in the body, the heart muscle needs oxygen-rich blood to function. Also, oxygen-depleted blood must be carried away. The coronary arteries wrap around the outside of the heart.

questions.Question: The plasma of the blood contains which among the following constituents?I. ProteinsII. SaltsIII. Hormones
questions.solution: Solution:		The plasma of the blood contains proteins, salts and hormones.

questions.Question: Antibodies is produced in the plasma of blood by
questions.solution: Solution:		Antibodies is produced in the plasma of blood by lymphocytes.

questions.Question: Who first studied the process of cell division in animals?
questions.solution: Solution:		Walther Fleming first studied the process of cell division in animals.

questions.Question: Which division provides a means of transmitting unchange information to the daughter cells?
questions.solution: Solution:		Mitosis allows for cells to produce identical copies of themselves, which means the genetic material is duplicated from parent to daughter cells.

questions.Question: Which of the following does not occur during mitosis?
questions.solution: Solution:		Replication of DNA does not occur in mitosis. Replication of DNA occurs during S phase, an entirely different phase of cell division.

questions.Question: Meiosis II is similar to mitosis in that
questions.solution: Solution:		Meiosis 2 is similar to mitosis because it separates the chromosomes to have sister chromatids in each cell. In both processes, you are separating the chromosome and dividing the cell to make 2 cells out of 1.

questions.Question: In animal cells, cell division starts with the division of
questions.solution: Solution:		In animal cells, cell division starts with the division of centrioles.

questions.Question: The site of RBC formation in human body is
questions.solution: Solution:		Red blood cells are formed in the red bone marrow of bones. Stem cells in the red bone marrow called hemocytoblasts give rise to all of the formed elements in blood.

questions.Question: Important component that helps in clotting of the blood is called ________ .
questions.solution: Solution:		The main job of platelets, or thrombocytes, is blood clotting. Platelets are much smaller in size than the other blood cells. They group together to form clumps, or a plug, in the hole of a vessel to stop bleeding.

questions.Question: The valve present between left auricle and left ventricle is
questions.solution: Solution:		The valve present between left auricle and left ventricle is mitral valve.

questions.Question: Function of heart in human body is
questions.solution: Solution:		Function of heart in human body is work like pumping machines.

questions.Question: Function of haemoglobin is
questions.optionC: To check the loss of blood
questions.solution: Solution:		Hemoglobin is essential for transferring oxygen in your blood from the lungs to the tissues. Myoglobin, in muscle cells, accepts, stores, transports and releases oxygen.

questions.Question: The study of structure and functions of cells is termed as
questions.solution: Solution:		Cell biology is the study of cell structure and function, and it revolves around the concept that the cell is the fundamental unit of life.

questions.Question: Where in the cell are chromosomes located?
questions.solution: Solution:		Chromosomes are thread-like structures located inside the nucleus of animal and plant cells. Each chromosome is made of protein and a single molecule of deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA).

questions.Question: Which are called the factory of protein synthesis?
questions.solution: Solution:		Ribosomes are known as the protein factory of the cell. As they synthesizes the proteins by gathering and assembling amino acids into protein chains.

questions.Question: Who is known as father of Biology?
questions.solution: Solution:		Development as a sequential knowledge of biology took place in the era of the famous Greek philosopher Aristotle (384- 322 B.C.). He revealed his thoughts about various aspects of the life of plants and animals. Therefore, Aristotle is called as the Father of Biology.

questions.Question: Who is known as father of Biology
questions.solution: No explanation is given for this questionLet's Discuss on Board

questions.Question: Saliva secreted from mouth digest
questions.solution: Solution:		Saliva contains special enzymes that help digest the starches in your food. An enzyme called amylase breaks down starches (complex carbohydrates) into sugars, which your body can more easily absorb. Saliva also contains an enzyme called lingual lipase, which breaks down fats.

questions.Question: Which organ has finger like outgrowths which are called as Villi (Singular Villus)?
questions.solution: Solution:		The internal walls of the small intestine are covered in finger-like tissue called villi. Each of these villi is covered in even smaller finger-like structures called microvilli.

questions.Question: A large number of bacteria in our digestive system, especially in the ________ and large intestine are important in completing digestive processes.
questions.solution: Solution:		A large number of bacteria in our digestive system, especially in the small intestine and large intestine are important in completing digestive processes.

questions.Question: Pepsin is an enzyme that digests ________ .
questions.solution: Solution:		Pepsin is a stomach enzyme that serves to digest proteins found in ingested food. Gastric chief cells secrete pepsin as an inactive zymogen called pepsinogen. Parietal cells within the stomach lining secrete hydrochloric acid that lowers the pH of the stomach.

questions.Question: Which among the following is used to treat indigestion?
questions.solution: Solution:		Antacid is used to treat indigestion.

questions.Question: Which organelle performs cellular respiration?
questions.solution: No explanation is given for this questionLet's Discuss on Board

questions.Question: The great contribution of Schwan was
questions.solution: Solution:		The great contribution of Schwan was cell theory.

questions.Question: What organelle carries out photosynthesis?
questions.solution: Solution:		Chloroplasts are organelles found in plant cells and eukaryotic algae that conduct photosynthesis. Chloroplasts absorb sunlight and use it in conjunction with water and carbon dioxide gas to produce food for the plant.

questions.Question: Which organelles are unique to plant cells?
questions.solution: Solution:		Plant cells have certain distinguishing features, including chloroplasts, cell walls, and intracellular vacuoles. Photosynthesis takes place in chloroplasts; cell walls allow plants to have strong, upright structures; and vacuoles help regulate how cells handle water and storage of other molecules.

questions.Question: Membrane bound organelles are not found in the cells of
questions.solution: Solution:		Membrane bound organelles are not found in the cells of prokaryotes whereas eukaryotes have nucleus and membrane bound organelles.

questions.Question: In cross section each centriole consists of a cylindrical array of how many microtubules?
questions.solution: Solution:		Centrioles are built from a cylindrical array of 9 microtubules, each of which has attached to it 2 partial microtubules.

questions.Question: Which phase's intiation is indicated by the appearance of the chromosomes as thin threads in the nucleus?
questions.solution: Solution:		During prophase chromosomes appear as thin threads in the nucleus.

questions.Question: In which of these mitosis is missing and the cell divided by binary fission?
questions.solution: Solution:		Mitosis is missing and the cell is divided by binary fission in prokaryotes.

questions.Question: Which event occurs during interphase?
questions.solution: Solution:		During interphase, the cell grows and the nuclear DNA is duplicated.

questions.Question: The stage of mitosis at which chromatids separate as independent chromosomes is the
questions.solution: Solution:		The sister chromatids are pairs of identical copies of DNA joined at a point called the centromere. During anaphase, each pair of chromosomes is separated into two identical, independent chromosomes. The chromosomes are separated by a structure called the mitotic spindle.

questions.Question: A species inhabiting different geographical areas is known as
questions.solution: Solution:		A species inhabiting different geographical areas is known as allopatric species. This geographical isolation prevents mating between the two organism of same species.

questions.Question: Lichen is a composite combination of two organisms.
questions.solution: Solution:		A lichen is a composite organism that emerges from algae or cyanobacteria living among the filaments (hyphae) of the fungi in a mutually beneficial symbiotic relationship. The fungi benefit from the carbohydrates produced by the algae or cyanobacteria via photosynthesis.

questions.Question: Nitrogen Fixation is carried out primarily by
questions.solution: Solution:		Nitrogen fixation is carried out naturally in soil by microorganisms termed diazotrophs that include bacteria such as Azotobacter and archaea. Some nitrogen-fixing bacteria have symbiotic relationships with plant groups, especially legumes.

questions.Question: Organisms that depend only on raw plant products are said to be
questions.solution: Solution:		Organisms that depend only on raw plant products are said to be herbivorous.

questions.Question: The scientific study of how organisms interact with their environment is called
questions.solution: Solution:		The scientific study of how organisms interact with their environment is called Ecology.

questions.Question: In 1910, who proved the idea of W.S.Sutton that genes are located on chromosomes?
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1910, T.H.Morgan proved the idea of W.S.Sutton that genes are located on chromosomes.

questions.Question: Different forms of genes are called
questions.solution: Solution:		An allele is a variant form of a gene. Some genes have a variety of different forms, which are located at the same position, or genetic locus, on a chromosome.

questions.Question: Fruitfly has
questions.solution: Solution:		Fruitfly has 8 chromosomes.

questions.Question: Which nitrogenous base is not found in dna?
questions.solution: Solution:		Uracil is present in RNA and binds to adenine whereas thymine is present in DNA and binds to adenine.

questions.Question: Gregor Johann Mendel worked on
questions.solution: Solution:		Gregor Johann Mendel worked on Garden pea.

questions.Question: Prokaryotic cells lack
questions.solution: Solution:		A prokaryotic cell is a cell which doesn't have an organized cellular structure. The membrane-bounded nucleus is absent and the genetic material is scattered directly in the cytoplasm. The membrane-bounded organelles are absent in a prokaryotic cell e.g., a bacterial cell.

questions.Question: The science related with the study of living is
questions.solution: Solution:		Biology is the science of life. Its name is derived from the Greek words "bios" (life) and "logos" (study).

questions.Question: Ribosomes are produced in the
questions.solution: Solution:		In bacterial cells, ribosomes are synthesized in the cytoplasm through the transcription of multiple ribosome gene operons. In eukaryotes, the process takes place both in the cell cytoplasm and in the nucleolus, which is a region within the cell nucleus.

questions.Question: Which of the following organelle is known as the 'Power House' of the cell?
questions.solution: Solution:		Mitochondria are tiny organelles inside cells that are involved in releasing energy from food. This process is known as cellular respiration. It is for this reason that mitochondria are often referred to as the powerhouses of the cell.

questions.Question: Smallest cell in human body is
questions.solution: Solution:		The sperm is the smallest cell in human biology, but also one of the most complex.

questions.Question: Which one among the following statements is correct?
questions.optionC: Except the pulmonary artery, all other arteries carry oxygenated blood
questions.optionD: Except the pulmonary vein, all other veins carry oxygenated blood
questions.solution: Solution:		Except the pulmonary artery, all other arteries carry oxygenated blood.

questions.Question: To complete one heart beat the time taken is
questions.solution: Solution:		To complete one heart beat the time taken is 0.8 second.

questions.Question: Pace maker is related with
questions.solution: Solution:		A pacemaker is a small device that's placed in the chest or abdomen to help control abnormal heart rhythms. This device uses electrical pulses to prompt the heart to beat at a normal rate.

questions.Question: PH of human blood is
questions.solution: Solution:		The pH scale, ranges from 0 (strongly acidic) to 14 (strongly basic or alkaline). A pH of 7.0, in the middle of this scale, is neutral. Blood is normally slightly basic, with a normal pH range of about 7.35 to 7.45.

questions.Question: PH value of human blood is
questions.solution: Solution:		PH value of human blood is 7.4.

questions.Question: The scientific study of livings is called
questions.solution: Solution:		The organised study of a topic or knowledge is known as science. The different fields of study are classified as the branches of science. The study of the living organisms is known as biology. This includes the details and all the study facts with respect to the living things like plants, animals and microbes.

questions.Question: They are present in the underground parts of the plants and stored food.
questions.solution: Solution:		Leucoplasts are present in the underground parts of the plants and stored food.

questions.Question: Which of the following groups is present in animal cells ?
questions.optionA: Mitochondria, Cell membrane, Cell wall, Cytoplasm
questions.solution: Solution:		Nucleus, Cell membrane, Mitochondria and Cytoplasm is present in animal cells.

questions.Question: What is the full form of DNA?
questions.solution: Solution:		The full form of DNA is Deoxyribonucleic Acid.

questions.Question: What is the full form of RNA?
questions.solution: Solution:		Ribonucleic acid is the full form of RNA.

questions.Question: Fusion of two gametes is called
questions.solution: Solution:		Fusion of two gametes is called fertilization.

questions.Question: Flowers in which polllination takes place by insect their pollen grains are ________
questions.solution: Solution:		Flowers in which pollination takes place by insect their pollen grains are rough and sticky.

questions.Question: Ornithology is the study of
questions.solution: Solution:		Ornithology, a branch of zoology dealing with the study of birds.

questions.Question: Pollination is best defined as
questions.optionA: Growth of pollen tube in ovule
questions.optionD: Transfer of pollen from anther to stigma
questions.solution: Solution:		Pollination can be best defined as the transfer of pollen from the male anther of a flower to the female stigma to produce new offspring.

questions.Question: Self pollination will lead to
questions.solution: Solution:		Self pollination will lead to inbreeding.

questions.Question: Jaundice in human beings is the result of
questions.solution: Solution:		Jaundice is caused by a buildup of bilirubin, a waste material, in the blood. An inflamed liver or obstructed bile duct can lead to jaundice, as well as other underlying conditions.

questions.Question: Which of the following can be a symptom of AIDS?
questions.solution: Solution:		As the virus continues to multiply and destroy your immune cells — the cells in your body that help fight off germs — you may develop mild infections or chronic signs and symptoms such as: Fever, Fatigue and Swollen lymph nodes.

questions.Question: Which one of the following is a hereditary disease?
questions.solution: Solution:		Haemophilia is a hereditary disease.

questions.Question: Malaria is more common in
questions.solution: Solution:		Malaria occurs in more than 100 countries and territories. About half of the world's population is at risk. Large areas of Africa and South Asia and parts of Central and South America, the Caribbean, Southeast Asia, the Middle East, and Oceania are considered areas where malaria transmission occurs.

questions.Question: Pathology is the branch of science which deal with the study of
questions.solution: Solution:		Pathology is a branch of medical science that involves the study and diagnosis of disease through the examination of surgically removed organs, tissues (biopsy samples), bodily fluids, and in some cases the whole body (autopsy).

questions.Question: Jellyfish belongs to which phylum?
questions.solution: Solution:		This jellyfish, a member of the phylum Cnidaria, can have tentacles up to 190 feet long (58 meters) and a bell almost 7 feet (2 meters) in diameter.

questions.Question: Which group of animals was the first to evolve to fly?
questions.solution: Solution:		Insects were the first to evolve to fly.

questions.Question: The skeleton secreting cells in poriferans are known as
questions.solution: Solution:		The spicules are secreted by specialized mesenchyme cells known as scleroblasts. Scleroblast secreting a calcareous spicule is called calcoblast while that producing a siliceous spicule is called silicoblast.

questions.Question: Which one is the basic unit of classification?
questions.solution: Solution:		Basic unit or smallest taxon of taxonomy/ classification is species. Species is a group of individuals that remain relatively constant in their characteristics; can be distinguished from other species and do not normally interbreed.

questions.Question: Which one of the following phylum is characterised by absence of true coelom?
questions.solution: Solution:		Nematodais characterised by absence of true coelom.

questions.Question: Oxygen crosses a plasma membrane by
questions.solution: Solution:		Oxygen crosses a plasma membrane by diffusion.

questions.Question: Which of the following is true of osmosis?
questions.optionA: It is a type of diffusion
questions.optionB: Movement is against water's concentration gradient
questions.solution: Solution:		All of the above statements are true about osmosis.

questions.Question: The water readily available to plants for absorption by roots is
questions.solution: Solution:		Capillary water is the water held by micropores of soil. This water is available for the plant because it gets trap in soil solution near the root of the plants. And some water is retained in mineral salts by chemical bonds but it does not increase the absorption capacity of roots. This is called chemically combined water. Thus the only water available for the plant is capillary water so the correct option is C.

questions.Question: The process of evaporation occurs from
questions.solution: Solution:		The process of evaporation occurs from leaf.

questions.Question: Which process requires cellular energy?
questions.solution: Solution:		In cellular biology, active transport is the movement of molecules across a cell membrane from a region of lower concentration to a region of higher concentration—against the concentration gradient. Active transport requires cellular energy to achieve this movement.

questions.Question: Two species occupying same or overlapping area are
questions.solution: Solution:		Two species occupying same or overlapping geographical areas are called as sympatric species. The species occupying distinct geographical areas are called as allopatric species.

questions.Question: The ecosystem of a pond is referred as
questions.solution: Solution:		A pond or lake ecosystem includes biotic (living) plants, animals and micro-organisms, as well as abiotic (nonliving) physical and chemical interactions. Pond and lake ecosystems are a prime example of lentic ecosystems. Lentic refers to stationary or relatively still water, from the Latin lentus, which means sluggish.

questions.Question: Which of the following systems in man is affected by the bite of cobra ?
questions.solution: Solution:		The venom of elapids, including sea snakes, kraits, cobras, king cobra, mambas, and many Australian species, contains toxins which attack the nervous system, causing neurotoxicity. The person may present with strange disturbances to their vision, including blurriness.

questions.Question: ________ is a thyroid hormone which controls the balance of calcium in the body.
questions.solution: Solution:		Calcitonin is a hormone that is produced in humans by the parafollicular cells (commonly known as C-cells) of the thyroid gland. Calcitonin is involved in helping to regulate levels of calcium and phosphate in the blood, opposing the action of parathyroid hormone.

questions.Question: Which of the following is known as master gland in man?
questions.solution: Solution:		The pituitary gland, which hangs by a thin stalk from the hypothalamus, is called the master gland of the body because it regulates the activity of the endocrine glands.

questions.Question: Pigmentation of skin is due to
questions.solution: Solution:		A common cause of hyperpigmentation is an excess production of melanin. Melanin is a pigment that gives skin its color. It's produced by skin cells called melanocytes.

questions.Question: Norepinephrine increases
questions.solution: Solution:		Together with adrenaline, norepinephrine increases heart rate and blood pumping from the heart. It also increases blood pressure and helps break down fat and increase blood sugar levels to provide more energy to the body.

questions.Question: Night blindness is cause by lack of which vitamin?
questions.solution: Solution:		Night blindness is caused by lack of vitamin A.

questions.Question: Monocot root differs from dicot root in having
questions.solution: Solution:		In dicot root, well developed pith is absent. In monocot root, well developed pith is present.

questions.Question: Radioactivity is a phenomenon of the spontaneous emission of
questions.solution: Solution:		Radioactivity is a phenomenon of the spontaneous emission of protons, electrons and gamma rays.

questions.Question: In how many parts is the human brain divided?
questions.solution: Solution:		All the parts of the brain work together, but each part has its own special properties. The brain can be divided into three basic units: the forebrain, the midbrain, and the hindbrain.

questions.Question: Centre of reflex action
questions.solution: Solution:		Central nervous system (specifically cerebellum) is the control centre of a reflex action. The impulse for reflex action travels to and from spinal cord.

questions.Question: Cerebro spinal fluid protects
questions.solution: Solution:		Cerebro spinal fluid protects the brain tissue from injury when jolted or hit, by providing a fluid buffer that acts as a shock absorber from some forms of mechanical injury.

questions.Question: Cerebrum is related to
questions.solution: Solution:		The cerebrum is the largest part of the brain. It is responsible for memory, speech, the senses, and emotional response. It is divided into four sections called lobes: the frontal, temporal, parietal, and occipital.

questions.Question: Which part of brain controls fine movement, maintains balance and equilibrium of the body and muscle tone in a human being ?
questions.solution: Solution:		The cerebellum (back of brain) is located at the back of the head. Its function is to coordinate voluntary muscle movements and to maintain posture, balance, and equilibrium.

questions.Question: How many teeth in man comes out twice?
questions.solution: Solution:		20 teeth in man comes out twice.

questions.Question: Appetite is triggered by
questions.optionD: Environmental cues such as the smell or taste of food
questions.solution: Solution:		Appetite is triggered by environmental cues such as the smell or taste of food. Appealing foods can stimulate appetite even when hunger is absent.

questions.Question: Where are the taste receptors located?
questions.solution: Solution:		The taste receptors are located in epiglottis, upper esophagus and tip of the tongue.

questions.Question: Assertion (A): In human body liver has an important role in fat digestion.Reason (R) : Liver produces two important fat digesting enzymes.Codes
questions.optionA: Both A and R are individually true and R is the correct explanation of A
questions.optionB: Both A and R are individually true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
questions.optionC: A is true R is false
questions.optionD: A is false but R is true
questions.solution: Solution:		Assertion is true but the reason is false.

questions.Question: Fat is completely digested in the
questions.solution: Solution:		The majority of fat digestion happens once it reaches the small intestine. This is also where the majority of nutrients are absorbed. Your pancreas produces enzymes that break down fats, carbohydrates, and proteins. Your liver produces bile that helps you digest fats and certain vitamins.

questions.Question: Which of the following bacterium causes crown gall disease in plants?
questions.solution: Solution:		Crown gall is caused by the bacterial plant pathogen, Agrobacterium tumefaciens. Crown gall bacteria enter plant roots through wounds.

questions.Question: Fossils of blue green algae were found in lime stones with the age almost as old as
questions.solution: Solution:		Fossils of blue green algae were found in lime stones with the age almost as old as 2.3 Billion years.

questions.Question: They have also proved extremely useful in our quest of knowledge of outer space.
questions.solution: Solution:		Yeasts have also proved extremely useful in our quest of knowledge of outer space.

questions.Question: Chemicals like ________ may be added to different foods or fruits to prevent or retard the growth microorganisms.
questions.solution: Solution:		Chemicals like potassium metabisulphite may be added to different foods or fruits to prevent or retard the growth microorganisms.

questions.Question: Eutrophication is the result of
questions.solution: Solution:		Eutrophication is the result of algae and aquatic plants.

questions.Question: Which of the following is a work done by the placenta tissue in humans?
questions.optionB: Removes waste matter from the embryo and provide nutrition to the embryo
questions.optionD: Remove waste matter from the embryo
questions.solution: Solution:		The placenta performs myriad functions to support fetal development, including facilitating blood flow, gas exchange, waste elimination, and serving as a protective barrier for the fetus against any infections the mother experiences during pregnancy.

questions.Question: Corpus luteum is associated with
questions.solution: Solution:		The corpus luteum secretes estrogens and progesterone. The latter hormone causes changes in the uterus that make it more suitable for implantation of the fertilized ovum and the nourishment of the embryo. If the egg is not fertilized, the corpus luteum becomes inactive after 10–14 days, and menstruation occurs.

questions.Question: A gland below the bladder and surrounding the urethra is
questions.solution: Solution:		Prostate gland is about the size of a walnut, and surrounds the neck of the bladder and urethra—the tube that carries urine from the bladder.

questions.Question: Snakes receive sound vibrations by
questions.solution: Solution:		Some snakes are able to perceive and react to substrate-borne vibrations. The vibrations are transmitted directly from skull to inner ear where it is sensed by brain. They also detect vibrations directly with receptors on their body surface. Thus, the correct answer is option B.

questions.Question: A man with colour blindness will see red as
questions.solution: Solution:		A person with color-blindness has trouble seeing red, green, blue, or mixtures of these colors. The most common type is red-green color-blindness, where red and green are seen as the same color.

questions.Question: What type of tissue is Blood?
questions.solution: Solution:		Blood is connective tissue.

questions.Question: The layer of cells between endodermis and vascular bundles is called
questions.solution: Solution:		The layer of cells between endodermis and vascular bundles is called pericycle.

questions.Question: Gymnosperms are characterized by the
questions.solution: Solution:		Gymnosperms are characterized by the absence of seeds.

questions.Question: In a bisexual flower if androecium and gynoecium mature at different time the phenomenon is known as ________
questions.solution: Solution:		In bisexual flower the production of male and female flower androecium and gynoecium mature at different times to avoid self-fertilization. That is called dichogamy.

questions.Question: The pollen grains of Pinus are carried to its female cone through the
questions.solution: Solution:		The pollen grains of Pinus are carried to its female cone through the wind.

questions.Question: The horizonatally growing hyphae of Rhizopus are called
questions.solution: Solution:		The horizonatally growing hyphae of Rhizopus are called stolons.

questions.Question: Which one of the following scientists first time saw bacteria through a microscope made by himself ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Antonie van Leeuwenhoek used single-lens microscopes, which he made, to make the first observations of bacteria and protozoa.

questions.Question: The unicellular algae used to supply and regulate the oxygen in space programmes is
questions.solution: Solution:		It is estimated that 2.3 kilograms of alga Chlorella pyrenoidosa produce enough oxygen to supply one man is space.

questions.Question: Amoeba moves in water with the help of locomotory organs called
questions.solution: Solution:		The locomotory organs of amoeba are called pseudopodia, which means 'fake feet'.

questions.Question: Bacteria are (were) considered more as plants than animals because of the presence of
questions.solution: Solution:		Both, plant cells and bacteria contain cell wall surrounding the cell membrane. Therefore, bacteria is said to be more like plant cell than animal cell.

questions.Question: Function of pace maker is
questions.optionA: To regulate the formation of urine
questions.optionB: To regulate the process of digestion
questions.optionD: To start the process of respiration
questions.solution: Solution:		A pacemaker is a small device that's placed in the chest or abdomen to help control abnormal heart rhythms. This device uses electrical pulses to prompt the heart to beat at a normal rate.

questions.Question: Which blood group is called universal donor?
questions.solution: Solution:		O- is called universal donor.

questions.Question: Blood group which has both antibodies is
questions.solution: Solution:		Blood group O is common, and individuals with this blood type will have both anti-A and anti-B in their serum.

questions.Question: Which among the following carries impure blood to human heart?
questions.solution: Solution:		The pulmonary artery carries impure blood to the right and left lungs. The left half of the heart collects and pumps pure (oxygenated) blood from the lungs to all parts of the body.

questions.Question: A person with 'AB' blood group is sometimes called a universal recipient because of the
questions.optionA: Lack of antigen in his b lood
questions.optionB: Lack of antibodies in his blood
questions.optionC: Lack of both antigen and antibodies in his blood
questions.optionD: Presence of antibodies in his blood
questions.solution: Solution:		A person with blood group AB is considered as the universal recipient as it contains both antigens such as A and B but no antibodies in plasma and thus, can accept all the blood type.

questions.Question: Which of the following plays an important part in photosynthesis?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Chloroplast contains the wonder green pigment chlorophyll which is able to trap solar energy and use it for synthesis of food.

questions.Question: Which of the following plays an important role in photosynthesis?
questions.solution: Solution:		Chloroplast plays an important role in photosynthesis.

questions.Question: Which of the following gas is necessary for the process of photosynthesis?
questions.solution: Solution:		To perform photosynthesis, plants need three things: carbon dioxide, water, and sunlight.

questions.Question: Photosynthesis fulfills which of the following requirements of the autotrophic organisms?I. CarbonII. WaterIII. Energy
questions.solution: Solution:		Carbon and energy requirements are fulfilled by photosynthesis.

questions.Question: The gas released during the photosynthesis by the green plants is
questions.solution: Solution:		The energy from light causes a chemical reaction that breaks down the molecules of carbon dioxide and water and reorganizes them to make the sugar (glucose) and oxygen gas.

questions.Question: What base does guanine pair with?
questions.solution: Solution:		Within the DNA molecule, guanine bases located on one strand form chemical bonds with cytosine bases on the opposite strand.

questions.Question: Which describes the correct pairing of DNA bases?
questions.solution: Solution:		Guanine - cytosine describes the correct pairing of DNA bases.

questions.Question: Sex determination of child is done by the chromosome of
questions.solution: Solution:		The sex of the child depends on the male chromosome which is transferred to the offspring. This happens because males have a mismatched pair of chromosome XY which is responsible for deciding the sex of the child.

questions.Question: The principle of dominance states that
questions.optionA: Some alleles are dominant, while others are recessive
questions.optionD: Alleles are neither dominant nor recessive
questions.solution: Solution:		Mendel's law of dominance states that in a heterozygote, one trait will conceal the presence of another trait for the same characteristic. Rather than both alleles contributing to a phenotype, the dominant allele will be expressed exclusively.

questions.Question: Which chemical is not found in DNA nucleotides?
questions.solution: Solution:		The only other difference in the nucleotides of DNA and RNA is that one of the four organic bases differs between the two polymers. The bases adenine, guanine, and cytosine are found in both DNA and RNA; thymine is found only in DNA, and uracil is found only in RNA.

questions.Question: Nitrogenous bases in DNA and RNA?
questions.solution: Solution:		The five-carbon sugar ring and the content of the nitrogenous base between DNA and RNA are slightly different from each other. Four different types of nitrogenous bases are found in DNA: adenine (A), thymine (T), cytosine (C), and guanine (G). In RNA, the thymine is replaced by uracil (U).

questions.Question: It is the study of hereditary characters transmitted from parents to offspring.
questions.solution: Solution:		Genetics is the study of how heritable traits are transmitted from parents to offspring. Humans have long observed that traits tend to be similar in families.

questions.Question: The inherited traits of an organism are controlled by
questions.solution: Solution:		The inherited traits of an organism are controlled by DNA molecules.

questions.Question: Which chromosomes are identical to each other on the basis of their morphology, position of centromere and other characteristics?
questions.solution: Solution:		Homologous chromosomes are identical to each other on the basis of their morphology, position of centromere and other characteristics.

questions.Question: Which is the correct pair of inherited chromosomes for the child to be a girl?
questions.optionA: X from father and Y from mother
questions.optionB: Y from father and X from mother
questions.optionC: Y from father and Y from mother
questions.optionD: X from father and X from mother
questions.solution: Solution:		 X from father and X from mother is the correct pair of inherited chromosomes for the child to be a girl.

questions.Question: In plants which one of the following tissues is dead ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Sclerenchyma cells are the permanent tissues present in the plants. They provide hardness and stiffness to the plant and are composed of dead cells. This tissue is present in stems around vascular bundles in the veins of leaves and in hard covering of seeds and nuts.

questions.Question: ________ connects muscle to the bones.
questions.solution: Solution:		A tendon is a fibrous connective tissue which attaches muscle to bone.

questions.Question: In animals like Annelids, Molluscs, organs have associated to form functional systems, each system concerned with a specific physiological function. This pattern is called ________ system level of organization.
questions.solution: Solution:		In animals like Annelids, Molluscs, organs have associated to form functional systems, each system concerned with a specific physiological function. This pattern is called organ system level of organization.

questions.Question: Xylem helps in transportation of which of the following?
questions.solution: Solution:		Xylem is one of the two types of transport tissue in vascular plants, phloem being the other. The basic function of xylem is to transport water from roots to stems and leaves, but it also transports nutrients.

questions.Question: Blood and lymph are types of
questions.solution: Solution:		Blood and lymph are types of connective tissues.

questions.Question: Haemoglobin is an important component of
questions.solution: Solution:		Hemoglobin is the most important component of red blood cells. It is composed of a protein called heme, which binds oxygen. In the lungs, oxygen is exchanged for carbon dioxide.

questions.Question: Hemoglobin, the oxygen carrying substance in red blood cells, is a
questions.solution: Solution:		Hemoglobin (Hgb) is an important protein in the red blood cells that carries oxygen from the lungs to all parts of our body. The main job of white blood cells, or leukocytes, is to fight infection.

questions.Question: What carries blood back to the heart?
questions.solution: Solution:		The circulatory system is made up of blood vessels that carry blood away from and towards the heart. Arteries carry blood away from the heart and veins carry blood back to the heart.

questions.Question: The smallest blood vessels which are one-cell thick, are called ________
questions.solution: Solution:		A capillary is a small blood vessel from 5 to 10 micrometres (μm) in diameter, and having a wall one endothelial cell thick. They are the smallest blood vessels in the body: they convey blood between the arterioles and venules.

questions.Question: Name the blood cells in which nucleus is absent.
questions.solution: Solution:		Blood Platelets doesn't have a nucleus.

questions.Question: Pellagra is caused due to the deficiency of
questions.solution: Solution:		Pellagra is caused by having too little niacin or tryptophan in the diet. It can also occur if the body fails to absorb these nutrients. Pellagra may also develop due to: Gastrointestinal diseases.

questions.Question: Rickets is caused due to the deficiency of
questions.solution: Solution:		Rickets is caused due to the deficiency of Calciferol.

questions.Question: The element found in bone and teeth is
questions.solution: Solution:		The element found in bone and teeth is calcium and phosphorus.

questions.Question: In Carbohydrates the ratio of hydrogen to oxygen is
questions.solution: Solution:		A carbohydrate is a biomolecule consisting of carbon (C), hydrogen (H) and oxygen (O) atoms, usually with a hydrogen–oxygen atom ratio of 2:1 (as in water) and thus with the empirical formula Cm(H2O)n (where m may be different from n).

questions.Question: The story of vitamins dates back to
questions.solution: Solution:		The story of vitamins dates back to 18th century.

questions.Question: The main thinking part of the brain is
questions.solution: Solution:		The main thinking part of the brain is forebrain.

questions.Question: What is the first thing that alcohol effects?
questions.solution: Solution:		Alcohol is absorbed into the lining of the stomach and then passes directly into the bloodstream and reaches your brain within minutes after consumption. A person's judgment is the first thing affected after drinking an alcoholic beverage.

questions.Question: Largest part of human brain is
questions.solution: Solution:		The largest part of the brain, the cerebrum has two hemispheres (or halves).

questions.Question: The functional connection between two neurons is a
questions.solution: Solution:		Synapse, also called neuronal junction, the site of transmission of electric nerve impulses between two nerve cells (neurons) or between a neuron and a gland or muscle cell (effector). A synaptic connection between a neuron and a muscle cell is called a neuromuscular junction.

questions.Question: The functional unit of the nervous system is the
questions.solution: Solution:		Neurons, or nerve cell, are the main structural and functional units of the nervous system. Every neuron consists of a body (soma) and a number of processes (neurites).

questions.Question: Red colour of blood is due to presence of
questions.solution: Solution:		Red colour of blood is due to presence of Hemoglobin.

questions.Question: Average life span of human R.B.C is
questions.solution: Solution:		Average life span of human R.B.C is 120 days.

questions.Question: With which of the following body organ is 'pace-maker' associated?
questions.solution: Solution:		Pacemaker is associated with heart. Pacemaker are implanted on the body of the patient to give artificial heart beat when the normal body heart beat fails to function in the body of the patient. They are implanted temporarily to treat a slow heartbeat after a heart attack, surgery or overdose of medication.

questions.Question: Which of the following blood group is called universal donor ?
questions.solution: Solution:		O- is called universal donor.

questions.Question: What carries blood away from the heart?
questions.solution: Solution:		Arteries carry blood away from the heart. Pulmonary arteries transport blood that has a low oxygen content from the right ventricle to the lungs. Systemic arteries transport oxygenated blood from the left ventricle to the body tissues.

questions.Question: Which one of the following parts of human brain is the regulating centre for swallowing and vomiting?
questions.solution: Solution:		The medulla oblongata helps regulate breathing, heart and blood vessel function, digestion, sneezing and swallowing. This part of the brain is a center for respiration and circulation. Sensory and motor neurons (nerve cells) from the forebrain and midbrain travel through the medulla.

questions.Question: Compared to land, the open oceans
questions.optionA: Are rich in silica and iron
questions.solution: Solution:		Compared to land, the open oceans are nutrient-poor environments.

questions.Question: Study of effect of radiation on plant and animal is
questions.solution: Solution:		Study of effect of radiation on plant and animal is Radiobiology.

questions.Question: Melvin calvin got Noble Prize for his studies on
questions.solution: Solution:		The Nobel Prize in Chemistry 1961 was awarded to Melvin Calvin "for his research on the carbon dioxide assimilation in plants."

questions.Question: Kyoto Protocol is associated with
questions.solution: Solution:		The Kyoto Protocol is an international agreement that aimed to manage and reduce carbon dioxide emissions and greenhouse gases. The Protocol was adopted at a conference in Kyoto, Japan, in 1997 and became international law on February 16, 2005.

questions.Question: Out of proteins, lipids and carbohydrates present in a cell membrane, what is true?
questions.optionD: All three are in equal proportion
questions.solution: Solution:		Carbohydrates are minimum in a cell membrane.

questions.Question: Potato is a modified form (outgrowth) of:
questions.solution: Solution:		Potato is a modified form (outgrowth) of stem.

questions.Question: Of the following taxonomic categories which is the most inclusive (i.e. is the highest in hierarchy)?
questions.solution: Solution:		Of the following taxonomic categories class is the most inclusive (i.e. is the highest in hierarchy).

questions.Question: Prothrombin which helps in clotting of blood is released by
questions.solution: Solution:		Prothrombin is a plasma protein which is converted into thrombin in the presence of thromboplastin released by platelets at the site of injury. The thrombin then converts protein fibrinogen into insoluble fibrin and thus aids in blood clotting.

questions.Question: Myopia is connected with
questions.solution: Solution:		Myopia is connected with eyes.

questions.Question: Pituitary gland is situated in
questions.solution: Solution:		The pituitary gland is a small gland that sits in the sella turcica, a bony hollow in the base of the skull, underneath the brain and behind the bridge of the nose.

questions.Question: The gland that is present close to trachea
questions.solution: Solution:		Thyroid glands are located in the neck, in close approximation to the first part of the trachea. In humans, the thyroid gland has a "butterfly" shape, with two lateral lobes that are connected by a narrow section called the isthmus.

questions.Question: Study of ductless gland is called
questions.solution: Solution:		Study of ductless gland is called endocrinology.

questions.Question: Cretinism is due to the disorder of the ______ gland.
questions.solution: Solution:		Cretinism is due to the disorder of the thyroid gland.

questions.Question: Pancreas secretes
questions.solution: Solution:		Pancreas secretes insulin, glucagon and pancreatic juice.

questions.Question: At the time of inspiration the diaphragm
questions.solution: Solution:		When the lungs inhale, the diaphragm contracts and pulls downward. At the same time, the muscles between the ribs contract and pull upward. This increases the size of the thoracic cavity and decreases the pressure inside. As a result, air rushes in and fills the lungs.

questions.Question: Rate of breathing in a minute by man is
questions.solution: Solution:		A normal breathing rate for an adult at rest is 8 to 16 breaths per minute.

questions.Question: The C shape of the tracheal cartilage is important because
questions.optionB: Allows for expansion or contraction of the trachea
questions.optionC: Provide a surface for the sense of smell
questions.solution: Solution:		The cartilaginous rings are C-shaped to allow the trachea to collapse slightly at the opening so that food can pass down the esophagus.

questions.Question: Alveoli is related to which of the following system of human body?
questions.solution: Solution:		Alveoli are tiny air sacs in your lungs that take up the oxygen you breathe in and keep your body going. Although they're microscopic, alveoli are the workhorses of your respiratory system.

questions.Question: Complete oxidation of sucrose in presence of oxygen into CO2, water and energy is called
questions.solution: Solution:		Aerobic respiration takes place in the presence of oxygen and finally degrades glucose to carbon dioxide and water with release of energy in form of ATP. So, the correct answer is option A.

questions.Question: Blood vessels bringing blood into Bowman's capsule is
questions.solution: Solution:		The blood enters the Bowman's capsule into the glomerulus through the afferent arterioles of the renal circulation. This is the vessel that brings blood into the Bowman's capsule. The filtered blood leaves the glomerulus through the efferent arteriole.

questions.Question: Which organ filters blood in human body?
questions.solution: Solution:		Kidneys filter waste and toxins out of the blood. They are responsible for taking waste out of other fluids in the body as well.

questions.Question: The renal corpuscle is made up of
questions.solution: Solution:		The renal corpuscle is made up of Bowman's capsule and Glomerulus.

questions.Question: Main nitrogenous product formed in man is
questions.solution: Solution:		The principle nitrogenous excretory compound in humans is urea. Urea is produced in a series of reactions (urea cycle) which take place in the mitochondrial matrix and cytosol of liver cells.

questions.Question: Loop of henle is related with
questions.solution: Solution:		Loop of henle is related with excretory system.

questions.Question: What is the study of cells called?
questions.solution: Solution:		The study of cells is called cytology or cellogysm.

questions.Question: Closely stacked flattened sacs (plants only) is called
questions.solution: Solution:		Closely stacked flattened sacs (plants only) is called Golgi apparatus.

questions.Question: Which one among the following cell organelles is semi-permeable ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Among the given example only nucleus is a cell organelle and rest are not cell organelle therefore nucleus is the correct answer.

questions.Question: Any foreign object that gains entry into the cell is immediately engulfed by the ________ and is completely broken into simple digestible pieces.
questions.solution: Solution:		Any foreign object that gains entry into the cell is immediately engulfed by the lysosomes and is completely broken into simple digestible pieces.

questions.Question: The function of nucleolus is the synthesis of
questions.solution: Solution:		The function of nucleolus is the synthesis of R-RNA.

questions.Question: Which of the following is necessary for digestion of food?
questions.solution: Solution:		Enzyme is necessary for digestion of food.

questions.Question: Where are Enzymes found?
questions.solution: Solution:		Enzymes are produced naturally in the body. For example, enzymes are required for proper digestive system function. Digestive enzymes are mostly produced in the pancreas, stomach, and small intestine.

questions.Question: Enzymes are important because they
questions.solution: Solution:		Enzymes create chemical reactions in the body. They actually speed up the rate of a chemical reaction to help support life. The enzymes in your body help to perform very important tasks.

questions.Question: Which one is the largest gland of human body?
questions.solution: Solution:		Liver is the largest gland in body. It stores its waste bile in Gall Bladder.

questions.Question: Colon and rectum is a part of
questions.solution: Solution:		The colon and rectum are part of large intestine, which is long, hollow tubes that run from stomach to anal opening.

questions.Question: Placenta is the structure formed
questions.optionA: by the union of foetal and uterine tissue
questions.solution: Solution:		Placenta is the structure formed by the union of foetal and uterine tissue.

questions.Question: Plants hormone that induces cell division is
questions.solution: Solution:		Plants hormone that induces cell division is gibberellins.

questions.Question: Neurospora is used as genetic material because
questions.optionA: it has short life cycle of 10 days
questions.optionB: the product of single meiosis can be easily analysed
questions.optionC: meiotic products are linearly arranged in the form of ordered tetrads
questions.solution: Solution:		Neurospora is used as genetic material because it has short life cycle of 10 days.

questions.Question: Phloem is a tissue found in
questions.solution: Solution:		Phloem, also called bast, tissues in plants that conduct foods made in the leaves to all other parts of the plant. Phloem is composed of various specialized cells called sieve tubes, companion cells, phloem fibres, and phloem parenchyma cells.

questions.Question: N2 content is kept constant in the biosphere due to
questions.solution: Solution:		N2 content is kept constant in the biosphere due to nitrogen cycle.

questions.Question: Lichens are the best indicator of
questions.solution: Solution:		Lichens are sensitive to atmospheric pollution such as nitrogen (N) because they receive all their nutrients and water from wet and dry atmospheric deposition (fall out).

questions.Question: Which one of the following processes takes place in lakes during eutrophication?
questions.optionC: Loss of dissolved nutrients from water
questions.optionD: Excessive entry of nutrient into water
questions.solution: Solution:		In lakes, when there's a excess entry ofnutrients in water, the growth of plant life takes place. This phenomenon is called Eutrophication. Thus, the correct answer is (d).

questions.Question: Which organelles supply energy to the cell?
questions.solution: Solution:		Mitochondria are membrane-bound cell organelles (mitochondrion, singular) that generate most of the chemical energy needed to power the cell's biochemical reactions. Chemical energy produced by the mitochondria is stored in a small molecule called adenosine triphosphate (ATP).

questions.Question: Who of the following is known as the Father of Biology?
questions.solution: Solution:		Development as a sequential knowledge of biology took place in the era of the famous Greek philosopher Aristotle (384-322 B.C.). He revealed his thoughts about various aspects of the life of plants and animals. Therefore, Aristotle is called as the Father of Biology.

questions.Question: Which is not a function of the cell membrane?
questions.optionA: Helps substances pass from the cytoplasm into the nucleus
questions.optionB: Keeps materials within the cell separated from the environment outside the cell
questions.optionC: Helps control the movement of materials into and out of the cell
questions.optionD: Allows the cell to change shape under pressure
questions.solution: Solution:		Cell membrane does not help substances pass from the cytoplasm into the nucleus.

questions.Question: The terminal part of the carpel in a flower, which may be sticky is ________
questions.solution: Solution:		The stigma is the top and sticky portion of a carpel or pistil that traps pollens.

questions.Question: The study of flower is known as
questions.solution: Solution:		Anthology is the branch of biology that deals with the study of flowers.

questions.Question: The innermost part of a flower is known as
questions.solution: Solution:		The innermost part of a flower is known as Stamens.

questions.Question: Ophthalmology is the branch of science in which we study about
questions.solution: Solution:		Ophthalmology is the branch of medicine which deals with the diseases of the eye and their treatment.

questions.Question: At which stage in its life cycle does the silkworm yield the fiber of commercial use?
questions.solution: Solution:		Silkworm yield the fiber of commercial use at pupa stage.

questions.Question: Octopus belongs to the phylum
questions.solution: Solution:		Octopus belongs to the phylum Mollusca.

questions.Question: Octopus is
questions.solution: Solution:		Octopus is a mollusc.

questions.Question: In coelenterates mesoderm gives rise to
questions.solution: Solution:		In coelentrates mesoderm gives rise to circulatory system.

questions.Question: It is the study of internal organs of organisms.
questions.solution: Solution:		The best known aspect of morphology, usually called anatomy, is the study of gross structure, or form, of organs and organisms.

questions.Question: Their cells have a very well defined nucleus ,in which nuclear material (chromosomes or DNA) is enclosed in double nuclear membrane.
questions.solution: Solution:		Eukaryotes cells have a very well defined nucleus, in which nuclear material (chromosomes or DNA) is enclosed in double nuclear membrane.

questions.Question: The subcellular organelle not bound by a single membrane is
questions.solution: Solution:		The subcellular organelle not bound by a single membrane is Lysosomes.

questions.Question: Which one is not found in the composition of plasma membrane?
questions.solution: Solution:		Minerals is not found in the composition of plasma membrane.

questions.Question: Which organelle in the cell, other than nucleus contains DNA?
questions.solution: Solution:		Mitochondria contain DNA other than nucleus.

questions.Question: The single membrane surrounding vacuoles in plant cells is known as
questions.solution: Solution:		Also called the vacuolar membrane, the tonoplast is the cytoplasmic membrane surrounding a vacuole, separating the vacuolar contents from the cell's cytoplasm.

questions.Question: Cellular respiration occurs in
questions.solution: Solution:		Cellular respiration occurs in the double-membrane organelle called the mitochondrion.

questions.Question: Gaseous exchange takes place in leaves through tiny pores for the purpose of photosynthesis. What are these pores?
questions.solution: Solution:		Stomata are tiny, microscopic pores that critical for photosynthesis.

questions.Question: The photosynthesis occurs in the
questions.solution: Solution:		The photosynthesis occurs in the day.

questions.Question: The oxygen released during photosynthesis process comes from
questions.solution: Solution:		The oxygen released during photosynthesis process comes from glucose.

questions.Question: In plants, photosynthesis mainly occurs in the
questions.solution: Solution:		In plants, the process of photosynthesis takes place in the mesophyll of the leaves, inside the chloroplasts. Chloroplasts contain disc-shaped structures called thylakoids, which contain the pigment chlorophyll.

questions.Question: Which one is important in photosynthesis to allows plants to absorb energy from light?
questions.solution: Solution:		Photosynthetic cells contain special pigments that absorb light energy. Different pigments respond to different wavelengths of visible light. Chlorophyll, the primary pigment used in photosynthesis, reflects green light and absorbs red and blue light most strongly.

questions.Question: Tissue in which cells have lost the capacity of cell division is
questions.solution: Solution:		In permanent tissue cells have lost the capacity of cell division.

questions.Question: Plant tissues are of how many types?
questions.solution: Solution:		Plant tissue differentiate into three main types: dermal, vascular, and ground tissue. Dermal tissue covers and protects the plant. Vascular tissue transports water, minerals, and sugars to different parts of the plant.

questions.Question: Detail study of internal organs at level of tissue with the help of microscope is called
questions.solution: Solution:		Histology, also known as microscopic anatomy or microanatomy, is the branch of biology which studies the microscopic anatomy of biological tissues. Histology is the microscopic counterpart to gross anatomy, which looks at larger structures visible without a microscope.

questions.Question: In plants and mineral salts from soil to the aerial parts of the plant are conducted through
questions.solution: Solution:		Xylem is associated with translocation of mainly water, mineral salts, some organic nitrogen and hormones, from roots to the aerial parts of the plants. The phloem translocates a variety of organic and inorganic solutes, mainly from the leaves to other parts of the plants.

questions.Question: Smooth muscles are likely to be found in
questions.solution: Solution:		Smooth muscle (so-named because the cells do not have striations) is present in the walls of hollow organs like the urinary bladder, uterus, stomach, intestines, and in the walls of passageways, such as the arteries and veins of the circulatory system, and the tracts of the respiratory, urinary, and reproductive system.

questions.Question: The group of pistils or carpels is collectively spoken off as a
questions.solution: Solution:		The group of pistils or carpels is collectively spoken off as a Gynoecium.

questions.Question: Each stamen has a slender stalk or filament at the top of which a pollen bearing organ is present.
questions.solution: Solution:		The part of the stamen where pollen is produced is called anther.

questions.Question: All sepals collectively constitute a structure termed as
questions.solution: Solution:		Sepals (collectively called the calyx) are modified leaves that encase the developing flower. They are sterile floral parts and may be either green or leaflike or composed of petal-like tissue.

questions.Question: An expanded basal portion of carpel is called as
questions.solution: Solution:		A pistil typically consists of an expanded basal portion called the ovary, an elongated section called a style and an apical structure that receives pollen called a stigma.

questions.Question: Taken together the petals constitute
questions.solution: Solution:		Together, all of the petals of a flower are called corolla.

questions.Question: Blood group which have no antibodies
questions.solution: Solution:		Blood group AB – has both A and B antigens, but no antibodies.

questions.Question: The sound lub-dub lub-dub is produced by
questions.solution: Solution:		The sound lub-dub lub-dub is produced by heart.

questions.Question: Blood is red in colour due to the presence of ________
questions.solution: Solution:		Hemoglobin is iron-containing oxygen transport protein in the red blood cells of all vertebrates. It has an oxygen binding capacity and gives the red colour to the blood.

questions.Question: Life of red blood cells in the body is
questions.solution: Solution:		Human red blood cells (RBC), after differentiating from erythroblasts in the bone marrow, are released into the blood and survive in the circulation for approximately 120 days. In humans and some other species, RBC normally survive in a nonrandom manner.

questions.Question: The upper chambers of the heart are the
questions.solution: Solution:		The upper chambers of the heart are the atria.

questions.Question: Diphtheria disease is caused by
questions.solution: Solution:		Diphtheria is a serious infection caused by strains of bacteria called Corynebacterium diphtheriae that make a toxin (poison).

questions.Question: Which of the following disease is non-communicable in nature?
questions.solution: Solution:		Cancer is a non communicable disease.

questions.Question: When a disease break out and spread from one place to another affecting large number of peoples it is called
questions.solution: Solution:		When a disease break out and spread from one place to another affecting large number of peoples it is called epidemic.

questions.Question: Which of the following disease is caused by female Anopheles mosquito?
questions.solution: Solution:		Malaria is transmitted to humans by female mosquitoes of the genus Anopheles. Female mosquitoes take blood meals for egg production, and these blood meals are the link between the human and the mosquito hosts in the parasite life cycle.

questions.Question: Which one among the following water-borne diseases is not caused by a bacteria ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Hepatitis A is not caused by a bacteria.

questions.Question: Surgical procedure in which a small portion of sperm duct is removed and cut end ligated in male is called
questions.solution: Solution:		Surgical procedure in which a small portion of sperm duct is removed and cut end ligated in male is called vasectomy.

questions.Question: Which of the following serves as a nutritive tissue for the growing embryo?
questions.solution: Solution:		The endosperm is a tissue produced inside the seeds of most of the flowering plants following fertilization. It is triploid (meaning three chromosome sets per nucleus) in most species. It surrounds the embryo and provides nutrition in the form of starch, though it can also contain oils and protein.

questions.Question: In the human being, normally in which one of the following parts, does the sperm fertilize the ovum?
questions.solution: Solution:		Human fertilization is the union of a human egg and sperm, usually occurring in the ampulla of the fallopian tube. The result of this union is the production of a zygote cell, or fertilized egg, initiating prenatal development.

questions.Question: Finger like ends of the fallopian tubes are called
questions.solution: Solution:		The fimbriae of the uterine tube, also known as fimbriae tubae, are small, finger like projections at the end of the fallopian tubes, through which eggs move from the ovaries to the uterus. The fimbriae are connected to the ovary.

questions.Question: Gestation period in human
questions.solution: Solution:		Gestation period in human is 9 month.

questions.Question: The camel's hump is composed of a tissue which provides water when oxidized. It is
questions.solution: Solution:		Camels humps are made from fatty adipose tissue. This concentrated fat minimizes heat trapping throughout the rest of the body. When the fat tissue is metabolized, it becomes energy and also yields more than 1gram of water.

questions.Question: Which among the following is not a connective tissue?
questions.solution: Solution:		Skin is composed of epithelial cells, and is therefore not an example of connective tissue. The major types of connective tissue include bone, adipose, blood, and cartilage.

questions.Question: The transport of organic substances in plants is through
questions.solution: Solution:		The transport of organic substances in plants is through phloem.

questions.Question: Who is regarded as father of plant tissue culture?
questions.solution: Solution:		On the basis of that 1902 address and his pioneering experimentation before and later, Haberlandt is justifiably recognized as the father of plant tissue culture.

questions.Question: What is common in both striated and cardiac cell?
questions.solution: Solution:		Striations is common in both striated and cardiac cell.

questions.Question: Normal adult human male has
questions.optionA: 10 gram of haemoglobin/100 gram of blood
questions.optionB: 14 gram of haemoglobin/100 gram of blood
questions.optionC: 18 gram of haemoglobin/100 gram of blood
questions.optionD: 24 gram of haemoglobin/100 gram of blood
questions.solution: Solution:		Normal adult human male has 14 gram of haemoglobin/100 gram of blood.

questions.Question: Plants wilt due to excess of
questions.solution: Solution:		Wilting is a condition when the amount of water lost from the plant during transpiration is greater the amount of water absorbed from the soil. It is the loss of rigidity of non-woody parts of the plants. This occurs when the turgor pressure in non-lignified plant cells falls towards zero, as a result of diminished water in the cells.

questions.Question: Monotremes are unique mammals because they
questions.solution: Solution:		Monotremes are different from other mammals because they lay eggs and have no teats. Monotremes are different from other mammals because they lay eggs and have no teats. The milk is provided for their young by being secreted by many pores on the female's belly.

questions.Question: Poison glands of snakes are homologous to
questions.solution: Solution:		Here Homologous Means having the same relation or relative position or structure.Here snakes poison is in glands and here salivary glands are in Vertebrates

questions.Question: Radical vascular bundles are those in which
questions.optionC: xylem and phloem occur on the same radius
questions.optionD: xylem and phloem occur on the different radii
questions.solution: Solution:		Radical vascular bundles are those in which xylem and phloem occur on the different radii.

questions.Question: Bacteria were first discovered by
questions.solution: Solution:		Two men are credited today with the discovery of microorganisms using primitive microscopes: Robert Hooke who described the fruiting structures of molds in 1665 and Antoni van Leeuwenhoek who is credited with the discovery of bacteria in 1676.

questions.Question: It is very serious disease of brain which is caused by fungi.
questions.solution: Solution:		Meningitis is very serious disease of brain which is caused by fungi.

questions.Question: Administering a vaccine provides protection by inducing synthesis of antibodies (proteins) specific of the vaccine. The cell in the body responsible for the production of antibodies is
questions.solution: Solution:		Lymphocyte is responsible for production of antibodies.

questions.Question: As an infant, the ability to produce antibodies is
questions.optionA: About 80% of that of an adult
questions.solution: Solution:		As an infant, the ability to produce antibodies is limited.

questions.Question: Antigen is a substance which
questions.optionD: Is used as an antidote to poison
questions.solution: Solution:		An antigen is any substance that causes your immune system to produce antibodies against it. This means your immune system does not recognize the substance, and is trying to fight it off. An antigen may be a substance from the environment, such as chemicals, bacteria, viruses, or pollen.

questions.Question: AIDS is caused by the organisms which are
questions.solution: Solution:		Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) is a chronic, potentially life-threatening condition caused by the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV).

questions.Question: Which of the following is not the part of digestive system ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Cornea is not the part of digestive system.

questions.Question: The enzyme found in saliva
questions.solution: Solution:		The enzyme found in saliva is Ptylin.

questions.Question: Which of the following is the largest gland in human body?
questions.solution: Solution:		Liver is the largest gland in body. It stores its waste bile in Gall Bladder. Bile is released into duodenum and helps in digestion of fats.

questions.Question: Which of the following is not a digestive enzyme in the human system?
questions.solution: Solution:		Gastrin is not a digestive enzyme, but a hormone.

questions.Question: In the human body which structure is the appendix attached to
questions.solution: Solution:		The appendix sits at the junction of the small intestine and large intestine. It's a thin tube about four inches long. Normally, the appendix sits in the lower right abdomen. The function of the appendix is unknown.

questions.Question: In a healthy person rate of heart beat on one minute is
questions.solution: Solution:		In a healthy person rate of heart beat on one minute is 72 times.

questions.Question: The word histology is related with
questions.solution: Solution:		The word histology is related with hematology.

questions.Question: Which one of the following statements regarding haemoglobin is correct?
questions.optionA: Haemoglobin present in RBC can carry only oxygen but not carbon dioxide
questions.optionB: Haemoglobin of RBC can carry both oxygen and carbon dioxide
questions.optionC: Haemoglobin of RBC can carry only carbon dioxide
questions.optionD: Haemoglobin is only used for blood clotting and not for carrying gases
questions.solution: Solution:		During respiration, about 97% of oxygen is transported by Red Blood Cells in blood and the remaining 3% gets dissolved in the plasma.Around 20-25% of carbon dioxide is carried by haemoglobin as carbamino-haemoglobin. Oxygen enters the blood from the lungs and carbon dioxide is expelled out of the blood into the lungs. The blood serves to transport both gases. Oxygen is carried to the cells. Carbon dioxide is carried away from the cells.

questions.Question: The vitamin required for coagulation of blood is
questions.solution: Solution:		Vitamin K is an essential vitamin that is needed by the body for blood clotting, bone building, and other important processes.

questions.Question: Amount of blood found in the body of man is
questions.solution: Solution:		Amount of blood found in the body of man is 7% total body weight.

questions.Question: We get pulse rate from
questions.solution: Solution:		We get pulse rate from artery.

questions.Question: Which of the following are involved directly in pulmonary circulation?
questions.optionA: Left ventricle, aorta, and inferior vena cava
questions.optionB: Right atrium, aorta, and left ventricle
questions.optionC: Superior vena cava, right atrium, and left ventricle
questions.optionD: Right ventricle, pulmonary artery, and left atrium
questions.solution: Solution:		The pulmonary circulation is the portion of the circulatory system which carries deoxygenated blood away from the right ventricle, to the lungs, and returns oxygenated blood to the left atrium and ventricle of the heart.

questions.Question: Rh factor is discovered by
questions.solution: Solution:		The Rh factor was discovered in 1940 by Landsteiner and Wiener. 5 Rabbits were injected with the blood of the rhesus monkey (Macacus rhesus).

questions.Question: Rh factor is related with
questions.solution: Solution:		Rh factor is related with monkey.

questions.Question: What is the main purpose of white blood corpuscles?
questions.solution: Solution:		The main purpose of white blood corpuscles is to combat infection.

questions.Question: Ordinary table salt is sodium chloride. What is baking soda?
questions.solution: Solution:		Sodium bicarbonate is baking soda.

questions.Question: Ozone hole refers to
questions.optionB: decrease in the ozone layer in troposphere
questions.optionC: decrease in thickness of ozone layer in stratosphere
questions.optionD: increase in the thickness of ozone layer in troposphere
questions.solution: Solution:		The term 'ozone hole' refers to the depletion of the protective ozone layer in the upper atmosphere (stratosphere) over Earth's polar regions. Stratospheric ozone is constantly produced by the action of the sun's ultraviolet radiation on oxygen molecules (known as photochemical reactions).

questions.Question: Pine, fir, spruce, cedar, larch and cypress are the famous timber-yielding plants of which several also occur widely in the hilly regions of India. All these belong to
questions.solution: Solution:		Pine, fir, spruce, cedar, larch and cypress are the famous timber-yielding plants of which several also occur widely in the hilly regions of India. All these belong to gymnosperms, a taxonomic class that includes plants whose seeds are not enclosed in an ovule.

questions.Question: Pollination is best defined as
questions.optionA: transfer of pollen from anther to stigma
questions.optionC: growth of pollen tube in ovule
questions.solution: Solution:		Pollination can be best defined as the transfer of pollen from the male anther of a flower to the female stigma to produce new offspring.

questions.Question: Plants receive their nutrients mainly from
questions.solution: Solution:		Plants receive their nutrients mainly from soil.

questions.Question: The corner of the cells of collenchyma tissue in plant are thickened due to deposition of ________
questions.solution: Solution:		The collenchyma is thickened due to deposition of pectin and cellulose.

questions.Question: Which plant cells give support to plant body?
questions.solution: Solution:		Sclerenchyma cells also provide support to the plant, but unlike collenchyma cells, many of them are dead at maturity.

questions.Question: Which plants have vascular tissues i.e .xylem and phloem vessel?
questions.solution: Solution:		Tracheophytes have vascular tissues i.e .xylem and phloem vessel.

questions.Question: Branch of science which deals with the study of tissue found in the body of organism is
questions.solution: Solution:		Histology is the branch of biology concerned with the composition and structure of plant and animal tissues in relation to their specialized functions.

questions.Question: Which one of the following is modification of parenchyma?
questions.solution: Solution:		Parenchyma cells with chloroplast to carry out photosynthesis are called as chlorenchyma cells. Therefore, option D is correct.

questions.Question: Protein synthesis in a bacterial cell is done by
questions.solution: Solution:		Ribosomes are protein-making factories found in all cells, from humans to bacteria. The ribosome will scan down the RNA, like a train going down tracks, adding in amino acids to the protein being produced. When the ribosome reaches the end of the RNA, the protein is released. This process is called translation.

questions.Question: Which one is the first organelle to be discovered?
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1833, Brown observed and described the nucleus, the first organelle. In 1838, the many and various observations were converted into a cell theory by Schleiden, who proposed that all plant tissues were composed of nucleated cells.

questions.Question: The cell was discovered by
questions.solution: Solution:		The cell was discovered by Robert Hooke.

questions.Question: The Powerhouse of the cell is
questions.solution: Solution:		Work on mitochondria did not stop in the 1950s after it was named “the powerhouse of the cell.”

questions.Question: In which year, Schwann and Schleiden suggested that cells were the basic unit of life
questions.solution: Solution:		Credit for developing cell theory is usually given to three scientists: Theodor Schwann, Matthias Jakob Schleiden, and Rudolf Virchow. In 1839, Schwann and Schleiden suggested that cells were the basic unit of life.

questions.Question: Nitrogenous Food is
questions.solution: Solution:		Proteins are nitrogenous foods. Nitrogenous foods as it is clear from the name are those foods which are high in the quantity of nitrogen they possess. Foods with nitrogen are the main ingredients when anyone talks about good health.

questions.Question: Which of the following crops would be preffered for sowing in order to enrich the soil with nitrogen?
questions.solution: Solution:		The "gram crops" would be preferred for sowing in order to enrich the "soil with nitrogen".

questions.Question: The temperature danger zone for food is
