questions.solution: Solution:		The temperature danger zone for food is 5 - 63 degree.

questions.Question:
Some species of which of the below kinds of organisms are employed as biopesticides?
1. Bacteria
2. Fungi
3. Flowering plants
questions.solution: Solution:		Bacteria are employed as biopesticides.

questions.Question: Golden rice has the highest quantity of
questions.solution: Solution:		Golden rice is a variety of rice (Oryza sativa) produced through genetic engineering to biosynthesize beta-carotene, a precursor of vitamin A, in the edible parts of rice.

questions.Question: In which phylum nerve cells are found but nerves are absent?
questions.solution: Solution:		In Coelenterata nerve cells are found but nerves are absent.

questions.Question: The non-vascular land plants are included in the group called
questions.solution: Solution:		Non vascular plants (often referred to collectively as the bryophytes) include three groups: the mosses (Bryophyta), approximately 15,000 species; liverworts (Hepaticophyta), approximately 7500 species; and hornworts (Anthocerophyta), approximately 250 species.

questions.Question: The animals in which the body cavity is absent are known as ________ .
questions.solution: Solution:		If the body cavity is absent called as acoelom and animal called as acoelomate e.g., Platyhelminthes.

questions.Question: Who is called the Father of Taxonomy?
questions.solution: Solution:		Carolus Linnaeus is called the Father of Taxonomy.

questions.Question: Spiders belong to the phylum
questions.solution: Solution:		Arthropod, (phylum Arthropoda), any member of the phylum Arthropoda, the largest phylum in the animal kingdom, which includes such familiar forms as lobsters, crabs, spiders, mites, insects, centipedes, and millipedes.

questions.Question: In plants, exchange of gases takes place through
questions.solution: Solution:		The exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide in the leaf (as well as the loss of water vapour in transpiration) occurs through pores called stomata (singular = stoma). Normally stomata open when the light strikes the leaf in the morning and close during the night.

questions.Question: The numerous minute pores in the epidermis of a leaf are called
questions.solution: Solution:		The numerous minute pores in the epidermis of a leaf are called stomata.

questions.Question: Stomata helps in
questions.solution: Solution:		Stomata helps in exchange of gases.

questions.Question: Release of water from plants as water droplets is known as
questions.solution: Solution:		Guttation is the loss of water in the form of water droplets from hydathodes (small pores) on the leaf margin of a small herbacious plant.

questions.Question: Stomata open at night in
questions.solution: Solution:		In CAM plants, stomata are open during the night and closed during day time. This is an adaptation of cutting transpiration loss of water. CAM plants grow in deserts and are exposed to high temperatures.Their stomata are open during the night for carbon dioxide uptake but closed during the day to prevent water loss. Thus, the correct answer is option C.

questions.Question: Chiropterophily is the process of pollination by
questions.solution: Solution:		Chiropterophily or bat pollination is the pollination of flowering plants by bats. Plants adapted to use bats or moths as pollinators typically have white petals, strong scent and flower at night, whereas plants that use birds as pollinators tend to produce copious nectar and have red petals.

questions.Question: Which of the following may cause the breakdown of pyruvate into lactic acid in our muscles?
questions.solution: Solution:		Lack of oxygen may cause the breakdown of pyruvate into lactic acid in our muscles.

questions.Question: The main result of aerobic respiration is the
questions.optionA: Production of lactic acid as an end product
questions.optionB: Production of ATP from the breakdown of glucose
questions.optionC: Conversion of radiant energy into chemical energy
questions.optionD: Storage of energy in a polysaccharide
questions.solution: Solution:		Aerobic respiration is the aerobic catabolism of nutrients to carbon dioxide, water, and energy, and involves an electron transport system in which molecular oxygen is the final electron acceptor.

questions.Question: What compound directly provides energy for cellular work?
questions.solution: Solution:		ATP compound directly provides energy for cellular work.

questions.Question: The outer membrane that covers the lungs
questions.solution: Solution:		The outer surfaces of the lungs are covered with a membrane called the pleura.

questions.Question: Which one of the following is a rich source of iron?
questions.solution: Solution:		Spinach is a rich source of iron.

questions.Question: The vitamin that is destroyed on heating is
questions.solution: Solution:		Vitamin C is a water-soluble and temperature-sensitive vitamin, so is easily degraded during cooking, and elevated temperatures and long cooking times have been found to cause particularly severe losses of vitamin C [12].

questions.Question: Which among the following is a vitamin?
questions.solution: Solution:		Follic acid is a vitamin.

questions.Question: They play key roles in the contraction of muscles,digestion of food and clotting of blood.
questions.solution: Solution:		Proteins play key roles in the contraction of muscles,digestion of food and clotting of blood.

questions.Question: Which one of the following organisms is dependent on saprophytic mode of nutrition?
questions.solution: Solution:		Saprophytic fungi feed on dead plant and animal remains. Many are extremely beneficial, breaking down this organic material into humus, minerals and nutrients that can be utilised by plants. Agaricus is one among them.

questions.Question: Which structure connects one bone to another bone?
questions.solution: Solution:		A tendon serves to move the bone or structure. A ligament is a fibrous connective tissue which attaches bone to bone, and usually serves to hold structures together and keep them stable.

questions.Question: Hinge joint is present between
questions.solution: Solution:		Hinge joint is present between humerus and radio-ulna.

questions.Question: Which of the following is not a form of Monosaccharide Sugar?
questions.solution: Solution:		Maltose is not a form of Monosaccharide Sugar.

questions.Question: All of the following are fat-soluble vitamins except
questions.solution: Solution:		All of the following are fat-soluble vitamins except Vitamin C.

questions.Question: Marasmus usually is associated with a deficiency of
questions.solution: Solution:		Marasmus usually is associated with a deficiency of Calories.

questions.Question: Nucleoli are present during
questions.solution: Solution:		Nucleoli are present during interphase.

questions.Question: Unlike Mitosis, Meiosis results in the formation of
questions.solution: Solution:		Unlike Mitosis, Meiosis results in the formation of 4 Genetically different cells. Meiosis results in the formation of 4 Haploid daughter cells from one Diploid parent cell.

questions.Question: How many daughter cells are produced in mitosis?
questions.solution: Solution:		2 daughter cells are produced in mitosis.

questions.Question: Chromosome start separating at which stage of mitosis?
questions.solution: Solution:		In anaphase, the sister chromatids separate from each other and are pulled towards opposite ends of the cell.

questions.Question: Almost all kinds of vegetative reproduction are carried out by the division known as
questions.solution: Solution:		Almost all kinds of vegetative reproduction are carried out by the division known as mitosis.

questions.Question: The scientific study of plants is termed as
questions.solution: Solution:		Botany, also called plant science(s), plant biology or phytology, is the science of plant life and a branch of biology. A botanist, plant scientist or phytologist is a scientist who specialises in this field.

questions.Question: Lobsters belong to which one of the following classes of organisms?
questions.solution: Solution:		Lobsters are farther categorized into the class Crustacea, along with other marine organisms like crabs and shrimp. These crustaceans are distinguishable from other Arthropods with hard exoskeletons, like mussels and clams, because their shell is softer and more flexible.

questions.Question: Fishes have a ________ chambered heart.
questions.solution: Solution:		Fish have a two-chambered heart with unidirectional circulation. Amphibians have a three-chambered heart, which has some mixing of the blood, and they have double circulation. Most non-avian reptiles have a three-chambered heart, but have little mixing of the blood; they have double circulation.

questions.Question: Which one of the following is not a chordate?
questions.solution: Solution:		Starfish is not a chordate.

questions.Question: Carica papaya is the scientific name of ________ .
questions.solution: Solution:		Carica papaya is the scientific name of papaya.

questions.Question: Number of cranial nerve found in man is
questions.solution: Solution:		Most doctors claim to have 12 cranial nerves, whereas humans in fact have 24 (12 pairs).

questions.Question: Centre of intelligence in human brain is
questions.solution: Solution:		Centre of intelligence in human brain is Cerebrum.

questions.Question: The schwann cell forms a myelin sheath around the
questions.solution: Solution:		Myelin is formed by Schwann cells in the peripheral nervous system (PNS) and oligodendrocytes in the central nervous system (CNS). Each Schwann cell forms a single myelin sheath around an axon.

questions.Question: The peripheral nervous system consists of
questions.solution: Solution:		The peripheral nervous system consists of the nerves that branch out from the brain and spinal cord. These nerves form the communication network between the CNS and the body parts. The peripheral nervous system is further subdivided into the somatic nervous system and the autonomic nervous system.

questions.Question: Which part of the brain plays an important role in motor control?
questions.solution: Solution:		In humans, the cerebellum plays an important role in motor control. It may also be involved in some cognitive functions such as attention and language as well as emotional control such as regulating fear and pleasure responses, but its movement-related functions are the most solidly established.

questions.Question: Nephron is related to which of the following system of human body?
questions.solution: Solution:		Excretory system consists of specialized structures and capillary networks that assist in the excretory process. The human excretory system includes the kidneys and their functional unit, the nephron.

questions.Question: Dialysis is used to perform the function of
questions.solution: Solution:		When your kidneys fail, dialysis keeps your body in balance by: removing waste, salt and extra water to prevent them from building up in the body, keeping a safe level of certain chemicals in your blood, such as potassium, sodium and bicarbonate and helping to control blood pressure.

questions.Question: Excretion is best described as the removal of
questions.optionA: Undigested material from the digestive tract
questions.optionC: Toxic wastes by the process of cyclosis
questions.solution: Solution:		Excretion is best described as the removal of metabolic wastes from a cell.

questions.Question: Islets of Langerhans are present in
questions.solution: Solution:		Islets of Langerhans are islands of endocrine cells scattered throughout the pancreas.

questions.Question: Filtration of blood occur in
questions.solution: Solution:		Filtration of blood occur in Bowmen's capsule.

questions.Question: Which among the following does not have a cell wall?
questions.solution: Solution:		Mycoplasma are a mollicute genus of bacteria that lack a cell wall around their cell membranes. Mycoplasma species are the smallest bacterial cells yet discovered, can survive without oxygen, and come in various shapes.

questions.Question: The ability to fix atmospheric nitrogen is found in the
questions.solution: Solution:		The ability to fix atmospheric nitrogen is found in the blue-green algae.

questions.Question: The number of chloroplasts in a cell of Spirogyra is
questions.solution: Solution:		The number of chloroplasts in a cell of Spirogyra is 1-14.

questions.Question: 'Pond silk' is the common name of
questions.solution: Solution:		Spirogyra is free-floating green algae present in freshwater habitats such as ponds, lakes, etc. Spirogyra is commonly known as water silk or pond silk.

questions.Question: Potato blight is caused by
questions.solution: Solution:		Potato blight is caused by meningitis.

questions.Question: Which of the following is the cellular respiratory centre?
questions.solution: Solution:		Cellular respiratory centre is the mitochondria.

questions.Question: The first root produced from a seed is known as
questions.solution: Solution:		The primary root, or radicle, is the first organ to appear when a seed germinates. It grows downward into the soil, anchoring the seedling. In gymnosperms and dicotyledons (angiosperms with two seed leaves), the radicle becomes a taproot.

questions.Question: The site in ovule where funicle is attached
questions.solution: Solution:		Nucellus is the wall of megasporangium and the part of ovule in which embryo sac develops. Nucellus provide nutrition to the growing embryo and also protects the embryo. Chalaza is the portion of ovule which is opposite to the region of attachment of nucellus, integuments and funicle. Micropyle is a small opening covered by the integuments and it is the site of entry of pollen tube during fertilisation. Hilum is a structure by which the body of ovule is attached to the funicle. So, the correct answer is D.

questions.Question: The seeds which contain abundant glyoxysomes are
questions.solution: Solution:		The seeds which contain abundant glyoxysomes are germinating seeds.

questions.Question: Skin is an example of what type of tissue?
questions.solution: Solution:		Skin is an example of epithelial tissue.

questions.Question: What is the effect of oversecretion of hormone from pituitary gland?
questions.solution: Solution:		When the pituitary gland produces excess growth hormones the result is excessive growth, called acromegaly. The excessive growth occurs first in the hands and feet, as soft tissue begins to swell.

questions.Question: Which of the following is not a gland?
questions.solution: Solution:		Gastrine is not a gland.

questions.Question: Oxytocin hormone is secreted by gland
questions.solution: Solution:		Oxytocin is produced in the hypothalamus and is secreted into the bloodstream by the posterior pituitary gland. Secretion depends on electrical activity of neurons in the hypothalamus – it is released into the blood when these cells are excited.

questions.Question: Enlargment of _______ gland takes place due to deficiency of iodine
questions.solution: Solution:		Enlargment of thyroid gland takes place due to deficiency of iodine.

questions.Question: Which one of following is not a endocrine gland?
questions.solution: Solution:		Endocrine glands are the ductless glands that secrete their products into bloodstream from where they are carried to the target organs. Pancreas, testes and thymus are endocrine glands as they secrete hormones. Pancreas secrete insulin and glucagon, testes secrete testosterone and thymus secrete thymosin hormone. Liver is not an endocrine gland instead, it is a digestive organ which secretes bile juice which is necessary for emulsification of fats.

questions.Question: Branch of science which deal with the study of causative agent of disease is
questions.solution: Solution:		Etiology is the science of causes; especially of disease.

questions.Question: Select the correct statement about active and passive immunity.
questions.optionA: A vaccination is an example of the introduction of passive immunity into the body
questions.optionB: Active and passive humoral immunity are both mechanisms of adaptive immunity that use antibodies
questions.optionC: Immunological memory is established by passive immunization
questions.optionD: The antibodies utilized in active immunity are acquired from another organism
questions.solution: Solution:		Active and passive humoral immunity are both mechanisms of adaptive immunity that use antibodies.

questions.Question: Polio is caused by
questions.solution: Solution:		Polio, or poliomyelitis, is a disabling and life-threatening disease caused by the poliovirus. The virus spreads from person to person and can infect a person's spinal cord, causing paralysis.

questions.Question: Rhinitis is the disease that effects which body part?
questions.solution: Solution:		Rhinitis is inflammation and swelling of the mucous membrane of the nose, characterized by a runny nose and stuffiness and usually caused by the common cold or a seasonal allergy. Colds and allergies are the most common causes of rhinitis.

questions.Question: Which disease is caused due to deficiency of Iodine?
questions.solution: Solution:		Worldwide, iodine deficiency is the most common cause of thyroid enlargement and goiter. Within a goiter, nodules can develop. Patients with a large goiter may experience symptoms of choking, especially when lying down, and difficulty swallowing and breathing.

questions.Question: Example of a single celled organism.
questions.solution: Solution:		Algae, Amoeba and Paramaecium all are single celled organism.

questions.Question: Chlamydomonas prefers water rich in
questions.solution: Solution:		Chlamydomonas is widely distributed in freshwater or damp soil. It is generally found in a habitat rich in ammonium salt.

questions.Question: The number of pyrenoids in a cell of Spirogyra is
questions.solution: Solution:		The biological parameters, which included cell width, cell length, number of chloroplast spirals, and number of pyrenoids, ranged from 40 to 90 μm, 85 to 263 μm, 5.5 to 16 spiral, and 50 to 240 pyrenoids, respectively.

questions.Question: Nuclear membrane is absent in
questions.solution: Solution:		Penicillium and Agaricus are fungi while Volvox is an alga. All three are eukaryotes thus have a membrane bound nucleus. Nostoc is a cyanobacterium, i.e., prokaryote, so it lacks true nucleus, thus nuclear membrane is absent.

questions.Question: Microscopic organism which passively float on the surface of water is called
questions.solution: Solution:		Microscopic organism which passively float on the surface of water is called Zooplanktons and Phytoplanktons.

questions.Question: The term biology is derived from the language
questions.solution: Solution:		The word biology is derived from the greek words "bios" meaning life and "logos" meaning study and is defined as the science of life and living organisms.

questions.Question: Which structure is common to plant and animal cells?
questions.solution: Solution:		Animal cells and plant cells share the common components of a nucleus, cytoplasm, mitochondria and a cell membrane. Plant cells have three extra components, a vacuole, chloroplast and a cell wall.

questions.Question: Which observation proves that a cell is a eukaryote?
questions.optionD: It has DNA inside a nucleus
questions.solution: Solution:		A eukaryotic cell is a cell which exhibit membrane-bound organelles. They exhibit a well-defined membrane bound nucleus in which the DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) resides it is the genetic material which is passed on from parents to their offsprings.

questions.Question: Physical basis of life is
questions.solution: Solution:		According to Huxley the protoplasm is the physical basis of life. Inside the cell wall of living cell the living substance is known as protoplasm. The protoplasm is a thick fluid or jellylike substance.

questions.Question: Where does cellular respiration take place in the cell?
questions.solution: Solution:		The enzymatic reactions of cellular respiration begin in the cytoplasm, but most of the reactions occur in the mitochondria. Cellular respiration occurs in the double-membrane organelle called the mitochondrion. The folds in the inner membrane are called cristae.

questions.Question: Which one of following is smallest gland of body?
questions.solution: Solution:		Pituitary is smallest gland of body among the following.

questions.Question: Deficiency of which minerals causes goitre?
questions.solution: Solution:		Deficiency of iodine causes goitre.

questions.Question: Chemical co-ordination in the body is brought out by
questions.solution: Solution:		In vertebrates the chemical coordination is brought about by endocrine glands which secrete hormones.

questions.Question: The disease Goitre is caused in persons who do not have in their diet sufficient
questions.solution: Solution:		Goitre is caused in persons who do not have sufficient iodine in their diet.

questions.Question: In case of a heart attack, a hormone is injected as an emergency measure, Which one is it?
questions.solution: Solution:		In the case of a heart attack, the hormone that injected as an emergency measure is Adrenaline. An adrenaline shot can increase the chance that the heart will regain a normal rhythm or restart your heart after a cardiac arrest by directing the flow of blood to the heart.

questions.Question: Which parts of the heart receive blood from the lungs?
questions.solution: Solution:		The left atrium receives oxygen-rich blood from the lungs and pumps it to the left ventricle through the mitral valve. The left ventricle pumps the oxygen-rich blood through the aortic valve out to the rest of the body.

questions.Question: The universal donor belongs to blood group
questions.solution: Solution:		The universal donor belongs to blood group O.

questions.Question: Person having blood group 'B' can donate the blood to person having blood group
questions.solution: Solution:		Person having blood group 'B' can donate the blood to person having blood group B and AB.

questions.Question: Scientist who discovered blood groups was
questions.solution: Solution:		Karl Landsteiner, was an Austrian biologist, physician, and immunologist. He distinguished the main blood groups in 1900, having developed the modern system of classification of blood groups.

questions.Question: Where do arteries carry blood?
questions.solution: Solution:		Arteries carry blood away from the heart. Pulmonary arteries transport blood that has a low oxygen content from the right ventricle to the lungs. Systemic arteries transport oxygenated blood from the left ventricle to the body tissues.

questions.Question: Bile produced by
questions.solution: Solution:		Bile is a fluid that is made and released by the liver and stored in the gallbladder. Bile helps with digestion. It breaks down fats into fatty acids, which can be taken into the body by the digestive tract.

questions.Question: Digestion starts in man from
questions.solution: Solution:		An adult's digestive tract is about 30 feet (about 9 meters) long. Digestion begins in the mouth, well before food reaches the stomach. When we see, smell, taste, or even imagine a tasty meal, our salivary glands in front of the ear, under the tongue, and near the lower jaw begin making saliva (spit).

questions.Question: Where does digestion of protein begins?
questions.solution: Solution:		Mechanical digestion of protein begins in the mouth and continues in the stomach and small intestine. Chemical digestion of protein begins in the stomach and ends in the small intestine. The body recycles amino acids to make more proteins.

questions.Question: After digestion protein is converted into
questions.solution: Solution:		When you eat food the body's digestive system breaks down the protein into the individual amino acids, which are absorbed and used by cells to build other proteins and a few other macromolecules, such as DNA.

questions.Question: Digestion of starch in mouth takes place by
questions.solution: Solution:		Digestion of starch in mouth takes place by Ptyline.

questions.Question: Out of 900 reported species of living gymnosperms, conifers are represented by about 500 species, About 2,50,000 species of angiosperms (flowering plants) have also been reported in the world. The vast and dominant woodlands in Europe, Asia, North America and mountains such as Himalayas are wooded with
questions.optionD: angiosperms and all gymnosperms except conifers
questions.solution: Solution:		Out of 900 reported species of living gymnosperms, conifers are represented by about 500 species, About 2,50,000 species of angiosperms (flowering plants) have also been reported in the world. The vast and dominant woodlands in Europe, Asia, North America and mountains such as Himalayas are wooded with only conifers.

questions.Question: One of the following is not a function of bones.
questions.optionC: Secretion of hormones for calcium regulation in blood and bones
questions.solution: Solution:		Secretion of hormones for calcium regulation in blood and bones is not a function of a bone.

questions.Question: Plants absorb most part of water needed by them through their
questions.solution: Solution:		Root hair cells are specialized epidermal cells that greatly increase the surface area of roots. The function of root hairs is to collect water and mineral nutrients present in the soil and take this solution up through the roots to the rest of the plant.

questions.Question: Photo-oxidation is
questions.solution: Solution:		Photo-oxidation involves all of the above process.

questions.Question: Process of cell division can take place by
questions.solution: Solution:		Mitosis is a process of nuclear division in eukaryotic cells that occurs when a parent cell divides to produce two identical daughter cells. During cell division, mitosis refers specifically to the separation of the duplicated genetic material carried in the nucleus.

questions.Question: Which of the following is a mixed gland?
questions.solution: Solution:		Pancreas is a mixed gland having both endocrine and exocrine functions. Endocrine portion secretes hormones, insulin and glucagon while the exocrine portion secretes an alkaline pancreatic juice containing enzymes and bicarbonate.

questions.Question: Female reproductive hormones is
questions.solution: Solution:		Reproductive hormones are usually made in the ovaries (in females) and testes (in males). Female reproductive hormones include estrogen and progesterone. They help develop and maintain female sex characteristics and play an important role in the menstrual cycle, fertility, and pregnancy.

questions.Question: Which of the following is an endocrine gland?
questions.solution: Solution:		Reproductive glands is an endocrine gland.

questions.Question: Growth hormone is secreted from
questions.solution: Solution:		Growth hormone (GH) is an ancestral hormone secreted episodically from somatotroph cells in the anterior pituitary.

questions.Question: Most important gland of human body is
questions.solution: Solution:		The pituitary gland is a small pea-sized gland that plays a major role in regulating vital body functions and general wellbeing. It is referred to as the body's 'master gland' because it controls the activity of most other hormone-secreting glands.

questions.Question: Through nitrogen fixation process nitrogen in the atmosphere is converted into
questions.solution: Solution:		Fixation converts nitrogen in the atmosphere into ammonium that plants can absorb through their root systems. A small amount of nitrogen can be fixed when lightning provides the energy needed for N2 to react with oxygen, producing nitrogen oxide, NO, and nitrogen dioxide, NO2.

questions.Question: In plants, which cells carry out photosynthesis?
questions.solution: Solution:		In plants, Chlorenchymatous carry out photosynthesis.

questions.Question: Part of the plant where photosynthesis generally occurs
questions.solution: Solution:		In plants, the process of photosynthesis takes place in the mesophyll of the leaves, inside the chloroplasts. Chloroplasts contain disc-shaped structures called thylakoids, which contain the pigment chlorophyll.

questions.Question: The energy stored in photosynthesis is obtained from
questions.solution: Solution:		The energy stored in photosynthesis is obtained from sunlight.

questions.Question: Maximum fixation of solar energy is done by
questions.solution: Solution:		The maximum 20% of the input of solar energy falling on leaves is converted into chemical energy by green plants. Green plants utilize solar energy and synthesize sugar from CO2 and water through the process of photosynthesis. However, they are able to utilize only 3% of the light energy that strikes on their green parts; the rest is dissipated as heat.

questions.Question: Pickles, candies, jams and breads are preserved by the much of adding
questions.solution: Solution:		There are many chemical preservatives used in food industry. Sodium benzoate is generally used is ketchups, pickles, jams etc.

questions.Question: Which type of bacteria get their food from dead organic matter?
questions.solution: Solution:		Saprophytic bacteria get their food from dead organic matter.

questions.Question: Heterocysts, specialised for nitrogen fixation, occur in certain
questions.solution: Solution:		Heterocysts, specialised for nitrogen fixation, occur in certain Blue green algae.

questions.Question: The number pyrenoids in Chlamydomonas is
questions.solution: Solution:		The number pyrenoids in Chlamydomonas is 1.

questions.Question: Commercial agar is obtained from
questions.solution: Solution:		The gelling agent in agar is an unbranched polysaccharide obtained from the cell walls of some species of red algae, primarily from tengusa (Gelidiaceae) and ogonori (Gracilaria). For commercial purposes, it is derived primarily from ogonori.

questions.Question: It is an oxygen carrying protein of red colour concentrated in red blood cells.
questions.solution: Solution:		Haemoglobin is an oxygen carrying protein of red colour concentrated in red blood cells.

questions.Question: Which blood group is a universal recipient?
questions.solution: Solution:		ABis a universal recipient.

questions.Question: The largest artery in human body is
questions.solution: Solution:		The largest artery in the body is the aorta, which is connected to the heart and extends down into the abdomen.

questions.Question: Number of chamber found in human heart is
questions.solution: Solution:		The heart consists of four chambers in which blood flows. Blood enters the right atrium and passes through the right ventricle. The right ventricle pumps the blood to the lungs where it becomes oxygenated. The oxygenated blood is brought back to the heart by the pulmonary veins which enter the left atrium.

questions.Question: Blood pressure is the pressure exerted on the wall of
questions.solution: Solution:		Blood pressure is the pressure that blood exerts on the wall of the blood vessels. This pressure originates in the contraction of the heart, which forces blood out of the heart and into the blood vessels. Two mechanisms take place in the heart: diastole and systole.

questions.Question: Longest bone found in man is
questions.solution: Solution:		The femur is one of the most researched bones in the human anatomy and forensic medicine.

questions.Question: What is the total number of bones in the human body?
questions.solution: Solution:		The adult human body has 206 bones.

questions.Question: Number of bones found in skull is
questions.solution: Solution:		Number of bones found in skull is 8.

questions.Question: How many pairs of ribs are there in human body?
questions.solution: Solution:		In humans there are normally 12 pairs of ribs. The first seven pairs are attached directly to the sternum by costal cartilages and are called true ribs.

questions.Question: Total number of bone found in man is
questions.solution: Solution:		Total number of bone found in man is 206.

questions.Question: What do eukaryotic cells have that prokaryotic cells do not?
questions.solution: Solution:		The primary distinction between these two types of organisms is that eukaryotic cells have a membrane-bound nucleus and prokaryotic cells do not. The nucleus is where eukaryotes store their genetic information.

questions.Question: The sea horse belongs to the class of
questions.solution: Solution:		The sea horse belongs to the class of fishes.

questions.Question: They are considered to be the most primitive and are surely the first of the vertebrates.
questions.solution: Solution:		Jawless fishes are considered to be the most primitive and are surely the first of the vertebrates.

questions.Question: They are extremely diverse group of organisms.
questions.solution: Solution:		Fungi are extremely diverse group of organisms.

questions.Question: In Animal Kingdom classification, which of the following is not a Phylum?
questions.solution: Solution:		In Animal Kingdom classification, coelomates is not a phylum.

questions.Question: Which is a homologous chromosome pair?
questions.solution: Solution:		Tetrad is a homologous chromosome pair.

questions.Question: A multicellular organism grows by ________ .
questions.solution: Solution:		All multicellular organisms use cell division for growth and the maintenance and repair of cells and tissues. Single-celled organisms use cell division as their method of reproduction.

questions.Question: At anaphase stage of mitosis in plant cells, interzonal of the spindle fibres gets transformed into
questions.solution: Solution:		At anaphase stage of mitosis in plant cells, interzonal of the spindle fibres gets transformed into Phragmoplast.

questions.Question: During which stage of mitosis does cytokinesis usually occur in animals?
questions.solution: Solution:		During telophase cytokinesis usually occur in animals.

questions.Question: During the metaphase and anaphase stages of cell division, each chromosome comprises of two unseparated replicas known as the
questions.solution: Solution:		During the metaphase and anaphase stages of cell division, each chromosome comprises of two unseparated replicas known as the chromatids.

questions.Question: Karl Landsteiner discovered
questions.solution: Solution:		Karl Landsteiner discovered blood groups.

questions.Question: Systolic and diastolic pressure in a healthy man is
questions.solution: Solution:		For a normal reading, your blood pressure needs to show a top number (systolic pressure) that's between 90 and less than 120 and a bottom number (diastolic pressure) that's between 60 and less than 80.

questions.Question: Red blood corpuscles is produced into
questions.solution: Solution:		Red blood cells are formed in the red bone marrow of bones. Stem cells in the red bone marrow called hemocytoblasts give rise to all of the formed elements in blood.

questions.Question: Oxygenated blood flows through which vessel?
questions.solution: Solution:		The oxygenated blood is brought back to the heart by the pulmonary veins which enter the left atrium. From the left atrium blood flows into the left ventricle. The left ventricle pumps the blood to the aorta which will distribute the oxygenated blood to all parts of the body.

questions.Question: Which of the following cells produce antibodies?
questions.solution: Solution:		Plasma cells produce antibodies.

questions.Question: Main function of white blood corpuscles is
questions.optionC: To produce immune system of body
questions.solution: Solution:		They protect you against illness and disease. Think of white blood cells as your immunity cells. In a sense, they are always at war. They flow through your bloodstream to fight viruses, bacteria, and other foreign invaders that threaten your health.

questions.Question: What is the average Life span of RBC?
questions.solution: Solution:		The average Life span of RBC is 120 days.

questions.Question: Red blood corpuscles is also known as
questions.solution: Solution:		Red blood cell, also called erythrocyte, cellular component of blood, millions of which in the circulation of vertebrates give the blood its characteristic colour and carry oxygen from the lungs to the tissues.

questions.Question: Blood group which have no antigen
questions.solution: Solution:		Blood group O – has no antigens, but both anti-A and anti-B antibodies in the plasma. blood group AB – has both A and B antigens, but no antibodies.

questions.Question: The normal blood pressure in human beings is
questions.solution: Solution:		Normal blood pressure: 90/60 to under 120/80 mm Hg in human beings.

questions.Question: Which is the cause of malaria infection?
questions.solution: Solution:		Malaria is caused by the Plasmodium parasite. The parasite can be spread to humans through the bites of infected mosquitoes.

questions.Question: In human beings influenza is caused by
questions.solution: Solution:		Influenza, commonly known as "the flu", is an infectious disease caused by an influenza virus. Symptoms can be mild to severe.

questions.Question: Asthma is caused due to
questions.solution: Solution:		Asthma is caused due to inflammation of lungs and spasm in bronchial muscles. The peculiar symptoms of the disease are coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. It is mainly caused due to environmental and genetic factor.

questions.Question: Cancer is caused by
questions.solution: Solution:		When cells of the body at a particular site start to grow out of control, they may become cancerous.

questions.Question: Sickle-cell anemia is a disease caused due to the abnormality in
questions.solution: Solution:		Sickle cell anemia is caused by a mutation in the gene that tells your body to make the iron-rich compound that makes blood red and enables red blood cells to carry oxygen from your lungs throughout your body (hemoglobin).

questions.Question: Mitochondria are also known as
questions.solution: Solution:		Mitochondria are often called the “powerhouses” or “energy factories” of a cell because they are responsible for making adenosine triphosphate (ATP), the cell's main energy-carrying molecule.

questions.Question: Which is the basic structural as well as functional unit for all organisms?
questions.solution: Solution:		In all life forms, including bacteria, plants, animals, and humans, the cell was defined as the most basic structural and functional unit.

questions.Question: Which organelles are involved in the manufacture and supply of energy to the cell?
questions.solution: Solution:		Cells also contain mitochondria and peroxisomes, which are the organelles responsible for producing the cell's energy supply and detoxifying certain chemicals, respectively. Biochemical reactions within mitochondria transform energy-carrying molecules into the usable form of cellular energy known as ATP.

questions.Question: Which statement is one component of the cell theory?
questions.optionA: DNA is the basis of genetic transfer
questions.optionB: All living cells arise from pre-existing cells
questions.optionC: All cells are composed of same organelles
questions.optionD: Tissues are formed from combinations of cells
questions.solution: Solution:		The three parts of the cell theory are as follows: (1) All living things are made up of cells, (2) Cells are the smallest units (or most basic building blocks) of life, and (3) All cells come from pre-existing cells through the process of cell division.

questions.Question: Do plant cells have Mitochondria?
questions.solution: Solution:		Both animal and plant cells have mitochondria, but only plant cells have chloroplasts. Plants don't get their sugar from eating food, so they need to make sugar from sunlight. This process (photosynthesis) takes place in the chloroplast.

questions.Question: Cells which takes part in secondary growth are named as
questions.solution: Solution:		Cambium, in plants, is a layer of actively dividing cells between xylem (wood) and phloem (bast) tissues.It is responsible for the secondary growth of stems and roots (secondary growth occurs after the first season and results in an increase in thickness). Hence, Cells which takes part in secondary growth are named as Cambium. So, the correct answer is 'Cambium'.

questions.Question: Bones join with muscles with the help of
questions.solution: Solution:		Bones join with muscles with the help of tendon.

questions.Question: Which type of permanent tissue helps the aquatic plants to float?
questions.solution: Solution:		The tissue which allows aquatic plants to float is Aerenchyma. Basically aerenchyma is parenchyma tissue in aquatic plants. The cells of aerenchyma make a network which has wide air spaces or air cavities for gaseous exchange. These air cavities make the plant light and buoyant and hence, plants can float easily in water.

questions.Question: The xylem in plants are responsible for:
questions.solution: Solution:		Xylem is one of the two types of transport tissue in vascular plants, phloem being the other. The basic function of xylem is to transport water from roots to stems and leaves, but it also transports nutrients.

questions.Question: Most abundant tissue in the body
questions.solution: Solution:		Connective tissue is the most abundant tissue type in the body. In general, connective tissue consists of cells and an extracellular matrix.

questions.Question: Which of the following is the largest phylum in the animal kingdom in respect of number of species?
questions.solution: Solution:		Arthropoda is by far the largest phylum in the animal kingdom. It includes insects, lobsters, mites, crabs etc. A recent estimate of the number of arthropods on Earth today is 3.7 million species.

questions.Question: It is stiff rod of special cells surrounded by connective tissue present in the mid-dorsal region and appears in the embryos of all chordates.
questions.solution: Solution:		Notochord is stiff rod of special cells surrounded by connective tissue present in the mid-dorsal region and appears in the embryos of all chordates.

questions.Question: Which of the following is cold blooded?
questions.solution: Solution:		Fish, frog and lizard all are cold blooded.

questions.Question: Higher vascular plants are also called
questions.solution: Solution:		The vascular plants, or tracheophytes, are plants that have specialized tissues for conducting water, minerals, and photosynthetic products through the plant. They include the ferns, clubmosses, horsetails, flowering plants, conifers and other gymnosperms. They are often called the higher plants or the seed plants.

questions.Question: A genus can best be defined as
questions.optionA: A taxon composed of one or more species and a classification level lying below family
questions.solution: Solution:		A genus can best be defined as a taxon composed of one or more species and a classification level lying below family.

questions.Question: Algae and fungi are collectively known as
questions.solution: Solution:		Algae and fungi are collectively known as thallophytes.

questions.Question: Which of the following is true about bryophytes?
questions.solution: Solution:		All of these is true about bryophytes.

questions.Question: In birds, some of the vertebrae are fused to form
questions.solution: Solution:		Some posterior thoracic vertebrae, the lumbar, sacral and a few anterior caudal vertebrae are fused to form a complex bone called synsacrum. The innominate bones are fused with the synsacrum to a greater or lesser extent, according to species, forming an avian pelvis.

questions.Question: They play a central role in the making of dairy products such as butter, cheese, yogurt etc.
questions.solution: Solution:		Bacteria play a central role in the making of dairy products such as butter, cheese, yogurt etc.

questions.Question: There are certain bacteria which can fix atmospheric gas named
questions.solution: Solution:		Nitrogen-fixing bacteria are prokaryotic microorganisms that are capable of transforming nitrogen gas from the atmosphere into “fixed nitrogen” compounds, such as ammonia, that are usable by plants. Read about nitrogen fixation.

questions.Question: Biogeographical regions are also called
questions.solution: Solution:		A biogeographic realm or ecozone is the broadest biogeographic division of Earth's land surface, based on distributional patterns of terrestrial organisms.

questions.Question: Hepatitis virus destroys the cells and may cause the disease
questions.solution: Solution:		Hepatitis virus destroys the cells and may cause the disease - jaundice.

questions.Question: It is disease which used to exist in the past in most countries of old world.
questions.solution: Solution:		Malaria used to exist in the past in most countries of old world.

questions.Question: Sleeping sickness in man is caused by the organism
questions.solution: Solution:		Human African trypanosomiasis, also known as sleeping sickness, is a vector-borne parasitic disease. It is caused by infection with protozoan parasites belonging to the genus Trypanosoma.

questions.Question: The harmful poisonous substances produced by bacteria are called
questions.solution: Solution:		Toxins are poisonous substances produced within living cells or organisms and can include various classes of small molecules or proteins that cause disease on contact.

questions.Question: The main function of Henle's loop is
questions.solution: Solution:		The principal function of the loop of Henle is in the recovery of water and sodium chloride from urine.

questions.Question: The ultimate cause of water movement in a plant stem against gravity is
questions.solution: Solution:		The ultimate cause of water movement in a plant stem against gravity is transpiration.

questions.Question: They protect plants from water loss and abrasive damage.
questions.solution: Solution:		Waxes protect plants from water loss and abrasive damage.

questions.Question: The suitable conditions in which the rate of evaporation occurs more fastly are
questions.optionD: Excess amount of water in the soil
questions.solution: Solution:		The suitable conditions in which the rate of evaporation occurs more fastly are low humidity and high temperature.

questions.Question: The device to measure transpiration in plants is
questions.solution: Solution:		A potometer, sometimes known as transpirometer, is a device used for measuring the rate of water uptake of a leafy shoot which is almost equal to the water lost through transpiration.

questions.Question: Study of nose and alfactory organs is called
questions.solution: Solution:		Study of nose and alfactory organs is called Rhinology.

questions.Question: The size of the pupil is controlled by the
questions.solution: Solution:		The size of the pupil is controlled by the activities of two muscles: the circumferential sphincter muscle found in the margin of the iris, innervated by the parasympathetic nervous system: and the iris dilator muscle, running radially from the iris root to the peripheral border of the sphincter.

questions.Question: Damage to hearing is caused by sounds which exceed
questions.solution: Solution:		Noise is a level of sound beyond the capacity of ears. Normal level of sound for conversation is 60 decibels and lawn mower is 90 decibels that can not harm the ears but very high levels of noise (at or above 120 decibels) exposure can leads to hearing loss. Noise-induced hearing loss is irreversible, the main form of treatment is prevention.

questions.Question: Myopia is connected with
questions.solution: Solution:		Myopia is connected with eyes.

questions.Question: Human beings hearing range is ________
questions.solution: Solution:		Human beings hearing range is 20 to 20,000 Hz.

questions.Question: Of the following, which is the most fundamental generalization in biology?
questions.solution: Solution:		Cell theory is the most fundamental generalization in biology.

questions.Question: Where does protein synthesis take place?
questions.solution: Solution:		Ribosomes are the sites in a cell in which protein synthesis takes place. Cells have many ribosomes, and the exact number depends on how active a particular cell is in synthesizing proteins.

questions.Question: Membrane bound pigment containing bodies present in the cells are called as
questions.solution: Solution:		The plastid is a membrane-bound organelle found in the cells of plants, algae, and some other eukaryotic organisms.

questions.Question: Lysosome is formed from which of the following cell organelles?
questions.solution: Solution:		Lysosomes originate by budding off from the membrane of the trans-Golgi network, a region of the Golgi complex responsible for sorting newly synthesized proteins, which may be designated for use in lysosomes, endosomes, or the plasma membrane.

questions.Question: In the cell of animals, some microorganisms and lower plants contain
questions.solution: Solution:		In the cell of animals, some microorganisms and lower plants contain two centriole.

questions.Question: Such plants which are adapted to survival under conditions a limited supply of water in its habitat are known as
questions.solution: Solution:		A xerophyte is a species of plant that has adaptations to survive in an environment with little liquid water, such as a desert or an ice- or snow-covered region in the Alps or the Arctic. Popular examples of xerophytes are cacti, pineapple and some Gymnosperm plants.

questions.Question: Azolla is a
questions.solution: Solution:		Azolla (mosquito fern, duckweed fern, fairy moss, water fern) is a genus of seven species of aquatic ferns in the family Salviniaceae. They are extremely reduced in form and specialized, looking nothing like other typical ferns but more resembling duckweed or some mosses.

questions.Question: Bamboo is classified as
questions.solution: Solution:		Bamboo is classified as grass.

questions.Question: Bios means
questions.solution: Solution:		Bios means life.

questions.Question: In mainly which phylum the body of an organisms is usually divided in there regions called head, thorax and abdomen?
questions.solution: Solution:		Class Insecta is the largest group of arthropods and includes mainly terrestrial arthropods with a distinct head, thorax and abdomen, one pair of antennae, three pairs of legs, jaws and up to two pairs of wings. This group includes most of the familiar creatures affectionately known as "bugs".

questions.Question: ________ being a higher category, is the assemblage of families which exhibit a few similar characters.
questions.solution: Solution:		Order being a higher category, is the assemblage of families which exhibit a few similar characters.

questions.Question: Subphylum vertebrata is also known as
questions.solution: Solution:		Vertebrate, also called Craniata, any animal of the subphylum Vertebrata, the predominant subphylum of the phylum Chordata.

questions.Question: How many vertebrae found in human vertebral column?
questions.solution: Solution:		Vertebrae are the 33 individual bones that interlock with each other to form the spinal column. The vertebrae are numbered and divided into regions: cervical, thoracic, lumbar, sacrum, and coccyx.

questions.Question: Biological classification of plants and animals was first proposed by
questions.solution: Solution:		Biological classification of plants and animals was first proposed by Aristotle on the basis of simple morphological characters.

questions.Question: Bacteria is included in the kingdom classification of
questions.solution: Solution:		In the five kingdom classification, bacteria are included in Kingdom Monera. Bacteria are cosmopolitan in distribution. These organisms show the most extensive metabolic diversity. Bacteria may be autotrophic or heterotrophic in their mode of nutrition.

questions.Question: In most plants and animals, the fluid filled sacs or cisternae of Golgi Bodies may vary from
questions.solution: Solution:		In most plants and animals, the fluid filled sacs or cisternae of Golgi Bodies may vary from 3 to 7.

questions.Question: A cell consists of three main components which is ________
questions.solution: Solution:		A cell consists of three parts: the cell membrane, the nucleus, and, between the two, the cytoplasm.

questions.Question: These are rods or filament like very small bodies present in the cytoplasm of all cells of plants and animals.
questions.solution: Solution:		Mitochondria are rods or filament like very small bodies present in the cytoplasm of all cells of plants and animals.

questions.Question: Through cell membrane, which substances can pass more easily than others?
questions.solution: Solution:		Lipid soluble can pass more easily.

questions.Question: Which of the following are longest cells of human body?
questions.solution: Solution:		The longest cell in the human body is the neuron. Neurons are cells of the nervous system that process and transmit information throughout the body.

questions.Question: Pollen grains in plants are produced in
questions.solution: Solution:		Pollen grains in plants are produced in flower.

questions.Question: Nitrogen is fixed in ecosystems in ways stated below. Which one of the statements below is false?
questions.optionB: By electrical discharges in the atmosphere
questions.solution: Solution:		Nitrogen is not fixed in ecosystems by denitrification.

questions.Question: Ptyalin is an enzyme produced in the
questions.solution: Solution:		Ptyalin is produced by the salivary glands, whereas pancreatic amylase is secreted by the pancreas into the small intestine.

questions.Question: Mycobacterium leprae causes leprosy, Corynebacterium diphtheria causes diphtheria and Vibrio comma causes
questions.solution: Solution:		Vibrio cholerae (also Kommabacillus) is a gram negative comma-shaped bacterium with a polar flagellum that causes cholera in humans

questions.Question: Biotic component of the environment does not include-
questions.solution: Solution:		Animal, Micro organism and Plants are biotic components of the environment while soil along with other landforms are non-biotic components of the environment.

questions.Question: The stages between larval moults in an insect are called
questions.solution: Solution:		An instar is a developmental stage of arthropods, such as insects, between each moult (ecdysis), until sexual maturity is reached.

questions.Question: In which of the following stages of silkworm, silk is secreted
questions.solution: Solution:		Silkworms feed on fresh mulberry leaves the silkworm grows in size and then becomes a pupa. In the pupa stage, it weaves a net to hold itself. It then swings its head from side to side, secreting a fibre that hardens on contact with air. In pupa stage silk is obtained.

questions.Question: Which is the longest bone in the human body?
questions.solution: Solution:		The femur is one of the most researched bones in the human anatomy and forensic medicine. As the longest bone in the human body, it is well preserved in skeletal remains.

questions.Question: The bone of which organ is the longest in the human body?
questions.solution: Solution:		The bone of thigh called femur is the longest in the human body.

questions.Question: Treatment of body defects through massage and exercise is
questions.solution: Solution:		Physiology is branch of medicine that studies towards proper functioning and working of human body. The methods used to do so are referred as physiotherapy. The person expert in physiology is called as physiotherapist. Physiotherapy is done after recovery of bone damage to ensure it's complete working as a normal bone. So, the correct option is 'Physiotherapy'.

questions.Question: In plants, which of the following cells are used to store surplus food?
questions.solution: Solution:		Parenchymatous cells are used to store surplus food in plants.

questions.Question: Which tissue makes the plant hard and stiff?
questions.solution: Solution:		Sclerenchyma is the tissue which makes the plant hard and stiff. Sclerenchyma is the supporting tissue in plants. Two types of sclerenchyma cells exist: fibers cellular and sclereids.

questions.Question: Excess of fat in the body is stored in
questions.solution: Solution:		The extra energy is stored in adipose tissue all around the body in the form of triglycerides.

questions.Question: Study of tissue culture is useful for
questions.solution: Solution:		Tissue culture studies have clarified the genetic causes of certain hereditary diseases, and methods have been developed for detecting environmental substances that may cause gene damage. It has been important for plants.

questions.Question: What is the name of a group of similar cells performing a specific function?
questions.solution: Solution:		A tissue is a group of similar cells performing similar functions. Each tissue has a specific function.

questions.Question: Which of the following structure is not found in a eukaryotic cell?
questions.solution: Solution:		Mesosome is not found in a eukaryotic cell.

questions.Question: Which of the following is found in plant cells but not in animal cells?
questions.solution: Solution:		Plant cells have a cell wall, chloroplasts and other specialized plastids, and a large central vacuole, which are not found within animal cells. The cell wall is a rigid covering that protects the cell, provides structural support, and gives shape to the cell.

questions.Question: Prokaryotic cell differs from eukaryotic cell in lacking
questions.solution: Solution:		The primary distinction between these two types of organisms is that eukaryotic cells have a membrane-bound nucleus and prokaryotic cells do not.

questions.Question: The prokaryotic cell lacks
questions.solution: Solution:		The prokaryotic cell lacks nuclear envelope and plastids.

questions.Question: Which is the only human cell that has a flagella?
questions.solution: Solution:		An example of a eukaryotic flagellate cell is the mammalian sperm cell, which uses its flagellum to propel itself through the female reproductive tract.

questions.Question: Innate immune system defenses include
questions.solution: Solution:		When pathogens enter the body, the innate immune system responds with a variety of internal defenses. These include the inflammatory response, phagocytosis, natural killer cells, and the complement system.

questions.Question: A vehicle borne transmitted diseases are
questions.solution: Solution:		Vehicle-borne transmission is a vehicle that is, an inanimate object or material called in scientific terms a "fomite"—becomes contaminated with the infectious agent. The agent, such as a virus, may or may not have multiplied or developed in or on the vehicle. The vehicle contacts the person's body. Plague and Malaria are vehicle borne transmitted diseases.

questions.Question: Plasmodium is a
questions.solution: Solution:		Plasmodium, a genus of parasitic protozoans of the sporozoan subclass Coccidia that are the causative organisms of malaria. Plasmodium, which infects red blood cells in mammals (including humans), birds, and reptiles, occurs worldwide, especially in tropical and temperate zones.

questions.Question: Study of the effects of toxic chemical substance on animal and plant is
questions.solution: Solution:		Toxicology is traditionally defined as "the science of poisons." Over time, our understanding of how various agents can cause harm to humans and other organisms has increased, resulting in a more descriptive definition of toxicology as "the study of the adverse effects of chemical, physical, or biological agents

questions.Question: Main function of antibodies is against
questions.solution: Solution:		Antibodies contribute to immunity in three ways: preventing pathogens from entering or damaging cells by binding to them (neutralization); stimulating removal of pathogens by macrophages and other cells by coating the pathogen (opsonization); and triggering destruction of pathogens by stimulating other immune responses.
